main.docTitle: The Rules of the District Court

section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation, etc., Application, Interpretation and Forms

section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation (O. 1, r. 1)

subsection.content: These Rules may be cited as the Rules of the District Court.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application (O. 1, r. 2)

subsection.content: Subject to this rule, these Rules shall have effect in relation to all proceedings in the Court.

These Rules shall not have effect in relation to proceedings of the kinds specified in column 1 of the following Table (being proceedings in respect of which rules may be made under the enactments specified in column 2 of that Table).

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (2B), these Rules shall not have effect in relation to— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings under Part III of the Landlord and Tenant (Consolidation) Ordinance (Cap. 7);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: matrimonial proceedings (except for an appeal against any judgment, order or decision of a judge to which Order 58 shall apply); (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: proceedings under the Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Ordinance (Cap. 189) (except for an appeal against any judgment, order or decision of a judge to which Order 58 applies); (L.N. 153 of 2008; 18 of 2009 s. 19)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: proceedings—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the recovery of employees’ compensation; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in respect of which rules are made under section 50 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282). (L.N. 221 of 2001)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.content: Subject to section 85(1) of the Landlord and Tenant (Consolidation) Ordinance (Cap. 7), Order 58 has effect in relation to an appeal against a judgment, order or decision of the Court made under Part III of that Ordinance. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
These Rules shall not have effect in relation to any criminal proceedings other than any criminal proceedings to which Order 62 applies.

In the case of the proceedings mentioned in paragraphs (2), (2A) and (3), nothing in those paragraphs shall be taken as affecting any provision of any rules (whether made under the Ordinance or any other Ordinance) by virtue of which the Rules of the District Court (Cap. 336 sub. leg. H) or any provision thereof is applied in relation to any of those proceedings. (E.R. 4 of 2017)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Application of Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (O. 1, r. 3)
section.content: The Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall apply to the interpretation of these Rules as it applies to subsidiary legislation made after the commencement of that Ordinance.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Definitions (O. 1, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: In these Rules, unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the meanings hereby respectively assigned to them, namely—
subsection.def: action for personal injuries (就人身傷害而提出的訴訟) means an action in which there is a claim for damages in respect of personal injuries to the plaintiff or any other person or in respect of a person’s death, and personal injuries (人身傷害) includes any disease and any impairment of a person’s physical or mental condition; (L.N. 153 of 2008)
aided person (受助人) means an aided person within the meaning of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91); (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Amendment Rules 2008 (《2008年修訂規則》) means the Rules of the District Court (Amendment) Rules 2008 (L.N. 153 of 2008); (L.N. 153 of 2008)
cause book (訟案登記冊) means the book or any computer record kept in the Registry in which the letter and number of, and other details relating to, a cause or matter are entered;
judgment rate (判定利率) means the rate of interest determined by the Chief Justice under section 50(1)(b) of the Ordinance; (18 of 2003 s. 22)
money lender’s action (放債人訴訟) has the meaning assigned to it by Order 83A;

notice of intention to defend (擬抗辯通知書) means an acknowledgment of service containing a statement to the effect that the person by whom or on whose behalf it is signed intends to contest the proceedings to which the acknowledgment relates;
officer (人員) means an officer of the Court;
originating summons (原訴傳票) means every summons other than a summons in a pending cause or matter;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a direction issued by the Chief Justice as to the practice and procedure of the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a direction issued by a specialist judge for his specialist list; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.def: the Ordinance (本條例) means the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
writ (令狀) means a writ of summons;
written law (成文法律) includes Ordinance and enactment as defined in section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1). (L.N. 153 of 2008)

In these Rules, unless the context otherwise requires, the Court (區域法院) means the District Court or any judge thereof whether sitting in court or in chambers or the Registrar or any master but the foregoing provision shall not be taken as affecting any provision of these Rules and, in particular, Order 32, rule 16 by virtue of which the authority and jurisdiction of the Registrar is defined and regulated.

subsection.content: In these Rules, unless the context otherwise requires, any reference to acknowledging service of a document or giving notice of intention to defend any proceedings is a reference to lodging in the Registry an acknowledgment of service of that document or, as the case may be, a notice of intention to defend those proceedings.
For the purposes of the definition cause book, the book kept in the Registry may be in written form or in such other form or medium which can be reproduced in written form.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Construction of references to Orders, rules, etc. (O. 1, r. 5)

subsection.content: Unless the context otherwise requires, any reference in these Rules to a specified Order, rule or Appendix is a reference to that Order or rule of, or that Appendix to, these Rules and any reference to a specified rule, paragraph or subparagraph is a reference to that rule of the Order, that paragraph of the rule or that subparagraph of the paragraph in which the reference occurs.

Any reference in these Rules to anything done under a rule of these Rules includes a reference to the same thing done under a rule of these Rules before the commencement of that rule under any corresponding rule of court ceasing to have effect on the commencement of that rule.

Except where the context otherwise requires, any reference in these Rules to any written law shall be construed as a reference to that written law as amended, extended or applied by or under any other written law.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Construction of references to action, etc., for possession of land (O. 1, r. 6)
section.content: Except where the context otherwise requires, references in these Rules to an action or claim for the possession of land shall be construed as including references to proceedings against the Government for an order declaring that the plaintiff is entitled as against the Government to the land or to the possession thereof.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Construction of references to Registrar (O. 1, r. 6A)
section.content: Wherever the word “Registrar” appears in these Rules and forms, there may be substituted the word “master” when and where appropriate.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Forms (O. 1, r. 9)
section.content: The forms in the Appendices shall be used where applicable with such variations as the circumstances of the particular case require.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Rules not to exclude conduct of business by post (O. 1, r. 10)
section.content: Nothing in these Rules shall prejudice any power to regulate the practice of the Court by giving directions enabling any business or class of business to be conducted by post.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Objectives

section.name: s1
section.heading: Underlying objectives (O. 1A, r. 1)
section.leadIn: The underlying objectives of these Rules are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to increase the cost-effectiveness of any practice and procedure to be followed in relation to proceedings before the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to ensure that a case is dealt with as expeditiously as is reasonably practicable;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to promote a sense of reasonable proportion and procedural economy in the conduct of proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to ensure fairness between the parties;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to facilitate the settlement of disputes; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to ensure that the resources of the Court are distributed fairly.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application by the Court of underlying objectives (O. 1A, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall seek to give effect to the underlying objectives of these Rules when it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exercises any of its powers (whether under its inherent jurisdiction or given to it by these Rules or otherwise); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: interprets any of these Rules or a practice direction.

subsection.content: In giving effect to the underlying objectives of these Rules, the Court shall always recognize that the primary aim in exercising the powers of the Court is to secure the just resolution of disputes in accordance with the substantive rights of the parties.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Duty of the parties and their legal representatives (O. 1A, r. 3)
section.content: The parties to any proceedings and their legal representatives shall assist the Court to further the underlying objectives of these Rules.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Court’s duty to manage cases (O. 1A, r. 4)

subsection.content: The Court shall further the underlying objectives of these Rules by actively managing cases.

subsection.leadIn: Active case management includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: encouraging the parties to co-operate with each other in the conduct of the proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identifying the issues at an early stage;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: deciding promptly which issues need full investigation and trial and accordingly disposing summarily of the others;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: deciding the order in which the issues are to be resolved;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: encouraging the parties to use an alternative dispute resolution procedure if the Court considers that appropriate, and facilitating the use of such a procedure;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: helping the parties to settle the whole or part of the case;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: fixing timetables or otherwise controlling the progress of the case;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: considering whether the likely benefits of taking a particular step justify the cost of taking it;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: dealing with as many aspects of the case as practicable on the same occasion;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: dealing with the case without the parties needing to attend at court;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: making use of technology; and

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: giving directions to ensure that the trial of a case proceeds quickly and efficiently.

section.name: s1B
section.heading: Case Management Powers

section.name: s1
section.heading: Court’s general powers of management (O. 1B, r. 1)

subsection.content: The list of powers in this rule is in addition to and not in substitution for any powers given to the Court by any other rule or practice direction or by any other enactment or any powers it may otherwise have.

subsection.leadIn: Except where these Rules provide otherwise, the Court may by order—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: adjourn or bring forward a hearing;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require a party or a party’s legal representative to attend the Court;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: direct that part of any proceedings (such as a counterclaim) be dealt with as separate proceedings;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: stay the whole or part of any proceedings or judgment either generally or until a specified date or event;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: consolidate proceedings;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: try two or more claims on the same occasion;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: direct a separate trial of any issue;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: decide the order in which issues are to be tried;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: exclude an issue from consideration;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: dismiss or give judgment on a claim after a decision on a preliminary issue;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: take any other step or make any other order for the purpose of managing the case and furthering the underlying objectives set out in Order 1A.

subsection.leadIn: When the Court makes an order, it may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make it subject to conditions, including a condition to pay a sum of money into court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the consequences of failure to comply with the order or a condition.

subsection.content: Where a party pays money into court following an order under paragraph (3), the money is security for any sum payable by that party to any other party in the proceedings.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Court’s power to make order of its own motion (O. 1B, r. 2)

subsection.content: Except where a rule or some other enactment provides otherwise, the Court may exercise its powers on an application or of its own motion.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court proposes to make an order of its own motion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it may give any person likely to be affected by the order an opportunity to make representations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it does so, it shall specify the time by and the manner in which the representations must be made.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court proposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make an order of its own motion; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to hold a hearing to decide whether to make the order,

subsection.continued: it shall give each party likely to be affected by the order at least 3 days’ notice of the hearing.

subsection.content: The Court may make an order of its own motion, without hearing the parties or giving them an opportunity to make representations.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has made an order under paragraph (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party affected by the order may apply to have it set aside, varied or stayed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the order must contain a statement of the right to make such an application.

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (5)(a) must be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within such period as may be specified by the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Court does not specify a period, not more than 14 days after the date on which notice of the order was sent to the party making the application.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Court’s power to give procedural directions by way of order nisi (O. 1B, r. 3)

subsection.content: Where the Court considers that it is necessary or desirable to give a direction on the procedure of the Court and that the direction is unlikely to be objected to by the parties, it may of its own motion and without hearing the parties, give the direction by way of an order nisi.
The order nisi becomes absolute 14 days after the order is made unless a party has applied to the Court for varying the order.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Effect of Non-Compliance

section.name: s1
section.heading: Non-compliance with Rules (O. 2, r. 1)

subsection.content: Where, in beginning or purporting to begin any proceedings or at any stage in the course of or in connection with any proceedings, there has, by reason of any thing done or left undone, been a failure to comply with the requirements of these Rules, whether in respect of time, place, manner, form or content or in any other respect, the failure shall be treated as an irregularity and shall not nullify the proceedings, any step taken in the proceedings, or any document, judgment or order therein.

Subject to paragraph (3), the Court may, on the ground that there has been such failure as is mentioned in paragraph (1), and on such terms as to costs or otherwise as it thinks just, set aside either wholly or in part the proceedings in which the failure occurred, any step taken in those proceedings or any document, judgment or order therein or exercise its powers under these Rules to allow such amendments (if any) to be made and to make such order (if any) dealing with the proceedings generally as it thinks fit.

The Court shall not wholly set aside any proceedings or the writ or other originating process by which they were begun on the ground that the proceedings ought to have begun by an originating process other than the one employed, but shall instead give directions for the continuation of the proceedings in an appropriate manner. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application to set aside for irregularity (O. 2, r. 2)

subsection.content: An application to set aside for irregularity any proceedings, any step taken in any proceedings or any document, judgment or order therein shall not be allowed unless it is made within a reasonable time and before the party applying has taken any fresh step after becoming aware of the irregularity.
An application under this rule may be made by summons and the grounds of application must be stated in the summons.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Non-compliance with rules and court orders (O. 2, r. 3)

subsection.content: The Court may order a party to pay a sum of money into court if that party has, without good reason, failed to comply with a rule or court order.

subsection.leadIn: When exercising its power under paragraph (1), the Court shall have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount in dispute; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs which the parties have incurred or which they may incur.

subsection.content: Where a party pays money into court following an order under paragraph (1), the money is security for any sum payable by that party to any other party in the proceedings.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Sanctions have effect unless defaulting party obtains relief (O. 2, r. 4)
section.content: Where a party has failed to comply with a rule or court order, any sanction for failure to comply imposed by the rule or court order has effect unless the party in default applies to the Court for and obtains relief from the sanction within 14 days of the failure.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Relief from sanctions (O. 2, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: On an application for relief from any sanction imposed for a failure to comply with any rule or court order, the Court shall consider all the circumstances including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the interests of the administration of justice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the application for relief has been made promptly;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether the failure to comply was intentional;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether there is a good explanation for the failure to comply;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the extent to which the party in default has complied with other rules and court orders;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whether the failure to comply was caused by the party in default or his legal representative;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: in the case where the party in default is not legally represented, whether he was unaware of the rule or court order, or if he was aware of it, whether he was able to comply with it without legal assistance;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: whether the trial date or the likely trial date can still be met if relief is granted;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the effect which the failure to comply had on each party; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the effect which the granting of relief would have on each party.

subsection.content: An application for relief must be supported by evidence.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Time

section.name: s1
section.heading: Month (月) means calendar month (O. 3, r. 1)
section.content: Without prejudice to section 3 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) in its application to these Rules, the word month (月), where it occurs in any judgment, order, direction or other document forming part of any proceedings in the Court, means a calendar month unless the context otherwise requires.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Reckoning periods of time (O. 3, r. 2)

subsection.content: Any period of time fixed by these Rules or by any judgment, order or direction for doing any act shall be reckoned in accordance with this rule.
Where the act is required to be done within a specified period after or from a specified date, the period begins immediately after that date.
Where the act is required to be done within or not less than a specified period before a specified date, the period ends immediately before that date.

Where the act is required to be done a specified number of clear days before or after a specified date, at least that number of days must intervene between the day on which the act is done and that date.
Where, apart from this paragraph, the period in question, being a period of 7 days or less, would include a specified day, that day shall be excluded. (18 of 2016 s. 21)

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Saturday;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a general holiday;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a gale warning day as defined by section 71(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a black rainstorm warning day as defined by that section; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: (if the act in question is required to be done at an office of the Court) another day on which the office is closed. (18 of 2016 s. 21)

section.name: s4
section.heading: Time expires on day on which office is closed (O. 3, r. 4)

subsection.content: Where the time prescribed by these Rules, or by any judgment, order or direction, for doing any act at an office of the Court expires on a specified day, and by reason thereof that act cannot be done on that day, the act shall be in time if done on the next day on which that office is open. (18 of 2016 s. 22)

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

def.name: SpecifiedDay
def.leadIn: specified day (指明日子), in relation to an office of the Court, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Saturday;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a general holiday;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a gale warning day as defined by section 71(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a black rainstorm warning day as defined by that section; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: another day on which the office is closed. (18 of 2016 s. 22)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Extensions, etc., of time (O. 3, r. 5)

subsection.content: The Court may, on such terms as it thinks just, by order extend or abridge the period within which a person is required or authorized by these Rules, or by any judgment, order or direction, to do any act in any proceedings.
The Court may extend any such period as is referred to in paragraph (1) although the application for extension is not made until after the expiration of that period.

The period within which a person is required by these Rules, or by any order or direction, to serve, file or amend any pleading or other document may be extended by consent (given in writing) without an order of the Court being made for that purpose.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Notice of intention to proceed after year’s delay (O. 3, r. 6)
section.content: Where a year or more has elapsed since the last proceeding in a cause or matter, the party who desires to proceed must give to every other party not less than one month’s notice of his intention to proceed. A summons on which no order was made is not a proceeding for the purposes of this rule.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Transfer and Consolidation of Proceedings

section.name: s1
section.heading: Transfer to the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal (O. 4, r. 1)
section.text: An application under section 41 or 42 of the Ordinance for an order transferring proceedings to the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal shall be made by summons and shall be supported by an affidavit stating the grounds on which the application is made and verifying the facts relied on.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Consolidation, etc., of causes or matters (O. 4, r. 9)

subsection.leadIn: Where 2 or more causes or matters are pending, then, if it appears to the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that some common question of law or fact arises in both or all of them; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the rights to relief claimed therein are in respect of or arise out of the same transaction or series of transactions; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that for some other reason it is desirable to make an order under this rule,

subsection.continued: the Court may order those causes or matters to be consolidated on such terms as it thinks just or may order them to be tried at the same time, or one immediately after another, or may order any of them to be stayed until after the determination of any other of them.

subsection.content: Where the Court makes an order under paragraph (1) that 2 or more causes or matters are to be tried at the same time but no order is made for those causes or matters to be consolidated, then a party to one of those causes or matters may be treated as if it were a party to any of those other causes or matters for the purpose of making an order for costs against him or in his favour.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Mode of Beginning Civil Proceedings in the Court

section.name: s1
section.heading: Mode of beginning civil proceedings (O. 5, r. 1)
section.content: Subject to the provisions of any written law and of these Rules, civil proceedings in the Court may be begun by writ or originating summons.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Proceedings which may be begun by writ or originating summons (O. 5, r. 4)

subsection.content: Except in the case of proceedings which under any written law are required or authorized to be begun by a specific form of originating process, proceedings may be begun either by writ or by originating summons as the plaintiff considers appropriate. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: Proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in which the sole or principal question at issue is, or is likely to be, one of the construction of any written law or of any instrument made under any written law or of any deed, will, contract or other document, or some other question of law; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in which there is unlikely to be any substantial dispute of fact,

subsection.continued: are appropriate to be begun by originating summons unless the plaintiff intends in those proceedings to apply for judgment under Order 14 or Order 86 or for any other reason considers the proceedings more appropriate to be begun by writ.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Proceedings to be begun by motion or petition (O. 5, r. 5)
section.content: Proceedings may be begun by originating motion or petition if, but only if, under any written law the proceedings in question are required or authorized to be so begun.

section.name: s5A
section.heading: Right to Act in Person

section.name: s1
section.heading: Right to act in person (O. 5A, r. 1)
section.content: Subject to rule 2 and to Order 80, rule 2, any person (whether or not he acts as a trustee or personal representative or in any other representative capacity) may begin or carry on proceedings in the Court in person or by a solicitor.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Corporations acting by a director (O. 5A, r. 2)

subsection.content: Subject to Order 12, rule 1(2), a corporation may not begin or carry on any such proceedings in the Court otherwise than by a solicitor except as expressly provided by or under any enactment or by this rule.

subsection.leadIn: A corporation may begin or carry on proceedings by one of its directors where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a solicitor does not act for the corporation in the proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the director has been duly authorized by the board of directors of the corporation to act on its behalf in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the director has made and filed at the Registry an affidavit stating that he has been duly authorized by the board of directors of the corporation to act on its behalf in the proceedings and exhibiting—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the original of the resolution authorizing the director to act on behalf of the corporation; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a copy of such resolution duly certified by another person who must either be a director or the secretary of the corporation. (L.N. 221 of 2001)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Writs of Summons: General Provisions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Form of writ (O. 6, r. 1)
section.content: Every writ must be in Form No. 1 in Appendix A.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Indorsement of claim (O. 6, r. 2)
section.leadIn: Before a writ is issued, it must be indorsed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with a statement of claim or, if the statement of claim is not indorsed on the writ, with a concise statement of the nature of the claim made or the relief or remedy required in the action begun thereby;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the claim made by the plaintiff is for a debt or liquidated demand only, with a statement of the amount claimed in respect of the debt or demand and for costs and also with a statement that further proceedings will be stayed if, within the time limited for acknowledging service, the defendant pays the amount so claimed to the plaintiff, his solicitor or agent; and (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the only remedy that the plaintiff is seeking is the payment of money, with a statement that the defendant may make an admission in accordance with Order 13A within the period fixed for service of his defence. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Indorsement as to capacity (O. 6, r. 3)
section.leadIn: Before a writ is issued, it must be indorsed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the plaintiff sues in a representative capacity, with a statement of the capacity in which he sues;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where a defendant is sued in a representative capacity, with a statement of the capacity in which he is sued.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Indorsement as to solicitor and address (O. 6, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Before a writ is issued, it must be indorsed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the plaintiff sues by a solicitor, with the plaintiff’s address and the solicitor’s name or firm and a business address of his within the jurisdiction and also (if the solicitor is the agent of another) the name or firm and a business address of his principal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the plaintiff other than a corporation sues in person, with the address of his place of residence and, if his place of residence is not within the jurisdiction or if he has no place of residence, the address of a place within the jurisdiction at or to which documents for him may be delivered or sent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the plaintiff which is a corporation sues in person, with the address of its registered or principal office and, if its registered or principal office is not within the jurisdiction, the address of a place within the jurisdiction at or to which documents for it may be delivered or sent.

subsection.leadIn: The address for service of a plaintiff shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where he sues by a solicitor, the business address to which may be added a numbered box at a document exchange of the solicitor indorsed on the writ;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where he sues in person, the address within the jurisdiction indorsed on the writ.

subsection.content: Where a solicitor’s name is indorsed on a writ, he must, if any defendant who has been served with or who has acknowledged service of the writ requests him in writing so to do, declare in writing whether the writ was issued by him or with his authority or privity.

If a solicitor whose name is indorsed on a writ declares in writing that the writ was not issued by him or with his authority or privity, the Court may on the application of any defendant who has been served with or who has acknowledged service of the writ, stay all proceedings in the action begun by the writ.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Concurrent writ (O. 6, r. 6)

subsection.content: One or more concurrent writs may, at the request of the plaintiff, be issued at the time when the original writ is issued or at any time thereafter before the original writ ceases to be valid.

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), a writ for service within the jurisdiction may be issued as a concurrent writ with one which is to be served out of the jurisdiction and a writ which is to be served out of the jurisdiction may be issued as a concurrent writ with one for service within the jurisdiction.
A concurrent writ is a true copy of the original writ with such differences only (if any) as are necessary having regard to the purpose for which the writ is issued.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Issue of writ (O. 6, r. 7)

content.leadIn: No writ which is to be served out of the jurisdiction shall be issued without the leave of the Court:
content.proviso: Provided that if every claim made by a writ is one which by virtue of any written law the Court has power to hear and determine notwithstanding that the person against whom the claim is made is not within the jurisdiction of the Court or that the wrongful act, neglect or default giving rise to the claim did not take place within its jurisdiction, the foregoing provision shall not apply to the writ.

subsection.content: Issue of a writ takes place upon its being sealed by an officer of the Registry.
The officer by whom a concurrent writ is sealed must mark it as a concurrent writ with an official stamp.

No writ shall be sealed unless at the time of the tender thereof for sealing the person tendering it leaves at the office at which it is tendered a copy thereof signed, where the plaintiff sues in person, by him or, where he does not so sue, by or on behalf of his solicitor.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Duration and renewal of writ (O. 6, r. 8)

subsection.content: For the purpose of service, a writ (other than a concurrent writ) is valid in the first instance for 12 months beginning with the date of its issue and a concurrent writ is valid in the first instance for the period of validity of the original writ which is unexpired at the date of issue of the concurrent writ.

Where a writ has not been served on a defendant, the Court may by order extend the validity of the writ from time to time for such period, not exceeding 12 months at any one time, beginning with the day next following that on which it would otherwise expire, as may be specified in the order, if an application for extension is made to the Court before that day or such later day (if any) as the Court may allow.
Before a writ, the validity of which has been extended under this rule, is served, it must be marked with an official stamp showing the period for which the validity of the writ has been so extended.

Where the validity of a writ is extended by order made under this rule, the order shall operate in relation to any other writ (whether original or concurrent) issued in the same action which has not been served so as to extend the validity of that other writ until the expiration of the period specified in the order.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Originating Summonses: General Provisions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application (O. 7, r. 1)
section.content: The provisions of this Order apply to all originating summonses subject, in the case of originating summonses of any particular class, to any special provisions relating to originating summonses of that class made by these Rules or by or under any written law.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Form of summons, etc. (O. 7, r. 2)

subsection.content: Every originating summons (other than an ex parte summons) shall be in Form No. 8 in Appendix A or, if so authorized or required, in Form No. 10 in Appendix A, and every ex parte originating summons shall be in Form No. 11 in Appendix A.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Form No. 8 in Appendix A is to be used in all cases except where another form is prescribed under a written law or there is no party on whom the summons is to be served. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: Form No. 10 in Appendix A is to be used if it is prescribed under a written law. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: Form No. 11 in Appendix A is to be used if there is no party on whom the summons is to be served. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
The party taking out an originating summons (other than an ex parte summons) shall be described as a plaintiff, and the other parties shall be described as defendants.
This rule is subject to Order 121, rule 2. (L.N. 4 of 2016)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Contents of summons (O. 7, r. 3)

subsection.content: Every originating summons must include a statement of the questions on which the plaintiff seeks the determination or direction of the Court or, as the case may be, a concise statement of the relief or remedy claimed in the proceedings begun by the originating summons with sufficient particulars to identify the cause or causes of action in respect of which the plaintiff claims that relief or remedy.
Order 6, rules 3 and 5, shall apply in relation to an originating summons as they apply in relation to a writ.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Concurrent summons (O. 7, r. 4)
section.content: Order 6, rule 6, shall apply in relation to an originating summons as it applies in relation to a writ.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Issue of summons (O. 7, r. 5)

subsection.content: An originating summons shall be issued out of the Registry.
Order 6, rule 7, shall apply in relation to an originating summons as it applies in relation to a writ.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Duration and renewal of summons (O. 7, r. 6)
section.content: Order 6, rule 8, shall apply in relation to an originating summons as it applies in relation to a writ.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Ex parte originating summonses (O. 7, r. 7)

subsection.content: Rules 2(1) and (1C), 3(1) and 5(1) shall, so far as applicable, apply to ex parte originating summonses; but, save as aforesaid, the foregoing rules of this Order shall not apply to ex parte originating summonses. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Order 6, rule 7(3) and (5), shall, with the necessary modifications, apply in relation to an ex parte originating summons as they apply in relation to a writ.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Originating and Other Motions: General Provisions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application (O. 8, r. 1)
section.content: The provisions of this Order apply to all motions required or authorized under a written law, subject to any provisions relating to any class of motion made by that written law or any other written law.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Notice of motion (O. 8, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Except where an application by motion may properly be made ex parte, no motion shall be made without previous notice to the parties affected thereby, but the Court, if satisfied that the delay caused by proceeding in the ordinary way would or might entail irreparable or serious mischief, may make an order ex parte—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on such terms as to costs or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to such undertaking, if any, as it thinks just.

subsection.content: Any party affected by an order made under paragraph (1) may apply to the Court to set it aside.
Unless the Court gives leave to the contrary, there must be at least 2 clear days between the service of notice of a motion and the day named in the notice for hearing the motion.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Form and issue of notice of motion (O. 8, r. 3)

subsection.content: The notice of an originating motion must be in Form No. 13 in Appendix A and the notice of any other motion in Form No. 38 in that Appendix.
Where leave has been given under rule 2(3) to serve short notice of motion, that fact must be stated in the notice.
The notice of a motion must include a concise statement of the nature of the claim made or the relief or remedy required.
Order 6, rule 5, with the necessary modifications, applies in relation to notice of an originating motion as it applies in relation to a writ.
The notice of an originating motion by which proceedings are begun must be issued out of the Registry.
Issue of the notice of an originating motion takes place upon its being sealed by an officer of the Registry.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Service of notice of motion with writ, etc. (O. 8, r. 4)
section.content: Notice of a motion to be made in an action may be served by the plaintiff on the defendant with the writ of summons or originating summons or at any time after service of the writ or summons, whether or not the defendant has acknowledged service in the action.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Adjournment of hearing (O. 8, r. 5)
section.content: The hearing of any motion may be adjourned from time to time on such terms, if any, as the Court thinks fit.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Petitions: General Provisions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application (O. 9, r. 1)
section.content: The provisions of this Order apply to all petitions required or authorized under a written law, subject to any provisions relating to any class of petition made by that written law or any other written law.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Contents of petition (O. 9, r. 2)

subsection.content: A petition must include a concise statement of the nature of the claim made or the relief or remedy required in the proceedings begun by the petition.

subsection.leadIn: A petition must include at the end of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement of the names of the persons, if any, required to be served with the petition; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if no person is required to be served, a statement to that effect.

subsection.content: Order 6, rule 5, with the necessary modifications, applies in relation to a petition as it applies in relation to a writ.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Presentation of petition (O. 9, r. 3)
section.content: A petition may be presented by leaving it at the Registry.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Fixing time for hearing petition (O. 9, r. 4)

subsection.content: A day and time for the hearing of a petition which is required to be heard shall be fixed by the Registrar.
Unless the Court otherwise directs, a petition which is required to be served on any person must be served on him not less than seven days before the day fixed for the hearing of the petition.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Certain applications not to be made by petition (O. 9, r. 5)
section.content: No application in any cause or matter may be made by petition.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Service of Originating Process: General Provisions

section.name: s1
section.heading: General provisions (O. 10, r. 1)

subsection.content: A writ must be served personally on each defendant by the plaintiff or his agent.

subsection.leadIn: A writ for service on a defendant within the jurisdiction may, instead of being served personally on him, be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by sending a copy of the writ by registered post to the defendant at his usual or last known address; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is a letter box for that address, by inserting through the letter box a copy of the writ enclosed in a sealed envelope addressed to the defendant.

subsection.leadIn: Where a writ is served in accordance with paragraph (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of service shall, unless the contrary is shown, be deemed to be the seventh day (ignoring Order 3, rule 2(5)) after the date on which the copy was sent to, or as the case may be, inserted through the letter box for, the address in question;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any affidavit proving due service of the writ must contain a statement to the effect that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the opinion of the deponent (or, if the deponent is the plaintiff’s solicitor or an employee of that solicitor, in the opinion of the plaintiff) the copy of the writ, if sent to, or as the case may be, inserted through the letter box for, the address in question, will have come to the knowledge of the defendant within 7 days thereafter; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of service by post, the copy of the writ has not been returned to the plaintiff through the post undelivered to the addressee.

subsection.content: Where a defendant’s solicitor endorses on the writ a statement that he accepts service of the writ on behalf of that defendant, the writ shall be deemed to have been duly served on that defendant and to have been so served on the date on which the endorsement was made.

Subject to Order 12, rule 7, where a writ is not duly served on a defendant but he acknowledges service of it, the writ shall be deemed, unless the contrary is shown, to have been duly served on him and to have been so served on the date on which he acknowledges service.

Every copy of a writ for service on a defendant shall be sealed with the seal of the Court and shall be accompanied by a form of acknowledgment of service in Form No. 14 in Appendix A in which the title of the action and its number have been entered.

This rule shall have effect subject to the provisions of any Ordinance and these Rules and in particular to any enactment which provides for the manner in which documents may be served on bodies corporate.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Service of writ on agent of overseas principal (O. 10, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court is satisfied on an ex parte application that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contract has been entered into within the jurisdiction with or through an agent who is either an individual residing or carrying on business within the jurisdiction or a body corporate having a registered office or a place of business within the jurisdiction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the principal for whom the agent was acting was at the time the contract was entered into and is at the time of the application neither such an individual nor such a body corporate; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: at the time of the application either the agent’s authority has not been determined or he is still in business relations with his principal,

subsection.continued: the Court may authorize service of a writ beginning an action relating to the contract to be effected on the agent instead of the principal.

subsection.content: An order under this rule authorizing service of a writ on a defendant’s agent must limit a time within which the defendant must acknowledge service.

Where an order is made under this rule authorizing service of a writ on a defendant’s agent, a copy of the order and of the writ must be sent by post to the defendant at his address out of the jurisdiction.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Service of writ in pursuance of contract (O. 10, r. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contract contains a term to the effect that the Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine any action in respect of a contract or, apart from any such term, the Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine any such action; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contract provides that, in the event of any action in respect of the contract being begun, the process by which it is begun may be served on the defendant, or on such other person on his behalf as may be specified in the contract, in such manner, or at such place (whether within or out of the jurisdiction), as may be so specified,

subsection.continued: then, if an action in respect of the contract is begun in the Court and the writ by which it is begun is served in accordance with the contract, the writ shall, subject to paragraph (2), be deemed to have been duly served on the defendant.

subsection.content: A writ which is served out of the jurisdiction in accordance with a contract shall not be deemed to have been duly served on the defendant by virtue of paragraph (1) unless leave to serve the writ out of the jurisdiction has been granted under Order 11, rule 1(1) or service of the writ is permitted without leave under Order 11, rule 1(2).

section.name: s4
section.heading: Service of writ in certain actions for possession of premises or land (O. 10, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where a writ is indorsed with a claim for the recovery, or delivery of possession, of premises or land, the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if satisfied on an ex parte application that no person appears to be in possession of the premises or land and that service cannot be otherwise effected on any defendant, authorize service on that defendant to be effected by affixing a copy of the writ to some conspicuous part of the premises or land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if satisfied on such an application that no person appears to be in possession of the premises or land and that service could not otherwise have been effected on any defendant, order that service already effected by affixing a copy of the writ to some conspicuous part of the premises or land shall be treated as good service on that defendant.

subsection.content: Where a writ is indorsed with a claim for the recovery, or delivery of possession, of premises or land, in addition to, and not in substitution for any other mode of service, a copy of the writ shall be posted in a conspicuous place on or at the entrance to the premises or land recovery or possession of which is claimed.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Service of originating summons, notice of motion, or petition (O. 10, r. 5)

subsection.content: The foregoing rules of this Order shall apply, with any necessary modifications, in relation to an originating summons (other than an ex parte originating summons or an originating summons under Order 113) as they apply in relation to a writ, except that an acknowledgment of service of an originating summons shall be in Form No. 15 or 15A in Appendix A, whichever is appropriate. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Rule 1(1), (2), (3) and (4) applies, with any necessary modifications, in relation to a notice of an originating motion and a petition as they apply in relation to a writ. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s11
section.heading: Service of Process, etc., out of Jurisdiction

section.name: s1
section.heading:
Principal cases in which service of writ out
of jurisdiction is permissible (O. 11, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: Provided that the writ is not a writ to which paragraph (2) applies, service of a writ out of the jurisdiction is permissible with the leave of the Court if in the action begun by the writ—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: relief is sought against a person domiciled or ordinarily resident within the jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
paragraph.leadIn: the claim is brought to enforce, rescind, dissolve, annul or otherwise affect a contract, or to recover damages or obtain other relief in respect of the breach of a contract, being (in either case) a contract which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: was made within the jurisdiction; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was made by or through an agent trading or residing within the jurisdiction on behalf of a principal trading or residing out of the jurisdiction; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is by its terms, or by implication, governed by Hong Kong law; or

subparagraph.name: iv

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the claim is brought in respect of a breach committed within the jurisdiction of a contract made within or out of the jurisdiction, and irrespective of the fact, if such be the case, that the breach was preceded or accompanied by a breach committed out of the jurisdiction that rendered impossible the performance of so much of the contract as ought to have been performed within the jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the claim is founded on a tort and the damage was sustained, or resulted from an act committed, within the jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: g
h
i
paragraph.content: the claim is made for a debt secured on immovable property or is made to assert, declare or determine proprietary or possessory rights, or rights of security, in or over movable property, or to obtain authority to dispose of movable property, situate within the jurisdiction;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the claim is brought to execute the trusts of a written instrument being trusts that ought to be executed according to Hong Kong law and of which the person to be served with the writ is a trustee, or for any relief or remedy which might be obtained in any such action;

paragraph.name: k
n
paragraph.content: the claim is brought under the Carriage by Air Ordinance (Cap. 500);

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: the claim is for an order for the costs of and incidental to a dispute under section 53A(2) of the Ordinance; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: oa
paragraph.content: the claim is for a costs order under section 53(2) of the Ordinance against a person who is not a party to the relevant proceedings; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: the claim is brought for money had and received or for an account or other relief against the defendant as constructive trustee, and the defendant’s alleged liability arises out of acts committed, whether by him or otherwise, within the jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: Service of a writ out of the jurisdiction is permissible without the leave of the Court provided that each claim made by the writ is—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a claim which by virtue of any written law the Court has power to hear and determine notwithstanding that the person against whom the claim is made is not within the jurisdiction of the Court or that the wrongful act, neglect or default giving rise to the claim did not take place within its jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: Where a writ is to be served out of the jurisdiction under paragraph (2), the time to be inserted in the writ within which the defendant served therewith must acknowledge service shall—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be limited in accordance with the practice adopted under rule 4(4).

section.name: s4
section.heading:
Application for, and grant of, leave to serve
writ out of jurisdiction (O. 11, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: An application for the grant of leave under rule 1(1) must be supported by an affidavit stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the grounds on which the application is made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that in the deponent’s belief the plaintiff has a good cause of action;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in what place the defendant is, or probably may be found; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where the application is made under rule 1(1)(c), the grounds for the deponent’s belief that there is between the plaintiff and the person on whom a writ has been served a real issue which the plaintiff may reasonably ask the Court to try.

subsection.content: No such leave shall be granted unless it shall be made sufficiently to appear to the Court that the case is a proper one for service out of the jurisdiction under this Order.
An order granting under rule 1 leave to serve a writ out of the jurisdiction must limit a time within which the defendant to be served must acknowledge service.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Service of writ out of jurisdiction: general (O. 11, r. 5)

subsection.content: Subject to the following provisions of this rule, Order 10, rule 1(1), (4), (5) and (6) and Order 65, rule 4, shall apply in relation to the service of a writ notwithstanding that the writ is to be served out of the jurisdiction, save that the accompanying form of acknowledgment of service shall be modified in such manner as may be appropriate.

Nothing in this rule or in any order or direction of the Court made by virtue of it shall authorize or require the doing of anything in a country or place in which service is to be effected which is contrary to the law of that country or place.

subsection.leadIn: A writ which is to be served out of the jurisdiction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: need not be served personally on the person required to be served so long as it is served on him in accordance with the law of the country or place in which service is effected; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: need not be served by the plaintiff or his agent if it is served by a method provided for by rule 5A, 6 or 7.

subsection.leadIn: An official certificate stating that a writ as regards which rule 5A or 6 has been complied with, has been served on a person personally, or in accordance with the law of the country or place in which service was effected, on a specified date, being a certificate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a consular authority in that country or place; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the government or judicial authorities of that country or place; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by any other authority designated in respect of that country or place under the Hague Convention,

subsection.continued: shall be evidence of the facts so stated.

subsection.content: An official certificate by the Chief Secretary for Administration stating that a writ has been duly served on a specified date in accordance with a request made under rule 7 shall be evidence of that fact.
A document purporting to be such a certificate as is mentioned in paragraph (5) or (6) shall, until the contrary is proved, be deemed to be such a certificate.

subsection.def: In this rule and rule 6 the Hague Convention (《海牙公約》) means the Convention on the service abroad of judicial or extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial matters signed at The Hague on 15 November 1965.

section.name: s5A
section.heading: Service of writ in the Mainland or Macao through judicial authorities (O. 11, r. 5A)

subsection.content: Where in accordance with these Rules, a writ is to be served on a person in the Mainland or Macao, the writ must be served through the judicial authorities of the Mainland or Macao, as the case may be. (L.N. 26 of 2020)

A person who wishes to serve a writ under paragraph (1) must lodge in the Registry a request for such service, together with 2 copies of the writ and 2 additional copies thereof for the person to be served.

subsection.leadIn: The request lodged under paragraph (2) must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the full name and address of the person to be served;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a description of the nature of proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if a particular method of service by the relevant judicial authorities is desired by the person making the request, an indication of that particular method. (L.N. 26 of 2020)

subsection.content: Every copy of a writ lodged under paragraph (2) must be in Chinese or accompanied by a Chinese translation.

Every translation lodged under paragraph (4) must be certified by the person making it to be a correct translation; and the certificate must contain a statement of that person’s full name, of his address and of his qualifications for making the translation.

Documents duly lodged under paragraph (2) shall be sent by the Registrar of the High Court to the relevant judicial authorities with a request that they arrange for the writ to be served or, where a particular method of service is indicated under paragraph (3)(c), to be served by that method. (L.N. 26 of 2020)

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: Mainland (內地) means any part of China other than Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan. (L.N. 26 of 2020)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Service of writ out of jurisdiction through foreign governments, judicial authorities and consuls (O. 11, r. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Where in accordance with these Rules a writ is to be served on a defendant in any country with respect to which there subsists a Civil Procedure Convention (other than the Hague Convention) providing for service in that country of process of the Court, the writ may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the judicial authorities of that country; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through a consular authority in that country (subject to any provision of the Convention as to the nationality of persons who may be so served).

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Where in accordance with these Rules a writ is to be served on a defendant in any country which is a party to the Hague Convention, the writ may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the authority designated under the Convention in respect of that country; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the law of that country permits—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: through the judicial authorities of that country; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: through a consular authority in that country.

subsection.leadIn: Where in accordance with these Rules a writ is to be served on a defendant in any country with respect to which there does not subsist a Civil Procedure Convention providing for service in that country of process of the Court, the writ may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the government of that country, where that government is willing to effect service; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: through a consular authority in that country, except where service through such an authority is contrary to the law of that country.

subsection.content: A person who wishes to serve a writ by a method specified in paragraph (2), (2A) or (3) must lodge in the Registry a request for service of the writ by that method, together with a copy of the writ and an additional copy thereof for each person to be served.

content.leadIn: Every copy of a writ lodged under paragraph (4) must be accompanied by a translation of the writ in the official language of the country in which service is to be effected or, if there is more than one official language of that country, in any one of those languages which is appropriate to the place in that country where service is to be effected:
content.proviso: Provided that this paragraph shall not apply in relation to a copy of a writ which is to be served in a country the official language of which is, or the official languages of which include, English, or is to be served in any country by a consular authority on a subject of the country of that consular authority, unless the service is to be effected under paragraph (2) and the Civil Procedure Convention with respect to that country expressly requires the copy to be accompanied by a translation.

subsection.content: Every translation lodged under paragraph (5) must be certified by the person making it to be a correct translation; and the certificate must contain a statement of that person’s full name, of his address and of his qualifications for making the translation.

Documents duly lodged under paragraph (4) shall be sent by the Registrar of the High Court to the Chief Secretary for Administration with a request that he arranges for the writ to be served by the method indicated in the request lodged under that paragraph or, where alternative methods are so indicated, by such one of those methods as is most convenient.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Service of process on a foreign State (O. 11, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (4) where a person to whom leave has been granted under rule 1 to serve a writ on a foreign State, wishes to have the writ served on that State, he must lodge in the Registry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request for service of the writ to be arranged by the Chief Secretary for Administration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the writ; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: except where the official language of the State is, or the official languages of that State include, English, a translation of the writ in the official language or one of the official languages of the State.

subsection.content: Rule 6(6) shall apply in relation to a translation lodged under paragraph (1) as it applies in relation to a translation lodged under paragraph (5) of that rule.

Documents duly lodged under this rule shall be sent by the Registrar of the High Court to the Chief Secretary for Administration with a request that the Chief Secretary for Administration arranges for the writ to be served on the foreign State or the government in question, as the case may be.

Where the foreign State has agreed to a method of service other than that provided by the preceding paragraphs, the writ may be served either by the method agreed or in accordance with the preceding paragraphs of this rule.

section.name: s7A
section.heading: Service of writ in certain actions under Carriage by Air Ordinance (O. 11, r. 7A)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person to whom leave has been granted under rule 1 to serve a writ on a High Contracting Party or State Party, as may be appropriate, within the meaning of section 2(1) of the Carriage by Air Ordinance (Cap. 500), being a writ beginning an action to enforce a claim in respect of carriage undertaken by that Party, wishes to have the writ served on that Party, he must lodge in the Registry— (22 of 2005 s. 27)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request for service of the writ to be arranged by the Chief Secretary for Administration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the writ; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: except where the official language of the High Contracting Party or State Party, as may be appropriate, is, or the official languages of that Party include, English, a translation of the writ in the official language or one of the official languages of that Party. (22 of 2005 s. 27)

subsection.content: Rule 6(6) shall apply in relation to a translation lodged under paragraph (1) as it applies in relation to a translation lodged under paragraph (5) of that rule.

Documents duly lodged under this rule shall be sent by the Registrar of the High Court to the Chief Secretary for Administration with a request that the Chief Secretary for Administration arranges for the writ to be served on the High Contracting Party or State Party, as may be appropriate. (22 of 2005 s. 27)

section.name: s8
section.heading: Undertaking to pay expenses of service by Chief Secretary for Administration (O. 11, r. 8)
section.content: Every request lodged under rule 6(4), 7 or 7A must contain an undertaking by the person making the request to be responsible personally for all expenses incurred by the Chief Secretary for Administration in respect of the service requested and, on receiving due notification of the amount of those expenses, to pay that amount to the Treasury and to produce a receipt for the payment to the Registrar of the High Court.

section.name: s8A
section.heading: Undertaking to pay expenses of service by Registrar of the High Court (O. 11, r. 8A)
section.content: Every request lodged under rule 5A must contain an undertaking by the person making the request to be responsible personally for all expenses incurred by the Registrar of the High Court in respect of the service requested and, on receiving due notification of the amount of those expenses, to pay that amount to the Treasury and to produce a receipt for the payment to the Registrar of the High Court.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Service of originating summons, etc. (O. 11, r. 9)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (4A), rule 1 shall apply to the service out of the jurisdiction of an originating summons, notice of motion or petition as it applies to service of a writ. (L.N. 153 of 2008; L.N. 4 of 2016)

Subject to paragraph (4A), service out of the jurisdiction of any summons, notice or order issued, given or made in any proceedings is permissible with the leave of the Court, but leave shall not be required for such service in any proceedings in which the writ, originating summons, motion or petition may by these Rules or under any written law be served out of the jurisdiction without leave. (L.N. 153 of 2008; L.N. 4 of 2016)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: Service out of the jurisdiction of any originating summons issued under Order 121, rule 2 is permissible without the leave of the Court. (L.N. 4 of 2016)

Rule 4(1) and (2) shall, so far as applicable, apply in relation to an application for the grant of leave under this rule as they apply in relation to an application for the grant of leave under rule 1.
An order granting under this rule leave to serve an originating summons out of the jurisdiction must limit a time within which the defendant to be served with the summons must acknowledge service.
Rules 5, 5A, 6, 8 and 8A shall apply in relation to any document for the service of which out of the jurisdiction leave has been granted under this rule as they apply in relation to a writ.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Acknowledgment of Service of Writ or Originating Summons

section.name: s1
section.heading: Mode of acknowledging service (O. 12, r. 1)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (2) and to Order 80, rule 2, a defendant to an action begun by writ may (whether or not he is sued as a trustee or personal representative or in any other representative capacity) acknowledge service of the writ and give notice of intention to defend the action by a solicitor or in person.

The defendant to such an action which is a body corporate may acknowledge service of the writ and give notice of intention to defend the action either by a solicitor or by a person duly authorized to act on the defendant’s behalf.
Service of a writ may be acknowledged by properly completing an acknowledgment of service as defined by rule 3 and handing it in at, or sending it by post to, the Registry.

If 2 or more defendants to an action acknowledge service by the same solicitor and at the same time, only one acknowledgment of service need be completed and delivered for those defendants. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
The date on which service is acknowledged is the date on which the acknowledgment of service is received at the Registry.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Acknowledgment of service (O. 12, r. 3)

subsection.content: An acknowledgment of service must be in Form No. 14, 15 or 15A in Appendix A, whichever is appropriate, and except as provided in rule 1(2), must be signed by the solicitor acting for the defendant specified in the acknowledgment or, if the defendant is acting in person, by that defendant. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: An acknowledgment of service must specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a defendant acknowledging service in person, the address of his place of residence and, if his place of residence is not within the jurisdiction or if he has no place of residence, the address of a place within the jurisdiction at or to which documents for him may be delivered or sent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a defendant acknowledging service by a solicitor, a business address to which may be added a numbered box at a document exchange of his solicitor within the jurisdiction,

subsection.continued: and where the defendant acknowledges service in person the address within the jurisdiction specified under subparagraph (a) shall be his address for service, but otherwise his solicitor’s business address shall be his address for service.
In relation to a body corporate the references in subparagraph (a) to the defendant’s place of residence shall be construed as references to the defendant’s registered or principal office.

subsection.content: Where the defendant acknowledges service by a solicitor who is acting as agent for another solicitor having a place of business within the jurisdiction, the acknowledgment of service must state that the first-named solicitor so acts and must also state the name and address of that other solicitor.

If an acknowledgment of service does not specify the defendant’s address for service or the Court is satisfied that any address specified in the acknowledgment for service is not genuine, the Court may on application by the plaintiff set aside the acknowledgment or order the defendant to give an address or, as the case may be, a genuine address for service and may in any case direct that the acknowledgment shall nevertheless have effect for the purpose of Order 10, rule 1(5) and Order 65, rule 9.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Procedure on receipt of acknowledgment of service (O. 12, r. 4)
section.leadIn: On receiving an acknowledgment of service an officer of the Registry must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affix to the acknowledgment an official stamp showing the date on which he received it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enter the acknowledgment in the cause book with a note showing, if it be the case, that the defendant has indicated in the acknowledgment an intention to contest the proceedings or to apply for a stay of execution in respect of any judgment obtained against him in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make a copy of the acknowledgment, having affixed to it an official stamp showing the date on which he received the acknowledgment, and send by post to the plaintiff or, as the case may be, his solicitor at the plaintiff’s address for service.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Time limited for acknowledging service (O. 12, r. 5)
section.leadIn: References in these Rules to the time limited for acknowledging service are references—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a writ served within the jurisdiction, to 14 days after service of the writ (including the day of service) or, where that time has been extended by or by virtue of these Rules, to that time as so extended; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a writ served out of the jurisdiction, to the time limited under Order 10, rule 2(2), Order 11, rule 1(3), or Order 11, rule 4(4), or, where that time has been extended as aforesaid, to that time as so extended.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Late acknowledgment of service (O. 12, r. 6)

subsection.content: Except with the leave of the Court, a defendant may not give notice of intention to defend in an action after judgment has been obtained therein.

Except as provided by paragraph (1), nothing in these Rules or any writ or order thereunder shall be construed as precluding a defendant from acknowledging service in an action after the time limited for so doing, but if a defendant acknowledges service after that time, he shall not, unless the Court otherwise orders, be entitled to serve a defence or do any other act later than if he had acknowledged service within that time.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Acknowledgment not to constitute waiver (O. 12, r. 7)
section.content: The acknowledgment by a defendant of service of a writ shall not be treated as a waiver by him of any irregularity in the writ or service thereof or in any order giving leave to serve the writ or extending the validity of the writ for the purpose of service.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Dispute as to jurisdiction (O. 12, r. 8)

subsection.leadIn: A defendant who wishes to dispute the jurisdiction of the Court in the proceedings by reason of any such irregularity as is mentioned in rule 7 or on any other ground shall give notice of intention to defend the proceedings and shall, within the time limited for service of a defence, apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order setting aside the writ or service of the writ on him; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order declaring that the writ has not been duly served on him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the discharge of any order giving leave to serve the writ on him out of the jurisdiction; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the discharge of any order extending the validity of the writ for the purpose of service; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the protection or release of any property of the defendant seized or threatened with seizure in the proceedings; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the discharge of any order made to prevent any dealing with any property of the defendant; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a declaration that in the circumstances of the case the Court has no jurisdiction over the defendant in respect of the subject-matter of the claim or the relief or remedy sought in the action; or

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.content: an order staying the proceedings; or (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: such other relief as may be appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A defendant who wishes to argue that the Court should not exercise its jurisdiction in the proceedings on one or more of the grounds specified in paragraph (2A) or on any other ground shall also give notice of intention to defend the proceedings and shall, within the time limited for service of a defence, apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a declaration that in the circumstances of the case the Court should not exercise any jurisdiction it may have; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order staying the proceedings; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: such other relief as may be appropriate, including the relief specified in paragraph (1)(e) or (f). (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: The grounds specified for the purposes of paragraph (2) are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: considering the best interests and convenience of the parties to the proceedings and the witnesses in the proceedings, the proceedings should be conducted in another court;

paragraph.name: b
