A sanctioned offer made less than 28 days before the commencement of the trial may be withdrawn or diminished if the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer, the sanctioned offer may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned offer, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned offer or diminished sanctioned offer may be accepted.
If a sanctioned offer is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Notice of sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 8)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may relate to the whole claim or to part of it or to an issue arising from it.

subsection.leadIn: A defendant who makes a sanctioned payment shall file with the Court a notice in Form No. 23 in Appendix A, that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the amount of the payment;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: states whether it takes into account any counterclaim or set off;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if an interim payment has been made, states that the interim payment has been taken into account;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if it is expressed not to be inclusive of interest, gives the details relating to interest set out in rule 26(2); and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: if a sum of money has been paid into court (other than as security for costs), states whether the sanctioned payment has taken into account that sum of money.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Service of sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 9)
section.leadIn: A defendant who makes a sanctioned payment shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: serve the sanctioned payment notice—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on the plaintiff; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where the plaintiff is an aided person, on the Director of Legal Aid; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: file with the Court a certificate of service of the notice.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Withdrawal or diminution of sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 10)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may not be withdrawn or diminished before the expiry of 28 days from the date the sanctioned payment is made unless the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment, the sanctioned payment may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned payment, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned payment or diminished sanctioned payment may be accepted.
If a sanctioned payment is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Offer to settle claim for provisional damages (O. 22, r. 11)

subsection.content: A defendant may make a sanctioned payment in respect of a claim that includes a claim for provisional damages.

Where the defendant makes a sanctioned payment under paragraph (1), the sanctioned payment notice must specify whether or not the defendant is offering to agree to the making of an award of provisional damages.

subsection.leadIn: Where the defendant is offering to agree to the making of an award of provisional damages, the sanctioned payment notice must also state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the sum paid into court is in satisfaction of the claim for damages on the assumption that the injured person will not develop the disease or suffer the type of deterioration specified in the notice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the offer is subject to the condition that the plaintiff shall make any claim for further damages within a limited period; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: what that period is.

subsection.leadIn: Where a sanctioned payment is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made in accordance with paragraph (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accepted within the relevant period specified in rule 15,

subsection.continued: the sanctioned payment has the consequences specified in rule 20, unless the Court orders otherwise.

subsection.content: If the plaintiff accepts the sanctioned payment he must, within 7 days of doing so, apply to the Court for an order for an award of provisional damages under Order 37, rule 8.
The money in court may not be paid out unless the Court has disposed of the application made under paragraph (5).

subsection.def: In this rule, provisional damages (暫定損害賠償) means damages for personal injuries that are to be assessed on the assumption that the injured person will not develop the disease or suffer the deterioration referred to in section 72E of the Ordinance.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Time when sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is made and accepted (O. 22, r. 12)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is made when it is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned payment is made when a sanctioned payment notice is served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned offer is effective when its details are served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned payment is effective when notice of the amendment is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is accepted when notice of its acceptance is served on the offeror.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Service of notice of acceptance of plaintiff’s sanctioned offer (O. 22, r. 13)

subsection.content: Where there is more than one defendant, a defendant who serves on the plaintiff a notice of acceptance of the plaintiff’s sanctioned offer shall at the same time serve a copy of the notice on the other defendant or defendants.

subsection.leadIn: A defendant on whom a copy of the notice has been served may within 14 days after the service apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a direction as to any question of costs between him and the defendant who has accepted the plaintiff’s sanctioned offer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other direction relating to the acceptance of the plaintiff’s sanctioned offer.

subsection.content: No application may be made under paragraph (2) after the expiry of the 14-day period referred to in that paragraph.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Clarification of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment notice (O. 22, r. 14)

subsection.content: The offeree may, within 7 days of a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment being made, request the offeror to clarify the offer or payment notice.

If the offeror does not give the clarification requested under paragraph (1) within 7 days of service of the request, the offeree may, unless the trial has commenced, apply for an order that he does so.
If the Court makes an order pursuant to an application made under paragraph (2), it shall specify the date when the sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is to be treated as having been made.

Where a cause of action under the Fatal Accidents Ordinance (Cap. 22) and a cause of action under Part IV or IVA of the Law Amendment and Reform (Consolidation) Ordinance (Cap. 23) are joined in an action, with or without any other cause of action, the plaintiff is not entitled under paragraph (1) to request the defendant to make an apportionment of the sanctioned payment between the causes of action under those Ordinances.

section.crossHeading: III. Acceptance of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s15
section.heading: Time for acceptance of defendant’s sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 15)

subsection.content: Subject to rules 7(3) and 10(2), a plaintiff may accept a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment made not less than 28 days before the commencement of the trial without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the defendant a written notice of acceptance not later than 28 days after the offer or payment was made.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a defendant’s sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is made less than 28 days before the commencement of the trial; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff does not accept it within the period specified in paragraph (1),

subsection.continued: then the plaintiff may—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for costs, accept the offer or payment without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for costs, only accept the offer or payment with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.
A notice of acceptance of a sanctioned payment must be in Form No. 24 in Appendix A.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Time for acceptance of plaintiff’s sanctioned offer (O. 22, r. 16)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 7(3), a defendant may accept a sanctioned offer made not less than 28 days before the commencement of the trial without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the plaintiff a written notice of acceptance not later than 28 days after the offer was made.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer is made less than 28 days before the commencement of the trial; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the defendant does not accept it within the period specified in paragraph (1),

subsection.continued: then the defendant may—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for costs, accept the offer without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for costs, only accept the offer with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Payment out of a sum in court on acceptance of sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 17)
section.content: Subject to rules 18(4) and 19 and Order 22A, rule 2, where a sanctioned payment is accepted, the plaintiff may obtain payment out of the sum in court by making a request for payment in Form No. 25 in Appendix A.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, defendants (O. 22, r. 18)

subsection.content: This rule applies where the plaintiff wishes to accept a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, of a number of defendants.

subsection.leadIn: If the defendants are sued jointly or in the alternative, the plaintiff may accept the offer or payment without requiring the leave of the Court in accordance with rule 15(1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he discontinues his claim against those defendants who have not made the offer or payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those defendants give written consent to the acceptance of the offer or payment.

subsection.leadIn: If the plaintiff alleges that the defendants have a several liability to him, the plaintiff may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: accept the offer or payment in accordance with rule 15(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: continue with his claims against the other defendants.

subsection.leadIn: In all other cases the plaintiff shall apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order permitting a payment out to him of any sum in court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such order as to costs as the Court considers appropriate.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Other cases where court order is required to enable acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 19)

subsection.leadIn: Where a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is made in proceedings to which Order 80, rule 10 (Compromise, etc., by person under disability) applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offer or payment may be accepted only with the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the money in court may not be paid out except in pursuance of an order of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court grants leave to a plaintiff to accept a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment after the trial has commenced—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the money in court may not be paid out except in pursuance of an order of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court shall, in the order, deal with the whole costs of the proceedings.

subsection.content: Where a plaintiff accepts a sanctioned payment after a defence of tender before action has been put forward by the defendant, the money in court may not be paid out except in pursuance of an order of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Where a plaintiff accepts a sanctioned payment made in satisfaction of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a cause of action under the Fatal Accidents Ordinance (Cap. 22) and a cause of action under Part IV or IVA of the Law Amendment and Reform (Consolidation) Ordinance (Cap. 23); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a cause of action under the Fatal Accidents Ordinance (Cap. 22) where more than one person is entitled to the money,

subsection.continued: the money in court may not be paid out except in pursuance of an order of the Court.

section.crossHeading: IV. Consequences of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s20
section.heading: Costs consequences of acceptance of defendant’s sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 20)

subsection.content: Where a defendant’s sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment to settle the whole claim is accepted without requiring the leave of the Court, the plaintiff is entitled to his costs of the proceedings up to the date of serving notice of acceptance, unless the Court otherwise orders.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment relating to a part of the claim or an issue arising from the claim is accepted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the time of serving notice of acceptance the plaintiff abandons the other parts of the claim or other issues arising from the claim,

subsection.continued: the plaintiff is entitled to his costs of the proceedings up to the date of serving notice of acceptance, unless the Court otherwise orders.

subsection.content: The plaintiff’s costs include any costs attributable to the defendant’s counterclaim or set-off if the sanctioned offer or the sanctioned payment notice states that it takes into account the counterclaim or set-off.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Costs consequences of acceptance of plaintiff’s sanctioned offer (O. 22, r. 21)

subsection.content: Where a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer to settle the whole claim is accepted without requiring the leave of the Court, the plaintiff is entitled to his costs of the proceedings up to the date upon which the defendant serves notice of acceptance, unless the Court otherwise orders.
The plaintiff’s costs include any costs attributable to the defendant’s counterclaim or set-off if the sanctioned offer states that it takes into account the counterclaim or set-off.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Other consequences of acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 22)

subsection.content: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment relates to the whole claim and is accepted, the claim is stayed.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of acceptance of a sanctioned offer which relates to the whole claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the stay is upon the terms of the offer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: either party may apply to enforce those terms without the need to commence new proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment which relates only to a part of the claim or an issue arising from the claim is accepted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claim is stayed as to that part or issue, and in the case of the sanctioned offer, the stay is upon the terms of the offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: either party may apply to enforce those terms without the need to commence new proceedings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: unless the parties have agreed on costs, the liability for costs shall be decided by the Court.

subsection.content: If the approval of the Court is required before a settlement can be binding, any stay which would otherwise arise on the acceptance of a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment takes effect only when that approval has been given.

subsection.leadIn: Any stay arising under this rule does not affect the power of the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce the terms of a sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to deal with any question of costs (including interest on costs) relating to the proceedings; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to order payment out of court of any sum paid into court.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sanctioned offer has been accepted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a party alleges that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the other party has not honoured the terms of the offer; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is therefore entitled to a remedy for breach of contract,

subsection.continued: the party may claim the remedy by applying to the Court without the need to commence new proceedings unless the Court otherwise orders.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Costs consequences where plaintiff fails to do better than sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 23)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies where a plaintiff—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to obtain a judgment better than the sanctioned payment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to obtain a judgment that is more advantageous than a defendant’s sanctioned offer.

subsection.content: The Court may by order disallow all or part of any interest otherwise payable under section 49 of the Ordinance on the whole or part of any sum of money awarded to the plaintiff for some or all of the period after the latest date on which the payment or offer could have been accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.
The Court may order the plaintiff to pay any costs incurred by the defendant after the latest date on which the payment or offer could have been accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may also order that the defendant is entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his costs on the indemnity basis after the latest date on which the plaintiff could have accepted the payment or offer without requiring the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: interest on the costs referred to in paragraph (3) or subparagraph (a) at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the Court shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2), (3) and (4) unless it considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2), (3) and (4), the Court shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of any sanctioned payment or sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which any sanctioned payment or sanctioned offer was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned payment or sanctioned offer was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the payment or offer to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the Court under this rule is in addition to any other power it may have to award or disallow interest.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Costs and other consequences where plaintiff does better than he proposed in his sanctioned offer (O. 22, r. 24)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a defendant is held liable for more than the proposals contained in a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the judgment against a defendant is more advantageous to the plaintiff than the proposals contained in a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer.

subsection.content: The Court may order interest on the whole or part of any sum of money (excluding interest) awarded to the plaintiff at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate for some or all of the period after the latest date on which the defendant could have accepted the offer without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may also order that the plaintiff is entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his costs on the indemnity basis after the latest date on which the defendant could have accepted the offer without requiring the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: interest on those costs at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the Court shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3) unless it considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), the Court shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of any sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which any sanctioned offer was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned offer was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the offer to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the Court under this rule is in addition to any other power it may have to award interest.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Restriction on disclosure of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 22, r. 25)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is treated as “without prejudice save as to costs”.

The fact that a sanctioned payment has been made must not be communicated to the trial judge or the master hearing or determining the action or counterclaim or any question or issue as to the debt or damages until all questions of liability and the amount of money to be awarded have been decided.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (2) does not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the defence of tender before action has been raised;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: where—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the issue of liability has been determined before any assessment of the money claimed; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the fact that there has or has not been a sanctioned payment may be relevant to the question of the costs of the issue of liability.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Interest (O. 22, r. 26)

subsection.leadIn: Unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer which offers to accept a sum of money; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a sanctioned payment notice,

subsection.continued: indicates to the contrary, any such offer or payment is to be treated as inclusive of all interest until the last date on which it could be accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Where a plaintiff’s sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment notice is expressed not to be inclusive of interest, the offer or notice must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether interest is offered; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so, the amount offered, the rate or rates offered and the period or periods for which it is offered.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Money paid into court under order (O. 22, r. 27)

subsection.content: On making any payment into court under an order of the Court or a certificate of a master, the party making the payment shall give notice of the payment in Form No. 25A in Appendix A to every other party to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Unless the Court otherwise orders, a defendant who has paid money into court in pursuance of an order made under Order 14 may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by notice served on the plaintiff, appropriate the whole or any part of the money and any additional payment, if necessary, in satisfaction of any particular claim made by the plaintiff and specified in the notice; or

paragraph.name: b

subsection.leadIn: Any money appropriated in accordance with paragraph (2) is deemed to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of paragraph (2)(a), a sanctioned payment when the notice is served on the plaintiff; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of paragraph (2)(b), money paid into court with a plea of tender when the pleading is served on the plaintiff,

subsection.continued: and this Order applies accordingly.

subsection.content: A notice served on the plaintiff in accordance with paragraph (2)(a) is deemed to be a sanctioned payment notice.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Transitional provision relating to Part 9 of Amendment Rules 2008 (O. 22, r. 28)
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a payment into court has been made in accordance with Order 22 (the repealed Order) repealed by rule 61 (the repealing rule) of the Amendment Rules 2008; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disposal of the payment is pending immediately before the commencement* of the repealing rule,

section.continued: then nothing in Division 1 of Part 9 of the Amendment Rules 2008 applies in relation to that payment, and the repealed Order and all the other provisions amended or repealed by that Division, as in force immediately before the commencement, continue to apply in relation to that payment as if that Division had not been made.

section.name: s22A
section.heading: Miscellaneous Provisions about Payments into Court

section.name: s1
section.heading: Money remaining in court (O. 22A, r. 1)

subsection.content: Subject to Order 22, rule 17, any money paid into court in an action (whether or not in accordance with Order 22) may not be paid out except in pursuance of an order of the Court which may be made at any time before, at or after the trial or hearing of the action.

subsection.leadIn: Where an order under paragraph (1) is made before the trial or hearing and the money in court is a sanctioned payment made in accordance with Order 22, the money may not be paid out except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in satisfaction of the cause or causes of action in respect of which it was paid in; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the extent to which the sanctioned payment may be withdrawn or diminished pursuant to Order 22.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Person to whom payment to be made (O. 22A, r. 2)

subsection.content: Where the party entitled to money in court is a person in respect of whom a certificate is or has been in force entitling him to legal aid under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91), payment shall be made only to the Director of Legal Aid without the need for any authority from the party.
Subject to paragraph (1), payment shall be made to the party entitled or to his solicitor.
This rule applies whether the money in court has been paid into court under Order 22 or under an order of the Court or a certificate of the Registrar.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Payment out: small intestate estates (O. 22A, r. 3)
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person entitled to a fund in court, or a share of such fund, dies intestate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court is satisfied that no grant of administration of his estate has been made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the assets of his estate, including the fund or share, do not exceed $150,000 in value,

section.continued: it may order that the fund or share shall be paid, transferred or delivered to the person who, being a widower, widow, child, father, mother, brother or sister of the deceased, would have the prior right to a grant of administration of the estate of the deceased.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Investment of money in court (O. 22A, r. 4)
section.content: Cash under the control of or subject to the order of the Court may be invested in any manner specified in the District Court Suitors’ Funds Rules (Cap. 336 sub. leg. E) and the Trustee Ordinance (Cap. 29).

section.name: s23
section.heading: Security for Costs

section.name: s1
section.heading: Security for costs of action, etc. (O. 23, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: Where, on the application of a defendant to an action or other proceeding in the Court, it appears to the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the plaintiff is ordinarily resident out of the jurisdiction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the plaintiff (not being a plaintiff who is suing in a representative capacity) is a nominal plaintiff who is suing for the benefit of some other person and that there is reason to believe that he will be unable to pay the costs of the defendant if ordered to do so; or

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: that the plaintiff has changed his address during the course of the proceedings with a view to evading the consequences of the litigation,

subsection.continued: then if, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, the Court thinks it just to do so, it may order the plaintiff to give such security for the defendant’s costs of the action or other proceeding as it thinks just.

subsection.content: The Court shall not require a plaintiff to give security by reason only of paragraph (1)(c) if he satisfies the Court that the failure to state his address or the mis-statement thereof was made innocently and without intention to deceive.

The references in this rule to a plaintiff and a defendant shall be construed as references to the person (howsoever described on the record) who is in the position of plaintiff or defendant, as the case may be, in the proceeding in question, including a proceeding on a counterclaim.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Manner of giving security (O. 23, r. 2)
section.content: Where an order is made requiring any party to give security for costs, the security shall be given in such manner, at such time, and on such terms (if any) as the Court may direct.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Saving for enactments (O. 23, r. 3)
section.content: This Order is without prejudice to the provisions of any written law which empowers the Court to require security to be given for the costs of any proceedings.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Discovery and Inspection of Documents

section.name: s1
section.heading: Mutual discovery of documents (O. 24, r. 1)

subsection.content: After the close of pleadings in an action begun by writ there shall, subject to and in accordance with the provisions of this Order, be discovery by the parties to the action of the documents which are or have been in their possession, custody or power relating to matters in question in the action.
Nothing in this Order shall be taken as preventing the parties to an action agreeing to dispense with or limit the discovery of documents which they would otherwise be required to make to each other.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Discovery by parties without order (O. 24, r. 2)

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this rule and of rule 4, the parties to an action between whom pleadings are closed shall make discovery by exchanging lists of documents. Accordingly, each party shall, within 14 days after the pleadings in the action are deemed to be closed as between him and any other party, make and serve on that other party a list of the documents which are or have been in his possession, custody or power relating to any matter in question between them in the action.

Without prejudice to any directions given by the Court under Order 16, rule 4, paragraph (1) does not apply in third party proceedings, including proceedings under that Order involving fourth or subsequent parties.

Unless the Court otherwise orders, a defendant to an action arising out of an accident on land due to a collision or apprehended collision involving a vehicle shall not make discovery of any documents to the plaintiff under paragraph (1).
Paragraph (1) shall not be taken as requiring a defendant to an action for the recovery of any penalty recoverable by virtue of any written law to make discovery of any documents.

Paragraphs (3) and (4) apply in relation to a counterclaim as they apply in relation to an action but with the substitution, for the reference in paragraph (3) to the plaintiff, of a reference to the party making the counterclaim.

subsection.leadIn: On the application of any party required by this rule to make discovery of documents, the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that the parties to the action or any of them shall make discovery under paragraph (1) of such documents or classes of documents only, or as to such only of the matters in question, as may be specified in the order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if satisfied that discovery by all or any of the parties is not necessary, or not necessary at that stage of the action, order that there shall be no discovery of documents by any or all of the parties either at all or at that stage.

subsection.content: The Court shall make an order under paragraph (6), if and so far as it is of opinion that discovery is not necessary either for disposing fairly of the action or for saving costs.

An application for an order under paragraph (6) must be by summons, and the summons must be taken out before the expiration of the period within which by virtue of this rule discovery of documents in the action is required to be made.

Any party to whom discovery of documents is required to be made under this rule may, at any time before the case management summons in the action is taken out, serve on the party required to make such discovery a notice requiring him to make an affidavit verifying the list he is required to make under paragraph (1).

The party on whom the notice is served shall, within 14 days after service of the notice, make and file an affidavit in compliance with the notice and serve a copy of the affidavit on the party by whom the notice was served.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Order for discovery (O. 24, r. 3)

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this rule and of rules 4 and 8, the Court may order any party to a cause or matter (whether begun by writ or originating summons or otherwise) to make and serve on any other party a list of the documents which are or have been in his possession, custody or power relating to any matter in question in the cause or matter, and may at the same time or subsequently also order him to make and file an affidavit verifying such a list and to serve a copy thereof on the other party. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: Where a party who is required by rule 2 to make discovery of documents fails to comply with any provision of that rule, the Court, on the application of any party to whom the discovery was required to be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make an order against the first-mentioned party under paragraph (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as the case may be, may order him to make and file an affidavit verifying the list of documents he is required to make under rule 2 and to serve a copy thereof on the applicant. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.content: An order under this rule may be limited to such documents or classes of document only, or to such only of the matters in question in the cause or matter, as may be specified in the order.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Order for determination of issue, etc., before discovery (O. 24, r. 4)

subsection.content: Where on an application for an order under rule 2 or 3 it appears to the Court that any issue or question in the cause or matter should be determined before any discovery of documents is made by the parties, the Court may order that that issue or question be determined first.

subsection.leadIn: Where in an action begun by writ an order is made under this rule for the determination of an issue or question, Order 25, rules 5 to 10— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the omission of so much of rule 10(1) as requires parties to serve a notice specifying the orders and directions which they require; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with any other necessary modifications,

subsection.continued: apply as if the application on which the order was made were a case management summons.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Form of list and affidavit (O. 24, r. 5)

subsection.content: A list of documents made in compliance with rule 2 or with an order under rule 3 must be in Form No. 26 in Appendix A, and must enumerate the documents in a convenient order and as shortly as possible but describing each of them or, in the case of bundles of documents of the same nature, each bundle, sufficiently to enable it to be identified.
If it is desired to claim that any documents are privileged from production, the claim must be made in the list of documents with a sufficient statement of the grounds of the privilege.
An affidavit made as aforesaid verifying a list of documents must be in Form No. 27 in Appendix A.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Defendant entitled to copy of co-defendant’s list (O. 24, r. 6)

subsection.content: A defendant who has pleaded in an action shall be entitled to have a copy of any list of documents served on the plaintiff by any other defendant to the action; and a plaintiff against whom a counterclaim is made in an action begun by writ shall be entitled to have a copy of any list of documents served under any of those rules on the party making the counterclaim by any other defendant to the counterclaim.
A party required by virtue of paragraph (1) to supply a copy of a list of documents must supply it free of charge on a request made by the party entitled to it.

Where in proceedings begun by originating summons the Court makes an order under rule 3 requiring a defendant to the action to serve a list of documents on the plaintiff, it may also order him to supply any other defendant to the action with a copy of that list.
In this rule list of documents (文件清單) includes an affidavit verifying a list of documents.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Order for discovery of particular documents (O. 24, r. 7)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 8, the Court may at any time, on the application of any party to a cause or matter, make an order requiring any other party to make an affidavit stating whether any document specified or described in the application or any class of document so specified or described is, or has at any time been, in his possession, custody or power, and, if not then in his possession, custody or power, when he parted with it and what has become of it.
An order may be made against a party under this rule notwithstanding that he may already have made or been required to make a list of documents or affidavit under rule 3.

An application for an order under this rule must be supported by an affidavit stating the belief of the deponent that the party from whom discovery is sought under this rule has, or at some time had in his possession, custody or power the document, or class of document, specified or described in the application and that it relates to one or more of the matters in question in the cause or matter.

section.name: s7A
section.heading:
Application under section 47A or 47B(1) of
the Ordinance (O. 24 r. 7A)

subsection.content: An application for an order under section 47A of the Ordinance for the disclosure of documents before the commencement of proceedings shall be made by originating summons (in Form No. 10 in Appendix A) and the person against whom the order is sought shall be made defendant to the summons.

An application after the commencement of proceedings for an order under section 47B(1) of the Ordinance for the disclosure of documents by a person who is not a party to the proceedings shall be made by summons, which must be served on that person personally and on every party to the proceedings other than the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: A summons under paragraph (1) or (2) shall be supported by an affidavit which must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a summons under paragraph (1), state the grounds on which it is alleged that the applicant and the person against whom the order is sought are likely to be parties to subsequent proceedings in the Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any case, specify or describe the documents in respect of which the order is sought and show, if practicable by reference to any pleading served or intended to be served in the proceedings, that the documents are relevant to an issue arising or likely to arise in the proceedings and that the person against whom the order is sought is likely to have or have had them in his possession, custody or power. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: In the case of a summons under paragraph (1), paragraph (3)(b) shall be construed as if for the word “relevant”, there were substituted the words “directly relevant (within the meaning of section 47A of the Ordinance)”. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
A copy of the supporting affidavit shall be served with the summons on every person on whom the summons is required to be served.

An order under section 47A or 47B(1) of the Ordinance for the disclosure of documents may be made conditional on the applicant’s giving security for the costs of the person against whom it is made or on such other terms, if any, as the Court thinks just, and shall require the person against whom the order is made to make an affidavit stating whether any documents specified or described in the order are, or at any time have been, in his possession, custody or power and, if not then in his possession, custody or power, when he parted with them and what has become of them.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall be compelled by virtue of such an order to produce any documents which he could not be compelled to produce—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a summons under paragraph (1), if the subsequent proceedings had already been begun; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a summons under paragraph (2), if he had been served with a writ of subpoena duces tecum to produce the documents at the trial.

subsection.content: For the purposes of rules 10 and 11 an application for an order under section 47A or 47B(1) of the Ordinance shall be treated as a cause or matter between the applicant and the person against whom the order is sought.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Discovery to be ordered only if necessary (O. 24, r. 8)

subsection.content: On the hearing of an application for an order under rule 3 or 7, the Court, if satisfied that discovery is not necessary, or not necessary at that stage of the cause or matter, may dismiss or, as the case may be, adjourn the application and shall in any case refuse to make such an order if and so far as it is of opinion that discovery is not necessary either for disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for saving costs. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

No order for the disclosure of documents shall be made under section 47A or 47B of the Ordinance, unless the Court is of opinion that the order is necessary either for disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for saving costs. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s9
section.heading: Inspection of documents referred to in list (O. 24, r. 9)
section.content: A party who has served a list of documents on any other party, whether in compliance with rule 2 or with an order under rule 3, must allow the other party to inspect the documents referred to in the list (other than any which he objects to produce) and to take copies thereof and, accordingly, he must, when he serves the list on the other party, also serve on him a notice stating a time within 7 days after the service thereof at which the said documents may be inspected at a place specified in the notice.

section.name: s10
section.heading:
Inspection of documents referred to in pleadings
and affidavits (O. 24, r. 10)

subsection.content: Any party to a cause or matter shall be entitled at any time to serve a notice on any other party in whose pleadings, affidavits, or witness statements served under Order 38, rule 2A, or experts’ reports, reference is made to any document requiring him to produce that document for the inspection of the party giving the notice and to permit him to take copies thereof.

The party on whom a notice is served under paragraph (1) must, within 4 days after service of the notice, serve on the party giving the notice a notice stating a time within 7 days after the service thereof at which the documents, or such of them as he does not object to produce, may be inspected at a place specified in the notice, and stating which (if any) of the documents he objects to produce and on what grounds.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Order for production for inspection (O. 24, r. 11)

subsection.leadIn: If a party who is required by rule 9 to serve such a notice as is therein mentioned or who is served with a notice under rule 10(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to serve a notice under rule 9 or, as the case may be, rule 10(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: objects to produce any document for inspection; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: offers inspection at a time or place such that, in the opinion of the Court, it is unreasonable to offer inspection then or, as the case may be, there,

subsection.continued: then, subject to rule 13(1), the Court may, on the application of the party entitled to inspection, make an order for production of the documents in question for inspection at such time and place, and in such manner, as it thinks fit.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to paragraph (1), but subject to rule 13(1), the Court may, on the application of any party to a cause or matter, order any other party to permit the party applying to inspect any documents in the possession, custody or power of that other party relating to any matter in question in the cause or matter.

An application for an order under paragraph (2) must be supported by an affidavit specifying or describing the documents of which inspection is sought and stating the belief of the deponent that they are in the possession, custody or power of the other party and that they relate to a matter in question in the cause or matter.

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Provision of copies of documents (O. 24, r. 11A)

subsection.content: Any party who is entitled to inspect any documents under any provision of this Order or any order made thereunder may, at or before the time when inspection takes place, serve on the party who is required to produce such documents for inspection a notice (which shall contain an undertaking to pay the reasonable charges) requiring him to supply a true copy of any such document as is capable of being copied by photographic or similar process.
The party on whom such a notice is served must, within 7 days after receipt thereof, supply the copy requested together with an account of the reasonable charges.

Where a party fails to supply to another party a copy of any document under paragraph (2), the Court may, on the application of either party, make such order as to the supply of that document as it thinks fit.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Order for production to Court (O. 24, r. 12)
section.content: At any stage of the proceedings in any cause or matter the Court may, subject to rule 13(1), order any party to produce to the Court any document in his possession, custody or power relating to any matter in question in the cause or matter and the Court may deal with the document when produced in such manner as it thinks fit.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Production to be ordered only if necessary, etc. (O. 24, r. 13)

subsection.content: No order for the production of any documents for inspection or to the Court or for the supply of a copy of any document shall be made under any of the foregoing rules unless the Court is of opinion that the order is necessary either for disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for saving costs.

Where, on an application under this Order for production of any document for inspection or to the Court or for the supply of a copy of any document, privilege from such production or supply is claimed or objection is made to such production or supply on any other ground, the Court may inspect the document for the purpose of deciding whether the claim or objection is valid.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Production of business books (O. 24, r. 14)

subsection.content: Where production of any business books for inspection is applied for under any of the foregoing rules, the Court may, instead of ordering production of the original books for inspection, order a copy or any entries therein to be supplied and verified by an affidavit of some person who has examined the copy with the original books.
Any such affidavit shall state whether or not there are in the original book any and what erasures, interlineations or alterations.
Notwithstanding that a copy of any entries in any book has been supplied under this rule, the Court may order production of the book from which the copy was made.

section.name: s14A
section.heading: Use of documents (O. 24, r. 14A)
section.content: Any undertaking, whether express or implied, not to use a document for any purposes other than those of the proceedings in which it is disclosed shall cease to apply to such document after it has been read to or by the Court, or referred to, in open court, unless the Court for special reasons has otherwise ordered on the application of a party or of the person to whom the document belongs.

section.name: s15
section.heading:
Document disclosure of which would be injurious
to public interest: saving (O. 24, r. 15)
section.content: The foregoing provisions of this Order shall be without prejudice to any rule of law which authorizes or requires the withholding of any document on the ground that the disclosure of it would be injurious to the public interest.

section.name: s15A
section.heading: Order for limiting discovery (O. 24 r. 15A)
section.leadIn: For the purpose of managing the case in question and furthering any of the objectives specified in Order 1A, the Court may make any one or more of the following orders—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: an order directing that the discovery of documents required to be made under this Order to any party to the case shall, notwithstanding anything in this Order, be made in the manner specified in the order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order directing that documents which may be inspected under this Order shall, notwithstanding anything in rule 9 or 10, be inspected at a time or times specified in the order.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Failure to comply with requirement for discovery, etc. (O. 24, r. 16)

subsection.content: If any party who is required by any of the foregoing rules, or by any order made thereunder, to make discovery of documents or to produce any documents for the purpose of inspection or any other purpose or to supply copies thereof fails to comply with any provision of that rule or with that order, as the case may be, then, without prejudice, in the case of a failure to comply with any such provision, to rules 3(2) and 11(1), the Court may make such order as it thinks just including, in particular, an order that the action be dismissed or, as the case may be, an order that the defence be struck out and judgment be entered accordingly. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
If any party against whom an order for discovery or production of documents is made fails to comply with it, then, without prejudice to paragraph (1), he shall be liable to committal.

Service on a party’s solicitor of an order for discovery or production of documents made against that party shall be sufficient service to found an application for committal of the party disobeying the order, but the party may show in answer to the application that he had no notice or knowledge of the order.
A solicitor on whom such an order made against his client is served and who fails without reasonable excuse to give notice thereof to his client shall be liable to committal.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Transitional provision relating to rules 1 and 2 (O. 24, r. 17)

subsection.content: Where before the commencement* of rule 2, the pleadings in an action are deemed to have been closed, rule 2(1) has effect as if for the words “within 14 days after the pleadings in the action are deemed to be closed as between him and any other party”, there were substituted the words “within 14 days of the commencement of this rule”.

subsection.leadIn: Rules 1 and 2 and paragraph (1) has effect subject to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any direction relating to discovery of documents given by the Court before the commencement of those rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any memorandum filed under Order 23A, rule 4 (the repealed rule) repealed by rule 78 of the Amendment Rules 2008 which sets out the directions and orders agreed between the parties and taking effect under the repealed rule.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Case Management Summons and Conference

section.name: s1
section.heading: Case management summons and conference (O. 25, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of facilitating the giving of directions for the management of a case, each party shall, within 28 days after the pleadings in an action to which this rule applies are deemed to be closed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complete a questionnaire prescribed in a practice direction issued for that purpose by providing the information requested in the manner specified in the questionnaire; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serve it on all other parties or file it with the Court in the manner specified in the practice direction.

subsection.leadIn: Where, upon completion of the questionnaire, the parties are able to reach an agreement on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the directions relating to the management of the case that they wish the Court to make; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a timetable for the steps to be taken between the date of the giving of those directions and the date of the trial,

subsection.continued: they shall procure an order to that effect by way of a consent summons.

subsection.leadIn: Where there is no agreement on any of the matters specified in paragraph (2)(a) and (b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each party shall in the questionnaire make a proposal on the matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff shall, within the period specified in the practice direction, take out a summons (in these Rules referred to as a case management summons) returnable in not less than 14 days, so that the Court may give directions relating to the management of the case.

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies to all actions begun by writ except—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
d
paragraph.content: actions in which directions have been given under Order 29, rule 7;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: actions in which an order for the taking of an account has been made under Order 43, rule 1;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: actions in which an application for transfer to a specialist list is pending; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: actions for personal injuries for which automatic directions are provided by rule 11.

subsection.leadIn: If the plaintiff does not file the questionnaire in accordance with paragraph (1)(b) or take out a case management summons in accordance with paragraph (3)(b), the defendant or any defendant may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take out a case management summons; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply for an order to dismiss the action.

subsection.content: On an application by a defendant to dismiss the action under paragraph (5), the Court may either dismiss the action on such terms as may be just or deal with the application as if it were a case management summons.

In the case of an action which is proceeding only as respects a counterclaim, references in this rule and rule 2(1)(c) to the plaintiff and defendant are to be construed respectively as references to the party making the counterclaim and the defendant to the counterclaim.

Notwithstanding anything in paragraph (3), any party to an action to which this rule applies may take out a case management summons at any time after the defendant has given notice of intention to defend, or, if there are two or more defendants, at least one of them has given such notice.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Case management timetable (O. 25, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (4), as soon as practicable after the completed questionnaire has been filed with the Court, the Court shall, having regard to the questionnaire and the needs of the case—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: fix a case management conference if the Court is of the opinion that it is desirable to do so; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: direct the plaintiff to take out a case management summons if he has not already done so under rule 1(3)(b).

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has fixed a case management conference, it shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give directions relating to the management of the case and fix the timetable for the steps to be taken between the date of the giving of those directions and the date of the case management conference; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at the case management conference, fix a timetable for the steps to be taken between the date of the conference and the date of the trial, and the timetable must include—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a date for a pre-trial review; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the trial date or the period in which the trial is to take place.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has not fixed a case management conference, any timetable fixed under paragraph (1)(a) must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a date for a pre-trial review; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the trial date or the period in which the trial is to take place.

subsection.content: The Court may, without a hearing of the case management summons and having regard to the completed questionnaire, by an order nisi, give directions relating to the management of the case and fix the timetable for the steps to be taken between the date of the giving of those directions and the date of the trial.
The order nisi becomes absolute 14 days after the order is made unless a party has applied to the Court for varying the order.
The Court shall, on an application made under paragraph (5), hear the case management summons.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Variation of case management timetable (O. 25, r. 3)

subsection.content: The Court may, either of its own motion or on the application of a party, give further directions relating to the management of the case or vary any timetable fixed by it under rule 2.
A party may apply to the Court if he wishes to vary a milestone date.
The Court shall not grant an application under paragraph (2) unless there are exceptional circumstances justifying the variation.
A non-milestone date may be varied by procuring an order to that effect by way of a consent summons.
A party may apply to the Court if he wishes to vary a non-milestone date without the agreement of the other parties.
The Court shall not grant an application under paragraph (5) unless sufficient grounds have been shown to it.

Whether or not sufficient grounds have been shown to it, the Court shall not grant an application under paragraph (5) if the variation would make it necessary to change a trial date or the period in which the trial is to take place.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—

def.name: MilestoneDate
def.leadIn: milestone date (進度指標日期) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a date which the Court has fixed for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a case management conference;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a pre-trial review; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the trial; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a period fixed by the Court in which a trial is to take place;

subsection.def: non-milestone date (非進度指標日期) means a date or period fixed by the Court, other than a date or period specified in the definition of milestone date.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Failure to appear at case management conference or pre-trial review (O. 25, r. 4)

subsection.content: Where the plaintiff does not appear at the case management conference or pre-trial review, the Court shall provisionally strike out the plaintiff’s claim.

Where the defendant has made a counterclaim in the action and he does not appear at the case management conference or pre-trial review, the Court shall provisionally strike out the defendant’s counterclaim.

Where the Court has provisionally struck out a claim or counterclaim under paragraph (1) or (2), the plaintiff or the defendant may, before the expiry of 3 months from the date of the case management conference or pre-trial review, as the case may be, apply to the Court for restoration of the claim or counterclaim.
The Court may restore the claim or counterclaim subject to such conditions as it thinks fit or refuse to restore it.
The Court shall not restore the claim or counterclaim unless good reasons have been shown to the satisfaction of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: If the plaintiff or the defendant does not apply under paragraph (3) or his application under that paragraph is refused, then—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the plaintiff’s claim or the defendant’s counterclaim stands dismissed upon the expiry of 3 months from the date of the case management conference or pre-trial review, as the case may be; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of the plaintiff’s claim, the defendant is entitled to his costs of the claim; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of the defendant’s counterclaim, the plaintiff is entitled to his costs of the counterclaim.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Duty to consider all matters (O. 25, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: When the case management summons first comes to be determined, the Court shall consider whether—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: it is expedient to adjourn the consideration of all or any of those matters until a later stage.

subsection.leadIn: If when the case management summons first comes to be determined, the Court considers that it is possible to deal then with all the matters referred to in paragraph (1), it shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: deal with them forthwith; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: endeavour to secure that all other matters which must or can be dealt with on interlocutory applications and have not already been dealt with are also then dealt with.

subsection.leadIn: If, when the case management summons first comes to be determined, the Court considers that it is expedient to adjourn the consideration of all or any of the matters which, by the rules of this Order, are required to be considered at the case management summons, the Court shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: deal forthwith with such of those matters as it considers can conveniently be dealt with forthwith and adjourn the consideration of the remaining matters; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: endeavour to secure that all other matters which must or can be dealt with on interlocutory applications and have not already been dealt with are dealt with either then or at such time as the Court may specify.

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (5), and except where the parties agree to the making of an order under Order 33 as to the place or mode of trial before all the matters which, by the rules of this Order, are required to be considered at the case management summons have been dealt with, no such order shall be made until all those matters have been dealt with.

If, at the determination of the case management summons, an action is ordered to be transferred to the Court of First Instance or some other court, paragraph (4) does not apply and nothing in this Order shall be construed as requiring the Court to make any further order at the case management summons.
If the determination of the case management summons is adjourned without a day being fixed for its resumption, any party may restore the summons to the list on 2 days’ notice to the other parties.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Particular matters for consideration (O. 25, r. 6)
section.leadIn: At the determination of the case management summons, the Court shall in particular consider, if necessary of its own motion, whether any order should be made or direction given in the exercise of the powers conferred by any of the following provisions, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any provision of Part IV and Part V of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) (hearsay evidence of fact or opinion in civil proceedings) or of Part III and Part IV of Order 38;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Order 20, rule 5 and Order 38, rules 2 to 7;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: sections 41 and 42 of the Ordinance.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Admissions and agreements to be made (O. 25, r. 7)
section.leadIn: At the determination of the case management summons, the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall endeavour to secure that the parties make all admissions and all agreements as to the conduct of the proceedings which ought reasonably to be made by them; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may cause the order on the summons to record—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any admissions or agreements so made; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (with a view to such special order, if any, as to costs as may be just being made at the trial) any refusal to make any admission or agreement.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Limitation of right of appeal (O. 25, r. 8)
section.content: Nothing in rule 7 shall be construed as requiring the Court to endeavour to secure that the parties shall agree to exclude or limit any right of appeal, but the order made on the case management summons may record any such agreement.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Duty to give all information at determination of case management summons (O. 25, r. 9)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (5), no affidavit shall be used at the determination of the case management summons except by the leave or directions of the Court.

Subject to paragraph (7), it is the duty of the parties to the action and their advisers to give all such information and produce all such documents as the Court may reasonably require for the purposes of enabling it properly to deal with the summons.
The Court may, if it appears proper so to do in the circumstances, authorize any such information or documents to be given or produced to the Court without being disclosed to the other parties.
In the absence of such authority, any information or document given or produced under paragraph (2) shall be given or produced to all the parties as well as to the Court.

No leave is required by virtue of paragraph (1) for the use of an affidavit by any party at the determination of the case management summons in connection with any application thereat for any order if, under any of these Rules, an application for such an order is required to be supported by an affidavit.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court at the determination of the case management summons requires a party to the action or his solicitor or counsel to give any information or produce any document and that information or document is not given or produced, then, subject to paragraph (7), the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: if it appears to the Court to be just so to do—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: order the whole or any part of the pleadings of the party concerned to be struck out; or

subparagraph.name: ii

subsection.content: Notwithstanding anything in this rule, no information or documents which are privileged from disclosure are required to be given or produced under this rule by or by the advisers of any party otherwise than with the consent of that party.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Duty to make all interlocutory applications at case management summons (O. 25, r. 10)

subsection.leadIn: Any party to whom the case management summons is addressed must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: so far as practicable apply at the time fixed for determination of the summons for any order or directions which he may desire as to any matter capable of being dealt with on an interlocutory application in the action; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not less than 7 days before the time fixed for determination of the summons, serve on the other parties a notice specifying those orders and directions in so far as they differ from the orders and directions asked for by the summons.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the determination of the case management summons is adjourned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any party to the proceedings desires to apply for any order or directions not asked for by the summons or in any notice given under paragraph (1),

subsection.continued: he must, not less than 7 days before the resumption of the determination of the summons, serve on the other parties a notice specifying those orders and directions in so far as they differ from the orders and directions asked for by the summons or in any notice given under paragraph (1).

subsection.content: Any application subsequent to the case management summons and before judgment as to any matter capable of being dealt with on an interlocutory application in the action must be made under the summons by 2 clear days’ notice to the other party stating the grounds of the application.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Automatic directions in personal injury actions (O. 25, r. 11)

subsection.leadIn: When the pleadings in any action to which this rule applies are deemed to be closed, the following directions take effect automatically—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there shall be discovery of documents within 14 days in accordance with Order 24, rule 2, and inspection within 7 days thereafter, save that where liability is admitted, or where the action arises out of a road accident, discovery shall be limited to disclosure by the plaintiff of any documents relating to special damages;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the record of any proceedings in any court or tribunal shall be receivable in evidence upon production of a copy thereof certified as a true copy by the clerk or other appropriate officer of the court or tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prevents any party to an action to which this rule applies from applying to the Court for such further or different directions or orders as may, in the circumstances, be appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevents the making of an order for the transfer of the proceedings to the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of this rule—
subsection.def: a road accident (道路意外) means an accident on land due to a collision or apprehended collision involving a vehicle;

def.name: DocumentsRelatingToSpecialDamages
def.leadIn: documents relating to special damages (關於專項損害賠償的文件) include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: documents relating to any industrial injury, industrial disablement or sickness benefit rights; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the claim is made under the Fatal Accidents Ordinance (Cap. 22), documents relating to any claim for dependency on the deceased.

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies to any action for personal injuries except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any Admiralty action; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any action where the pleadings contain an allegation of a negligent act or omission in the course of medical treatment.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Application to action in specialist list (O. 25, r. 12)
section.content: Notwithstanding anything in this Order, a specialist judge may, by a practice direction, determine the extent to which this Order is to apply to an action in a specialist list.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Transitional (O. 25, r. 13)

subsection.leadIn: Where immediately before the commencement* of this Order, a summons for directions taken out under rule 7 of the repealed Order 23A is pending, then the summons for directions is deemed to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it was taken out by the plaintiff, a case management summons taken out under rule 1(3)(b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it was taken out by the defendant, a case management summons taken out under rule 1(5).

subsection.leadIn: Where before the commencement of this Order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court has given a direction requiring the plaintiff to apply for a pre-trial review under the repealed Order 34 or a memorandum setting out such a direction has been filed under rule 4 of the repealed Order 23A; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff has not made the application in accordance with the direction,

subsection.continued: then the direction is deemed to be a direction requiring the plaintiff to take out a case management summons under rule 1(3)(b).

subsection.content: Where immediately before the commencement of this Order, an application for a pre-trial review made under the repealed Order 34 is pending, then the application is deemed to be a case management summons taken out under this Order, irrespective of whether a notice in response has been filed under the repealed Order 34.

Where before the commencement of this Order, the pleadings in an action to which this rule applies are deemed to have been closed and paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) are not applicable, then rule 1(1) has effect as if for the words “the pleadings in an action to which this rule applies are deemed to be closed”, there were substituted the words “the commencement of this Order”.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: repealed Order 23A (已廢除的第23號命令) means Order 23A repealed by rule 78 of the Amendment Rules 2008;
repealed Order 34 (已廢除的第34號命令) means Order 34 repealed by rule 151 of the Amendment Rules 2008.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Interrogatories

section.name: s1
section.heading: Discovery by interrogatories (O. 26, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: A party to any cause or matter may apply to the Court for an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving him leave to serve on any other party interrogatories relating to any matter in question between the applicant and that other party in the cause or matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requiring that other party to answer the interrogatories on affidavit within such period as may be specified in the order.

subsection.content: An application under this rule shall be made by summons or by notice under Order 25, rule 10 and a copy of the proposed interrogatories shall be served with the summons or notice. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: On the hearing of an application under this rule, the Court shall give leave as to such only of the interrogatories as it considers necessary either for disposing fairly of the cause or matter or for savings costs; and in deciding whether to give leave the Court shall take into account any offer made by the party to be interrogated to give particulars, make admissions or produce documents relating to any matter in question. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

A proposed interrogatory which does not relate to such a matter as is mentioned in paragraph (1) shall be disallowed notwithstanding that it might be admissible in oral cross-examination of a witness.

section.name: s2
section.heading:
Interrogatories where party is a body
of persons (O. 26, r. 2)
section.content: Where a party to a cause or matter is a body of persons, whether corporate or unincorporate, being a body which is empowered by law to sue or be sued whether in its own name or in the name of an officer or other person, the Court may, on the application of any other party, make an order allowing him to serve interrogatories on such officer or member of the body as may be specified in the order.

section.name: s3A
section.heading:
Statement as to party, etc., required
to answer (O. 26, r. 3A)
section.content: Where interrogatories are to be served on 2 or more parties or are required to be answered by an agent or servant of a party, a note at the end of the interrogatories shall state which of the interrogatories each party or, as the case may be, an agent or servant is required to answer, and which agent or servant.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Objections and insufficient answers (O. 26, r. 5)

subsection.content: Where a person objects to answering any interrogatory on the ground of privilege he may take the objection in his answer.

Where any person on whom ordered interrogatories have been served answers any of them insufficiently, the Court may make an order requiring him to make a further answer, either by affidavit or on oral examination as the Court may direct.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Failure to comply with order (O. 26, r. 6)

subsection.content: If a party against whom an order is made under rule 1 or 5(2) fails to comply with it, the Court may make such order as it thinks just including, in particular, an order that the action be dismissed or, as the case may be, an order that the defence be struck out and judgment be entered accordingly.
If a party against whom an order is made under rule 1 or 5(2) fails to comply with it, then, without prejudice to paragraph (1), he shall be liable to committal.

Service on a party’s solicitor of an order to answer interrogatories made against the party shall be sufficient service to found an application for committal of the party disobeying the order, but the party may show in answer to the application that he had no notice or knowledge of the order.
