subsection.content: Where a person (in this Order referred to as the judgment creditor) has obtained a judgment or order for the payment by some other person (in this Order referred to as the judgment debtor) of a sum of money amounting in value to at least $1,000, not being a judgment or order for the payment of money into court, and any other person within the jurisdiction (in this Order referred to as the garnishee) is indebted to the judgment debtor, the Court may, subject to the provisions of this Order and of any written law, order the garnishee to pay the judgment creditor the amount of any debt due or accruing due to the judgment debtor from the garnishee, or so much thereof as is sufficient to satisfy that judgment or order and the costs of the garnishee proceedings. (See Appendix A, Forms 72-74)

An order under this rule shall in the first instance be an order to show cause, specifying the time and place for further consideration of the matter, and in the meantime attaching such debt as is mentioned in paragraph (1), or so much thereof as may be specified in the order, to answer the judgment or order mentioned in that paragraph and the costs of the garnishee proceedings.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application for order (O. 49, r. 2)
section.leadIn: An application for an order under rule 1 must be made ex parte supported by an affidavit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: stating the name and the last known address of the judgment debtor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identifying the judgment or order to be enforced and stating the amount remaining unpaid under it at the time of the application;

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.leadIn: if the amount remaining unpaid under the judgment or order is arrears of maintenance, stating—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the interest payable in respect of the arrears of maintenance that the judgment creditor is entitled to under section 20A(2) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9B(2) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53A(2) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AA(2) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the surcharge payable in respect of the arrears of maintenance under section 20B(1) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9C(1) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53B(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AB(1) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be; (18 of 2003 s. 23)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: stating that to the best of the information or belief of the deponent the garnishee (naming him) is within the jurisdiction and is indebted to the judgment debtor and stating the sources of the deponent’s information or the grounds for his belief; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: stating, where the garnishee is a bank having more than one place of business, the name and address of the branch at which the judgment debtor’s account is believed to be held or, if it be the case, that this information is not known to the deponent.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Service and effect of order to show cause (O. 49, r. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Unless the Court otherwise directs, an order under rule 1 to show cause must be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the garnishee personally, at least 15 days before the day appointed thereby for the further consideration of the matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the judgment debtor, at least 7 days after the order has been served on the garnishee and at least 7 days before the day appointed for the further consideration of the matter.

subsection.content: Such an order shall bind in the hands of the garnishee as from the service of the order on him any debt specified in the order or so much thereof as may be so specified.

section.name: s4
section.heading:
No appearance or dispute of liability
by garnishee (O. 49, r. 4)

subsection.content: Where on the further consideration of the matter the garnishee does not attend or does not dispute the debt due or claimed to be due from him to the judgment debtor, the Court may make an order absolute under rule 1 against the garnishee.
An order absolute under rule 1 against the garnishee may be enforced in the same manner as any other order for the payment of money.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Dispute of liability by garnishee (O. 49, r. 5)
section.content: Where on the further consideration of the matter the garnishee disputes liability to pay the debt due or claimed to be due from him to the judgment debtor, the Court may summarily determine the question at issue or order that any question necessary for determining the liability of the garnishee be tried in any manner in which any question or issue in an action may be tried, without if it orders trial before the master the need for any consent by the parties.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Claims of third persons (O. 49, r. 6)

subsection.content: If in garnishee proceedings it is brought to the notice of the Court that some other person than the judgment debtor is or claims to be entitled to the debt sought to be attached or has or claims to have a charge or lien upon it, the Court may order that person to attend before the Court and state the nature of his claim with particulars thereof.

After hearing any person who attends before the Court in compliance with an order under paragraph (1), the Court may summarily determine the questions at issue between the claimants or make such other order as it thinks just, including an order that any question or issue necessary for determining the validity of the claim of such other person as is mentioned in paragraph (1) be tried in such manner as is mentioned in rule 5.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Discharge of garnishee (O. 49, r. 8)
section.content: Any payment made by a garnishee in compliance with an order absolute under this Order, and any execution levied against him in pursuance of such an order, shall be a valid discharge of his liability to the judgment debtor to the extent of the amount paid or levied notwithstanding that the garnishee proceedings are subsequently set aside or the judgment or order from which they arose reversed.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Money in Court (O. 49, r. 9)

subsection.content: Where money is standing to the credit of the judgment debtor in court, the judgment creditor shall not be entitled to take garnishee proceedings in respect of that money but may apply to the Court by summons for an order that the money or so much thereof as is sufficient to satisfy the judgment or order sought to be enforced and the costs of the application be paid to the judgment creditor.
The money to which the application relates shall not be paid out of court until after the determination of the application.
Unless the Court otherwise directs, the summons must be served on the judgment debtor at least 7 days before the day named therein for the hearing of it.
The Court hearing an application under this rule may make such order with respect to the money in court as it thinks just.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Costs (O. 49, r. 10)
section.content: The costs of any application for an order under rule 1 or 9, and of any proceedings arising therefrom or incidental thereto, shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, be retained by the judgment creditor out of the money recovered by him under the order and in priority to the judgment debt.

section.name: s49B
section.heading: Execution and Enforcement of Judgment for Money by Imprisonment

section.name: s1
section.heading: Securing attendance at examination (O. 49B, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: Where a judgment for the payment of a specified sum of money is, wholly or partly, unsatisfied, the Court, on an ex parte application of the judgment creditor, may order that the judgment debtor be examined under rule 1A and shall, for the purpose of securing the attendance of the judgment debtor at an examination under rule 1A either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the judgment debtor, by an order which shall be served personally upon him, to appear before the Court at a time appointed by the Court, with such documents or records as the Court may specify; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it appears to the Court that there is reasonable cause, from all the circumstances of the case, including the conduct of the judgment debtor, to believe that an order under subparagraph (a) may be ineffective to secure the attendance of the judgment debtor for examination, order that he be arrested and brought before the Court before the expiry of the day after the day of arrest.

subsection.content: On an application under paragraph (1), the Court may make an order prohibiting the judgment debtor from leaving Hong Kong.

Where a judgment debtor fails to appear as ordered under paragraph (1)(a), the Court may order that he be arrested and brought before the Court for examination before the expiry of the day after the day of arrest.
Section 71 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall not apply to this rule.
The order for arrest under paragraph (3) shall be in Form No. 102 in Appendix A.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Examination of judgment debtor (O. 49B, r. 1A)

subsection.content: The judgment debtor shall, at his examination, make a full disclosure of all his assets, liabilities, income and expenditure and of the disposal of any assets or income and shall, subject to the directions of the Court, answer all questions put to him.

subsection.leadIn: Where the examination is adjourned, the Court shall order that the judgment debtor appear at the resumption of the examination and may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that he be prohibited from leaving Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it appears to the Court that there is reasonable cause, from all the circumstances of the case, including any evidence heard by the Court and the conduct of the judgment debtor, to believe that he may not appear at the resumption of the examination, order that he be imprisoned until that resumption.

subsection.content: The order for imprisonment under paragraph (3)(b) shall be in Form No. 103 in Appendix A.

section.name: s1AA
section.heading: Record of judgment debtor’s evidence given at examination (O. 49B, r. 1AA)
section.content: The Court shall cause to be recorded, by means of shorthand notes or mechanical, digital, electronic or optical device or otherwise, the evidence given by the judgment debtor at the examination conducted under rule 1A.

section.name: s1B
section.heading: Power of Court following examination (O. 49B, r. 1B)

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court is satisfied, following the examination conducted under rule 1A or following an examination conducted under Order 48, that the judgment debtor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is able to satisfy the judgment, wholly or partly; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has disposed of assets with a view to avoiding satisfaction of the judgment or the liability which is the subject of the judgment, wholly or partly; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has wilfully failed to make a full disclosure as required under rule 1A(2) or at the examination under Order 48 or to answer any question as provided under that rule or Order,

subsection.continued: the Court may, in its discretion, order the imprisonment of the judgment debtor for a period not exceeding 3 months.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Where the Court is satisfied, following the examination conducted under rule 1A or following an examination conducted under Order 48, that the judgment debtor is able or will be able to satisfy the judgment, wholly or partly, by instalments or otherwise, it may order him to satisfy the judgment in such manner as it thinks fit.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The Court may, on application, discharge, vary or suspend an order made under subparagraph (a), either absolutely or subject to such conditions as it thinks fit.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Where the judgment debtor fails to comply with an order made under paragraph (2), the judgment creditor may apply to the Court, on not less than 2 clear days’ notice to the judgment debtor, for an order for the imprisonment of the judgment debtor and the Court may, unless the judgment debtor shows good cause, order the imprisonment of the judgment debtor for a period not exceeding 3 months. (E.R. 1 of 2022)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Notwithstanding rule 7, the Court may order the imprisonment of the judgment debtor on each occasion of a failure to comply with an order made under paragraph (2) or more than once in respect of a continuing failure to comply with an order made under that paragraph.

subsection.content: The order for imprisonment under paragraph (1) shall be in Form No. 104 in Appendix A.
The application under paragraph (3)(a) shall be in Form No. 105 in Appendix A.
An order under paragraph (1), (2) or (3) shall not prevent execution of the judgment by other means unless the Court so directs.
An order for imprisonment of a judgment debtor shall be made in open court.

section.name: s1C
section.heading: Imprisonment not to satisfy debt (O. 49B, r. 1C)
section.content: An order for imprisonment under this Order shall not satisfy or extinguish any judgment debt.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Support and maintenance allowance to prisoner for debt (O. 49B, r. 2)
section.content: When a judgment debtor is committed to prison in execution of the judgment the Court shall fix whatever monthly allowance it may think sufficient for his support and maintenance, not exceeding $660 per diem, which shall be paid by the person at whose instance the judgment has been executed to the Commissioner of Correctional Services by monthly payments in advance, the second and subsequent such payments to be made not less than 7 days before the last preceding such payment is exhausted.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Removal to hospital of prisoner for debt in case of serious illness (O. 49B, r. 3)

subsection.content: In case of the serious illness of any person imprisoned in execution of a judgment it shall be lawful for the Court, on the certificate of the medical officer of the prison in which he is confined or of the Director of Health, to make an order for the removal of the judgment debtor to a hospital and for his treatment there under custody until further order.

In any such case the period of the judgment debtor’s stay in hospital shall be counted as part of his term of imprisonment and his support and maintenance money shall be paid as if no such order had been made.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Release of prisoner for debt (O. 49B, r. 4)
section.content: Every person arrested or imprisoned in execution of a judgment shall be released at any time on the judgment being fully satisfied, or at the request of the person at whose instance the judgment has been executed, or on such person omitting to pay his support and maintenance money.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Recovery of amount of support and maintenance money (O. 49B, r. 5)
section.content: All sums paid by a plaintiff for the support and maintenance of a person imprisoned in execution of a judgment shall be added to the costs of the judgment and shall be recoverable by the attachment and sale of the property of the judgment debtor; but the judgment debtor shall not be detained in custody or arrested on account of any sum so paid.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Recovery of costs of execution (O. 49B, r. 6)
section.content: The costs of obtaining and executing the order and warrant of arrest or imprisonment shall be added to the costs of the judgment and shall be recoverable accordingly.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Effect of discharge of prisoner for debt (O. 49B, r. 7)
section.content: Subject to rule 1B(3)(b), when any person imprisoned in execution of a judgment has been once discharged he shall not again be imprisoned on account of the same judgment, but his property shall continue liable, under the ordinary rules, to attachment and sale until the judgment is fully satisfied.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Meaning of judgment creditor (O. 49B, r. 8)
section.content: In this Order judgment creditor (判定債權人) includes any person entitled to enforce the judgment.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Charging Orders, Stop Orders, etc.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Order imposing a charge on a beneficial interest (O. 50, r. 1)

subsection.content: An application by a judgment creditor for a charging order in respect of a judgment debtor’s beneficial interest may be made ex parte, and any order made on such an application shall in the first instance be an order, made in Form No. 75 in Appendix A, to show cause, specifying the time and place for further consideration of the matter and imposing the charge in any event until that time.

subsection.leadIn: The application shall be supported by an affidavit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifying the judgment or order to be enforced and stating the amount unpaid at the date of the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stating the name of the judgment debtor and of any creditor of his whom the applicant can identify;

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.leadIn: if the amount unpaid under the judgment or order is arrears of maintenance, stating—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the interest payable in respect of the arrears of maintenance that the judgment creditor is entitled to under section 20A(2) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9B(2) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53A(2) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AA(2) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the surcharge payable in respect of the arrears of maintenance under section 20B(1) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9C(1) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53B(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AB(1) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be; (18 of 2003 s. 24)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: giving full particulars of the subject-matter of the intended charge, including, in the case of securities other than securities in court, the full title of the securities, their amount and the name in which they stand and, in the case of funds in court, the number of the account; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: verifying that the interest to be charged is owned beneficially by the judgment debtor.

subsection.content: Unless the Court otherwise directs, an affidavit for the purposes of this rule may contain statements of information or belief with the sources and grounds thereof.
An application may be made for a single charging order in respect of more than one judgment or order against the judgment debtor.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Service of notice of order to show cause (O. 50, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: On the making of an order to show cause, notice of the order shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, be served as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the order, together with a copy of the affidavit in support, shall be served on the judgment debtor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where the order relates to securities other than securities in court, copies of the order shall also be served—

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of stock of any body incorporated within Hong Kong, on that body;

subparagraph.name: iv
v

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the order relates to a fund in court, a copy of the order shall be served on the Registrar at the Registry; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where the order relates to an interest under a trust, copies of the order shall be served on such of the trustees as the Court may direct.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (1) the Court may, on making the order to show cause, direct the service of copies of the order, and of the affidavit in support, on any other creditor of the judgment debtor or on any other interested person as may be appropriate in the circumstances.
Documents to be served under this rule must be served at least 7 days before the time specified for the further consideration of the matter.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Order made on further consideration (O. 50, r. 3)

subsection.content: On the further consideration of the matter the Court shall either make the order absolute, with or without modifications, or discharge it.

Where the order is made absolute, it shall be in Form No. 76 in Appendix A, and where it is discharged, the provisions of rule 7, regarding the service of copies of the order of discharge, shall apply.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Order imposing charge on interest held by trustee (O. 50, r. 4)

subsection.content: Save as provided by this rule, the provisions of rules 1 to 3 shall apply to an order charging an interest held by a trustee as they apply to an order charging the judgment debtor’s beneficial interest.

Instead of verifying the judgment debtor’s beneficial ownership of the interest to be charged, the affidavit required by rule 1(3) shall state the ground on which the application is based and shall verify the material facts.

On making the order to show cause, the Court shall give directions for copies of the order, and of the affidavit in support, to be served on such of the trustees and beneficiaries, if any, as may be appropriate.

subsection.def: Rules 5 to 7 shall apply to an order charging an interest held by a trustee as they apply to an order charging the judgment debtor’s beneficial interest, except that, where the order is made under section 52AA(1)(b)(ii) or (iii) of the Ordinance references in those rules to the judgment debtor shall be references to the trustee.

subsection.content: Forms No. 75 and 76 in Appendix A shall be modified so as to indicate that the interest to be charged is held by the judgment debtor as trustee or, as the case may be, that it is held by a trustee (to be named in the order) on trust for the judgment debtor beneficially.

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Effect of order in relation to securities
out of Court (O. 50, r. 5)

subsection.content: No disposition by the judgment debtor of his interest in any securities to which an order to show cause relates made after the making of that order shall, so long as that order remains in force, be valid as against the judgment creditor.

Until such order is discharged or made absolute, the person or body served in accordance with rule 2(1)(b) shall not permit any transfer of any of the securities specified in the order, or pay any dividend, interest or redemption payment in relation thereto, except with the authority of the Court, and, if it does so, shall be liable to pay the judgment creditor the value of the securities transferred or, as the case may be, the amount of the payment made or, if that value or amount is more than sufficient to satisfy the judgment or order to which such order relates, so much thereof as is sufficient to satisfy it.

If the Court makes the order absolute, a copy of the order, including a stop notice as provided in Form No. 76 in Appendix A, shall be served on the person or body specified in rule 2(1)(b) as may be appropriate and, save as provided in rule 7(5), rules 11 to 14 shall apply to such a notice as they apply to a stop notice made and served under rule 11.
This rule does not apply to orders in respect of securities in court.

section.name: s6
section.heading:
Effect of order in relation to funds
in Court (O. 50, r. 6)

subsection.content: Where an order to show cause has been made in relation to funds in court (including securities in court) and a copy thereof has been served on the Registrar in accordance with rule 2, no disposition by the judgment debtor of any interest to which the order relates, made after the making of that order, shall, so long as the order remains in force, be valid as against the judgment creditor.
If the Court makes the order absolute, a copy of the order shall be served on the Registrar at the Registry.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Discharge, etc., of charging order (O. 50, r. 7)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (2) on the application of the judgment debtor or any other person interested in the subject-matter of the charge, the Court may, at any time, whether before or after the order is made absolute, discharge or vary the order on such terms (if any) as to costs or otherwise as it thinks just.

Where an application is made for the discharge of a charging order in respect of the judgment debtor’s land on the ground that the judgment debt has been satisfied, the applicant shall state in his application, and the Court shall specify in its order the lot number of the land and the memorial number of any relevant charge registered against the land.
Notice of an application for the discharge or variation of a charging order shall be served on such interested parties as the Court may direct.
Where an order is made for the discharge or variation of a charging order in respect of funds in court, a copy thereof shall be served on the Registrar at the Registry.

Where an order is made for the discharge or variation of a charging order in respect of securities other than securities in court, a copy thereof shall be served on the person or body specified in rule 2(1)(b) as may be appropriate, and the service thereof shall discharge, or, as the case may be, vary, any stop notice in respect of such securities which may be in force pursuant to the original order.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Jurisdiction of master to grant injunction (O. 50, r. 9)
section.content: A master shall have power to grant an injunction if, and only so far as, it is ancillary or incidental to an order under rule 1, 3 or 4 and an application for an injunction under this rule may be joined with the application for the order under rule 1, 3 or 4 to which it relates.

section.name: s9A
section.heading: Enforcement of charging order by sale (O. 50, r. 9A)

subsection.content: Proceedings for the enforcement of a charging order by sale of the property charged must be begun by originating summons.
The provisions of Order 88 shall apply to all such proceedings.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Funds in Court: stop order (O. 50, r. 10)

subsection.leadIn: The Court, on the application of any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who has a mortgage or charge on the interest of any person in funds in court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to whom that interest has been assigned; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: who is a judgment creditor of the person entitled to that interest,

subsection.continued: may make an order prohibiting the transfer, sale, delivery out, payment or other dealing with such funds, or any part thereof, or the income thereon, without notice to the applicant. (See Appendix A, Form 79)

subsection.content: An application for an order under this rule must be made by summons in the cause or matter relating to the funds in court, or, if there is no such cause or matter, by originating summons.
The summons must be served on every person whose interest may be affected by the order applied for but shall not be served on any other person.

Without prejudice to the Court’s powers and discretion as to costs, the Court may order the applicant for an order under this rule to pay the costs of any party to the cause or matter relating to the funds in question, or of any person interested in those funds occasioned by the application.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Securities not in Court: stop notice (O. 50, r. 11)

subsection.content: Any person claiming to be beneficially entitled to an interest in any securities of the kinds set out in section 52AA(2)(b) of the Ordinance, other than securities in court, who wishes to be notified of any proposed transfer or payment of those securities may avail himself of the provisions of this rule.

subsection.leadIn: A person claiming to be so entitled must file in the Registry—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a notice in Form No. 80 in Appendix A (a stop notice), signed by the deponent to the affidavit, and annexed to it, addressed to the body or unit trust concerned,

subsection.continued: and must serve an office copy of the affidavit, and a copy of the notice sealed with the Seal of the Court on that person or body specified in rule 2(1)(b).

subsection.content: There must be endorsed on the affidavit filed under this rule a note stating the address to which any such notice as is referred to in rule 12 is to be sent and, subject to paragraph (4), that address shall for the purpose of that rule be the address for service of the person on whose behalf the affidavit is filed.

A person on whose behalf an affidavit under this rule is filed may change his address for service for the purpose of rule 12 by serving on the person or body concerned, a notice to that effect, and as from the date of service of such a notice the address stated therein shall for the purpose of that rule be the address for service of that person.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Effect of stop notice (O. 50, r. 12)
section.content: Where a stop notice has been served in accordance with rule 11 then, so long as the stop notice is in force, the person or body on which it is served shall not register a transfer of the securities or take any other steps restrained by the stop notice until 14 days after sending notice thereof, by ordinary pre-paid post, to the person on whose behalf the stop notice was filed, but shall not by reason only of that notice refuse to register a transfer, or to take any other steps, after the expiry of that period.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Amendment of stop notice (O. 50, r. 13)
section.content: If any securities are incorrectly described in a stop notice which has been filed and of which a sealed copy has been served in accordance with rule 11, an amended stop notice may be filed and served in accordance with the same procedure and shall take effect as a stop notice on the day on which the sealed copy of the amended notice is served.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Withdrawal, etc., of stop notice (O. 50, r. 14)

subsection.content: The person on whose behalf a stop notice was filed may withdraw it by serving a request for its withdrawal on the person or body on whom the notice was served.
Such request must be signed by the person on whose behalf the notice was filed and his signature must be witnessed by a practising solicitor.
The Court, on the application of any person claiming to be beneficially entitled to an interest in the securities to which a notice under rule 11 relates, may by order discharge the notice.

subsection.leadIn: An application for an order under paragraph (3) must be made by originating summons, and the summons must be served on the person on whose behalf a stop notice was filed.
subsection.continued: The summons shall be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Order prohibiting transfer, etc., of securities (O. 50, r. 15)

subsection.leadIn: The Court, on the application of any person claiming to be beneficially entitled to an interest in any securities of the kinds set out in section 52AA(2)(b) of the Ordinance, may by order prohibit the person or body concerned from registering any transfer of the securities or taking any other steps to which section 72C(4) of the Ordinance applies.
subsection.continued: The order shall specify the securities to which the prohibition relates, the name in which they stand and the steps which may not be taken, and shall state whether the prohibition applies to the securities only or to the dividends or interest as well.

subsection.content: An application for an order under this rule must be made by summons. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: An originating summons under this rule must be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

The Court, on the application of any person claiming to be beneficially entitled to an interest in any securities to which an order under this rule relates, may vary or discharge the order on such terms (if any) as to costs or otherwise as it thinks fit.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Partner’s interest in partnership property (O. 50, r. 16)
section.content: Nothing in this Order shall affect the provisions of Order 81, rule 10.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Receivers: Equitable Execution

section.name: s1
section.heading: Appointment of receiver by way of equitable execution (O. 51, r. 1)
section.content: Where an application is made for the appointment of a receiver by way of equitable execution, the Court in determining whether it is just or convenient that the appointment should be made shall have regard to the amount claimed by the judgment creditor, to the amount likely to be obtained by the receiver and to the probable costs of his appointment and may direct an inquiry on any of these matters or any other matter before making the appointment. (See Appendix A, Form 84)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Masters may appoint receiver, etc. (O. 51, r. 2)
section.content: A master shall have power to make an order for the appointment of a receiver by way of equitable execution and to grant an injunction if, and only so far as, the injunction is ancillary or incidental to such order.

section.name: s3
section.heading:
Application of rules as to appointment of
receiver, etc. (O. 51, r. 3)
section.content: An application for the appointment of a receiver by way of equitable execution may be made in accordance with Order 30, rule 1, and rules 2 to 6 of that Order shall apply in relation to a receiver appointed by way of equitable execution as they apply in relation to a receiver appointed for any other purpose. (See Appendix A, Forms 82, 83)

section.name: s52
section.heading: Committal

section.name: s1
section.heading: Committal for contempt of Court (O. 52, r. 1)
section.content: The power of the Court to punish for contempt of court may be exercised by an order of committal made by a judge. (See Appendix A, Forms 85, 85A)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Grant of leave to apply for committal (O. 52, r. 2)

subsection.content: No application for an order of committal against any person may be made unless leave to make such an application has been granted in accordance with this rule.

An application for such leave must be made ex parte to a judge, and must be supported by a statement setting out the name and description of the applicant, the name, description and address of the person sought to be committed and the grounds on which his committal is sought, and by an affidavit, to be filed before the application is made, verifying the facts relied on.
The applicant must give notice of the application for leave not later than the preceding day to the Registrar and must at the same time lodge with the Registrar copies of the statement and affidavit.

The judge may determine the application for leave without a hearing, unless a hearing is requested in the notice of application, and need not sit in open court; and in any case the Registrar shall serve a copy of the judge’s order on the applicant.
Where an application for leave is refused by a judge or is granted on terms, the applicant may appeal against the judge’s order to the Court of Appeal within 10 days after such order.

Without prejudice to the powers conferred by Order 20, rule 8, the judge hearing an application for leave may allow the applicant’s statement to be amended on such terms, if any, as the judge thinks fit.
If the judge grants leave he may impose such terms as to costs and as to giving of security as he thinks fit.

section.name: s3
section.heading:
Application for order after leave to
apply granted (O. 52, r. 3)

subsection.content: When leave has been granted to make an application for an order of committal, the application shall be made by originating summons to a judge and unless the judge granting leave has otherwise directed, there must be at least 8 clear days between the service of the originating summons and the day named therein for the hearing.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The originating summons shall state the grounds in respect of which leave for making an application for an order of committal has been granted. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Unless within 14 days after such leave was granted the originating summons is entered for hearing the leave shall lapse.

The originating summons, accompanied by a copy of the statement and affidavit in support of the application for leave under rule 2, and the notice of hearing of the originating summons must be served personally on the person sought to be committed.
Without prejudice to the powers of the Court under Order 65, rule 4, the judge may dispense with service under this rule if he thinks it just to do so. (L.N. 217 of 2000)

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Saving for power to commit without application
for purpose (O. 52, r. 5)
section.content: Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Order shall be taken as affecting the power of the Court to make an order of committal of its own motion against a person guilty of contempt of court.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Provisions as to hearing (O. 52, r. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (2), the judge hearing an application for an order of committal may sit in private in the following cases, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the application arises out of proceedings relating to the adoption of an infant or wholly or mainly to the guardianship, custody, maintenance or upbringing of an infant, or rights of access to an infant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the application arises out of proceedings relating to a person suffering or appearing to be suffering from mental disorder within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the application arises out of proceedings in which a secret process, discovery or invention was in issue;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where it appears to the judge that in the interests of the administration of justice or for reasons affecting the security of Hong Kong the application should be heard in private,

subsection.continued: but, except as aforesaid, the application shall be heard in open court.

subsection.leadIn: If the judge hearing an application in private by virtue of paragraph (1) decides to make an order of committal against the person sought to be committed, he shall in open court state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of that person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in general terms the nature of the contempt of court in respect of which the order of committal is being made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the length of the period for which he is being committed.

subsection.content:
Except with the leave of the judge hearing an application for an order of committal, no grounds shall be relied upon at the hearing except the grounds as stated in the originating summons under rule 3(1A). (L.N. 153 of 2008)
The foregoing provision is without prejudice to the powers of the Court under Order 20, rule 8.
If on the hearing of the application the person sought to be committed expresses a wish to give oral evidence on his own behalf, he shall be entitled to do so.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Power to suspend execution of committal order (O. 52, r. 7)

subsection.content: The judge by whom an order of committal is made may by order direct that the execution of the order of committal shall be suspended for such period or on such terms or conditions as he may specify.

Where execution of an order of committal is suspended by an order under paragraph (1), the applicant for the order of committal must, unless the judge otherwise directs, serve on the person against whom it was made a notice informing him of the making and terms of the order under that paragraph.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Discharge of person committed (O. 52, r. 8)

subsection.content: The judge may, on the application of any person committed to prison for any contempt of court, discharge him.

Where a person has been committed for failing to comply with a judgment or order requiring him to deliver any thing to some other person or to deposit it in court or elsewhere, and a writ of sequestration has also been issued to enforce that judgment or order, then, if the thing is in the custody or power of the person committed, the commissioners appointed by the writ of sequestration may take possession of it as if it were the property of that person and, without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), the judge may discharge the person committed and may give such directions for dealing with the thing taken by the commissioners as he thinks fit.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Saving for other powers (O. 52, r. 9)
section.content: Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Order shall be taken as affecting the power of the Court to make an order requiring a person guilty of contempt of court, or a person punishable by virtue of any written law in like manner as if he had been guilty of contempt of the Court of First Instance, to pay a fine or to give security for his good behaviour, and those provisions, so far as applicable, and with the necessary modifications, shall apply in relation to an application for such an order as they apply in relation to an application for an order of committal.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Appeals

section.name: s1
section.heading:
Appeals from master to judge in
chambers (O. 58, r. 1)

subsection.content: Except as provided by rule 2 and Order 32 rule 17, an appeal shall lie to a judge in chambers from any judgment, order or decision of a master, irrespective of whether the judgment, order or decision was given or made on the basis of written submissions only or after hearing.

The appeal shall be brought by serving on every other party to the proceedings in which the judgment, order or decision was given or made a notice to attend before the judge on a day specified in the notice or as on such other day as may be directed.

Unless the Court otherwise orders, the notice must be issued within 14 days after the judgment, order or decision appealed against was given or made and must be served within 5 days after issue and an appeal to which this rule applies shall not be heard sooner than 2 clear days after such service.

No further evidence (other than evidence as to matters which have occurred after the date on which the judgment, order or decision was given or made) may be received on the hearing of an appeal under this rule except on special grounds. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Appeals to Court of Appeal (O. 58, r. 2)

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this rule, an appeal shall lie to the Court of Appeal from any judgment, order or decision of a judge. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the provisions of this rule, an appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judgment, order or decision of a master on any cause, matter, question or issue tried or assessed before him under Order 14, rule 6(2), Order 36, rule 1, Order 37 or Order 84A, rule 3; (L.N. 100 of 2014)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a judgment, order or decision (other than an interlocutory judgment, order or decision) of a master given or made under Order 49B; and (L.N. 153 of 2008; L.N. 100 of 2014)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a judgment of order of a master given or made under Order 17, rule 11(2). (L.N. 100 of 2014)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Notwithstanding paragraph (2)(b), an appeal lies to the Court of Appeal as of right from an order for imprisonment given or made by a master under Order 49B. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: An application for leave to appeal must be made to a judge, or to a master in the case of an appeal under paragraph (2), within—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: in the case of an appeal from an interlocutory judgment, order or decision of a judge, 14 days from the date of the interlocutory judgment, order or decision. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: If the judge or master (as the case may be) refuses an application for leave made under paragraph (4), a further application for leave may be made to the Court of Appeal within 14 days from the date of refusal. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.content: An application under paragraph (4) or (4A) must be made inter partes if the proceedings to which the judgment, order or decision relates are inter partes. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

So far as is practicable, every application for leave to appeal made to a judge or a master shall be made to the judge or the master against whose judgment, order or decision the appeal is sought. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
In any case in which the Court of Appeal may so allow, any such application may be made direct to the Court of Appeal.

Where leave to appeal is granted under paragraph (4) or (4A), the notice of appeal must be served under Order 59, rule 3(5) of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A), not later than 7 days after the date when leave is granted. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

In the case of an appeal from an order specified in section 63(3) of the Ordinance or an order for imprisonment given or made under Order 49B, the notice of appeal must be served under Order 59, rule 3(5) of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A), not later than 28 days from the date of the order of the Court. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

The Court or the Court of Appeal may, at any time, and notwithstanding that the time for an appeal or an application for leave to appeal may have already expired, extend the time for the appeal or for applying for leave to appeal.

section.name: s3
section.heading:
Appeal not to operate as stay of
proceedings (O. 58, r. 3)
section.content: Except so far as the Court may otherwise direct, an appeal under this Order shall not operate as a stay of the proceedings in which the appeal is brought.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Non-interlocutory judgments and orders (O. 58, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of rule 2(4)(b) and (c), the following judgments and orders are not interlocutory—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judgment or order determining in a summary way the substantive rights of a party to an action;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order made under section 53(3) of the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order prohibiting a debtor from leaving Hong Kong under Order 44A, rule 3(1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order for the imprisonment of a judgment debtor under Order 49B;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an order of committal for contempt of court under Order 52, rule 1; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a judgment given inter partes under Order 83A, rule 4, or Order 84A, rule 3 or in a mortgage action within the meaning of Order 88, rule 1.

subsection.leadIn: Without affecting the generality of paragraph (1)(a), the following are judgments and orders determining in a summary way the substantive rights of a party—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a summary judgment under Order 14 or Order 86;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a judgment or order determining any question of law or the construction of any document under Order 14A, rule 1(1);

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: a judgment on any question or issue tried pursuant to an order under Order 33, rule 3;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: an order dismissing or striking out an action or other proceedings for want of prosecution;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a judgment obtained pursuant to an “unless” order;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: an order refusing to set aside a judgment in default;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: an order refusing to allow an amendment of a pleading to introduce a new claim or defence or any other new issue; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: a judgment or order on admissions under Order 27, rule 3.

subsection.content: A direction as to whether a judgment or order is one that is referred to in paragraph (1)(a) may be sought from the judge who made or will make the judgment or order.
A reference to an order specified in paragraph (1)(b), (c), (d) and (e) includes an order refusing, varying or discharging the order.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Costs

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 62, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: In this Order—
subsection.def: certificate (證明書) includes allocatur;
contentious business (爭議事務) means any business done, whether as a barrister, solicitor or advocate, in or for the purpose of proceedings begun before the Court; (10 of 2005 s. 180)
legal representative (法律代表), in relation to a party to proceedings, means a counsel or solicitor conducting litigation on behalf of the party; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

mentally disordered person (精神紊亂的人) means a person who is so far disabled in mind or who is so mentally ill or subnormal due to arrested or incomplete development of mind as to render it either necessary or expedient that he, either for his own sake or in the public interest, should be placed and kept under control;
non-contentious business (非爭議事務) means any business done by and as a solicitor which is not contentious business;

def.name: PartyEntitledToBeHeardOnTaxation
def.leadIn: party entitled to be heard on taxation (有權在訟費評定中獲聆聽的一方) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party entitled to payment of costs;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a person who has given the party entitled to payment of costs and the Registrar written notice that he has a financial interest in the outcome of the taxation; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person in respect of whom a direction has been given under rule 21(3); (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.def: taxed costs (經評定的訟費) means costs taxed in accordance with this Order;
taxing master (訟費評定官) means the Registrar as taxing master; (L.N. 153 of 2008)
the Court (區域法院) means the District Court or any one or more judges thereof, whether sitting in court or in chambers, the Registrar or master;
wasted costs order (虛耗訟費命令) means an order made under section 53(3) of the Ordinance. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.content: In this Order, references to a fund, being a fund out of which costs are to be paid or which is held by a trustee or personal representative, include references to any estate or property whether immovable or personal held for the benefit of any person or class of persons; and references to a fund held by a trustee or personal representative include references to any fund to which he is entitled (whether alone or together with any other person) in that capacity, whether the fund is for the time being in his possession or not.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application (O. 62, r. 2)

subsection.content: This Order shall apply to all proceedings in the Court.

The powers and discretion of the Court as to costs under sections 53 and 53A of the Ordinance and under the enactments relating to the costs of criminal proceedings to which this Order applies shall be exercised subject to and in accordance with this Order. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Order as to entitlement to costs (O. 62, r. 3)

subsection.content: Subject to the provisions of this Order, no party shall be entitled to recover any costs of or incidental to any proceedings from any other party to the proceedings except under an order of the Court.

If the Court in the exercise of its discretion sees fit to make any order as to the costs of or incidental to any proceedings (other than interlocutory proceedings), the Court shall, subject to this Order, order the costs to follow the event, except when it appears to the Court that in the circumstances of the case some other order should be made as to the whole or any part of the costs. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: If the Court in the exercise of its discretion sees fit to make any order as to the costs of or incidental to any interlocutory proceedings, it may, subject to this Order, order the costs to follow the event or make such other order as it sees fit. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
The costs of and occasioned by any amendment made without leave in the writ of summons or any pleading shall be borne by the party making the amendment, unless the Court otherwise orders.

The costs of and occasioned by any application to extend the time fixed by these Rules, or any direction or order thereunder, for serving or filing any document or the doing of any other act (including the costs of any order made on the application) shall be borne by the party making the application, unless the Court otherwise orders.

If a party on whom a notice to admit facts is served under Order 27, rule 2, refuses or neglects to admit the facts within 7 days after the service on him of the notice or such longer time as may be allowed by the Court, the costs of proving the facts shall be paid by him, unless the Court otherwise orders.

subsection.leadIn: If a party—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on whom a list of documents is served in pursuance of any provision of Order 24; or (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on whom a notice to admit documents is served in accordance with Order 27, rule 5,

subsection.continued: gives notice of non-admission of any of the documents in accordance with Order 27, rule 4(2) or 5(2), as the case may be, the costs of proving that document shall be paid by him, unless the Court otherwise orders.

subsection.content: Where a defendant by notice in writing and without leave discontinues his counterclaim against any party or withdraws any particular claim made by him therein against any party, that party shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, be entitled to his costs of the counterclaim or his costs occasioned by the claim withdrawn, as the case may be, incurred to the time of receipt of the notice of discontinuance or withdrawal.

Where any person claiming to be a creditor seeks to establish his claim to a debt under any judgment or order in accordance with Order 44, he shall, if his claim succeeds, be entitled to his costs incurred in establishing it, unless the Court otherwise directs, and, if his claim or any part of it fails, may be ordered to pay the costs of any person incurred in opposing it.

Where a claimant is entitled to costs under paragraph (9), the amount of the costs shall be fixed by the Court unless it thinks fit to direct taxation, and the amount fixed or allowed shall be added to the claimant’s debt.

Where a claimant (other than a person claiming to be a creditor) having established a claim to be entitled under a judgment or order in accordance with Order 44 has been served with notice of the judgment or order pursuant to rule 2 of that Order, he shall, if he acknowledges service of the notice be entitled as part of his costs of action (if allowed) to costs incurred in establishing his claim, unless the Court otherwise directs; and where such a claimant fails to establish his claim or any part of it he may be ordered to pay the costs of any person incurred in opposing it.

Where an application is made in accordance with Order 24, rule 7A or Order 29, rule 7A, for an order under section 47A, 47B or 47D of the Ordinance, the person against whom the order is sought shall be entitled, unless the Court otherwise directs, to his costs of and incidental to the application and of complying with any order made thereon and he may, after giving the applicant 7 days’ notice of his intention to do so, tax such costs and, if they are not paid within 4 days after taxation, sign judgment for them.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Stage of proceedings at which costs to be dealt with (O. 62, r. 4)

subsection.content: Costs may be dealt with by the Court at any stage of the proceedings or after the conclusion of the proceedings; and any order of the Court for the payment of any costs may, if the Court thinks fit, and the person against whom the order is made is not an assisted person, require the costs to be paid forthwith notwithstanding that the proceedings have not been concluded.

In the case of any proceedings transferred to the Court from any other court or tribunal, the costs of the whole proceedings, both before and after the transfer, may (subject to any order of the court or tribunal ordering the transfer) be dealt with by the Court to which the proceedings are transferred. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Where under paragraph (2) the Court makes an order as to the costs of any proceedings before another court or tribunal, rules 28, 31 and 32 do not apply in relation to those costs, but, except in relation to costs of proceedings transferred from the Court of First Instance or the Lands Tribunal, the order shall specify the amount of the costs to be allowed. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Special matters to be taken into account in exercising discretion (O. 62, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: The Court in exercising its discretion as to costs shall, to such extent, if any, as may be appropriate in the circumstances, take into account— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: the underlying objectives set out in Order 1A, rule 1; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any payment of money into court and the amount of such payment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any written offer made under Order 33, rule 4A(2); (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any written offer which is expressed to be “without prejudice save as to costs” and which relates to any issue in the proceedings, but the Court may not take the offer into account if, at the time it is made, the party making it could have protected his position as to costs by means of a sanctioned payment or a sanctioned offer under Order 22; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the conduct of all the parties; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whether a party has succeeded on part of his case, even if he has not been wholly successful; and (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any admissible offer to settle made by a party, which is drawn to the Court’s attention. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of paragraph (1)(e), the conduct of the parties includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether it was reasonable for a party to raise, pursue or contest a particular allegation or issue;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manner in which a party has pursued or defended his case or a particular allegation or issue;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether a claimant who has succeeded in his claim, in whole or in part, exaggerated his claim; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: conduct before, as well as during, the proceedings. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s6
section.heading:
Restriction of discretion to order costs
(O. 62, r. 6)

subsection.content: Where a person is or has been a party to any proceedings in the capacity of trustee, personal representative or mortgagee, he shall, unless the Court otherwise orders, be entitled to the costs of those proceedings, in so far as they are not recovered from or paid by any other person, out of the fund held by the trustee or personal representative or the mortgaged property, as the case may be; and the Court may otherwise order only on the ground that the trustee, personal representative or mortgagee has acted unreasonably or, in the case of a trustee or personal representative, has in substance acted for his own benefit rather than for the benefit of the fund.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Costs orders in favour of or against non-parties (O. 62, r. 6A)

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court is considering whether to exercise its power under section 53 or 53A of the Ordinance to make a costs order in favour of or against a person who is not a party to the relevant proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that person must be joined as a party to the proceedings for the purposes of costs only; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that person must be given a reasonable opportunity to attend a hearing at which the Court shall consider the matter further.

subsection.leadIn: This rule does not apply where the Court is considering whether to make—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a wasted costs order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 47A or 47B of the Ordinance.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Costs arising from misconduct or neglect (O. 62, r. 7)

subsection.content: Where in any cause or matter any thing is done or omission is made improperly or unnecessarily by or on behalf of a party, the Court may direct that any costs to that party in respect of it shall not be allowed to him and that any costs occasioned by it to other parties shall be paid by him to them.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), the Court shall for the purpose of that paragraph have regard in particular to the following matters, that is to say—

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: the underlying objectives set out in Order 1A, rule 1; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the omission to do any thing the doing of which would have been calculated to save costs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the doing of any thing calculated to occasion, or in a manner or at a time calculated to occasion, unnecessary costs;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any unnecessary delay in the proceedings.

subsection.content: The Court may, instead of giving a direction under paragraph (1) in relation to any thing done or omission made, direct the taxing master to inquire into it and, if it appears to him that such a direction as aforesaid should have been given in relation to it, to act as if the appropriate direction had been given.

The taxing master shall, in relation to any thing done or omission made in the course of taxation, have the same power to disallow or to award costs as the Court has under paragraph (1) to direct that costs shall be disallowed to or paid by any party. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s8
section.heading: Personal liability of legal representative for costs—wasted costs order (O. 62, r. 8)

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make a wasted costs order against a legal representative, only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the legal representative, whether personally or through his employee or agent, has caused a party to incur wasted costs as defined in section 53(5) of the Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is just in all the circumstances to order the legal representative to compensate the party for the whole or part of those costs.

subsection.leadIn: A wasted costs order may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disallow the costs as between the legal representative and his client; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: direct the legal representative to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: repay to his client costs which the client has been ordered to pay to other parties to the proceedings; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: indemnify other parties against costs incurred by them.

subsection.content: The Court shall give the legal representative a reasonable opportunity to attend a hearing to give reasons why it should not make the order.

subsection.leadIn: When the Court makes a wasted costs order, it shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify the amount to be disallowed or paid; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct a master to decide the amount of costs to be disallowed or paid.

subsection.content: The Court may give directions about the procedure that should be followed in each case in order to ensure that the issues are dealt with in a way that is fair and is as simple and summary as the circumstances permit.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may direct that notice must be given to the legal representative’s client, in such manner as the Court may direct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of any proceedings under this rule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of any order made under this rule against his legal representative.

subsection.content: Before making a wasted costs order, the Court may direct a master to inquire into the matter and report to the Court.
The Court may refer the question of wasted costs to a master, instead of making a wasted costs order.

The Court may, if it thinks fit, direct or authorize the Official Solicitor to attend and take part in any proceedings or inquiry under this rule, and may make such order as it thinks fit as to the payment of his costs.

section.name: s8A
section.heading: Court may make wasted costs order on its own motion or on application (O. 62, r. 8A)

subsection.content: The Court may make a wasted costs order against a legal representative on its own motion.

subsection.leadIn: A party may apply for a wasted costs order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: orally in the course of a hearing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by making an interlocutory application by summons.

subsection.leadIn: Where a party applies for a wasted costs order by making an interlocutory application by summons, the party shall serve the summons on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the legal representative concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any party represented by that legal representative; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other person as may be directed by the Court,

subsection.continued: not less than 2 clear days before the day specified in the summons for its hearing.

subsection.content: An application for a wasted costs order shall not be made or dealt with until the conclusion of the proceedings to which the order relates, unless the Court is satisfied that there is reasonable cause for the application to be made or dealt with before the conclusion of the proceedings.

Unless there are exceptional circumstances making it inappropriate to do so, an application for a wasted costs order shall be heard by the judge or master who conducted the proceedings to which the order relates.

section.name: s8B
section.heading: Stages of considering whether to make a wasted costs order (O. 62, r. 8B)

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall consider whether to make a wasted costs order in 2 stages—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the first stage, the Court must be satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: the wasted costs proceedings are justified notwithstanding the likely costs involved; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the second stage (even if the Court is satisfied under subparagraph (a)), the Court shall consider, after giving the legal representative an opportunity to give reasons why the Court should not make a wasted costs order, whether it is appropriate to make the order in accordance with rule 8.

subsection.content: On an application for a wasted costs order, the Court may proceed to the second stage described in paragraph (1)(b) without first adjourning the hearing if it is satisfied that the legal representative has already had a reasonable opportunity to give reasons why the Court should not make a wasted costs order. In other cases the Court shall adjourn the hearing before proceeding to the second stage.

subsection.leadIn: On an application for a wasted costs order, any evidence in support must identify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: what the legal representative is alleged to have done or failed to do; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs that he may be ordered to pay or which are sought against him.

section.name: s8C
section.heading: Application for wasted costs order not to be used as means of intimidation (O. 62, r. 8C)

subsection.content: A party shall not by himself or by another person on his behalf threaten another party or any of that party’s legal representatives with an application for a wasted costs order with a view to coercing or intimidating either of them to do or refrain from doing anything.

subsection.leadIn: A party shall not indicate to another party or any of that party’s legal representatives that he intends to apply for a wasted costs order unless he is satisfied that he is able to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: particularize the behaviour of the legal representative from which the wasted costs concerned are alleged to result; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify the evidence or other materials on which he relies in support of the allegation.

section.name: s8D
section.heading: Personal liability of legal representative for costs—supplementary provisions (O. 62, r. 8D)

subsection.content: Where in any proceedings before a taxing master, the legal representative representing any party is guilty of neglect or delay or puts any other party to any unnecessary expense in relation to those proceedings, the taxing master may direct the legal representative personally to pay costs to any of the parties to those proceedings.

Where any legal representative fails to file a bill of costs (with the documents required by this Order) for taxation within the time fixed by or under this Order or otherwise delays or impedes the taxation, then, unless the taxing master otherwise directs, the legal representative shall not be allowed the fees to which he would otherwise be entitled for drawing the bill of costs and for attending the taxation.

If, on the taxation of costs to be paid out of a fund other than funds provided by the Legislative Council pursuant to section 27 of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91), one-sixth or more of the amount of the bill for those costs is taxed off, the legal representative whose bill it is shall not be allowed the fees to which he would otherwise be entitled for drawing the bill and for attending the taxation.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings in which the party by whom the fees prescribed by any enactment relating to court fees are payable is represented by a legal representative, if the fees or any part of the fees payable under that enactment are not paid as prescribed, the Court may, on the application of the Official Solicitor by summons, order the legal representative personally to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pay that amount in the manner so prescribed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pay the costs of the Official Solicitor of the application.

subsection.leadIn: A legal representative shall not be directed or ordered under this rule to pay any costs or fees, nor shall he be disallowed under this rule any fees, unless he has been given a reasonable opportunity to give reasons why—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the direction or order should not be made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he should not be disallowed the fees.

subsection.leadIn: When a taxing master makes a direction under paragraph (1), he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall specify the amount to be paid; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may give directions about the procedure that should be followed in each case in order to ensure that the issues are dealt with in a way that is fair and is as simple and summary as the circumstances permit.

subsection.content: The Court or a taxing master may direct that notice must be given to the legal representative’s client, in such manner as the Court or the taxing master may direct, of any direction or order made under this rule against his legal representative.

section.name: s8E
section.heading: Stages of considering whether to make direction under rule 8D(1) (O. 62, r. 8E)

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master shall consider whether to make a direction under rule 8D(1) in 2 stages—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the first stage, the taxing master must be satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he has before him evidence or other material which, if unanswered, would be likely to lead to a direction under rule 8D(1) being made; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the direction is justified notwithstanding the likely costs involved; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the second stage (even if the taxing master is satisfied under subparagraph (a)), the taxing master shall consider, after giving the legal representative an opportunity to give reasons why the taxing master should not make the direction, whether it is appropriate to make the direction.

subsection.content: On an application for a direction under rule 8D(1), the taxing master may proceed to the second stage described in paragraph (1)(b) without first adjourning the hearing if he is satisfied that the legal representative has already had a reasonable opportunity to give reasons why the taxing master should not make the direction. In other cases the taxing master shall adjourn the hearing before proceeding to the second stage.

subsection.leadIn: On an application for a direction under rule 8D(1), any evidence in support must identify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: what the legal representative is alleged to have done or failed to do; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs that he may be directed to pay or which are sought against him.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Taxed costs, fractional taxed costs or costs summarily assessed for non-interlocutory applications (O. 62, r. 9)

subsection.content: Subject to this Order, where by or under these Rules or any order or direction of the Court costs are to be paid to any person, that person shall be entitled to his taxed costs.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (1) shall not apply to costs which by or under any order or direction of the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are to be paid to a receiver appointed by the Court under section 52B of the Ordinance in respect of his remuneration, disbursements or expenses; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: are to be assessed or settled by a taxing master,

subsection.continued: but rules 28, 28A, 31 and 32 shall apply in relation to the assessment or settlement by a taxing master of costs which are to be assessed or settled as aforesaid as they apply in relation to the taxation of costs by a taxing master.

subsection.content: Where a writ in an action is endorsed in accordance with Order 6, rule 2(b), and judgment is entered on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence for the amount claimed for costs (whether alone or together with any other amount claimed), paragraph (1) of this rule shall not apply to those costs, but if the amount claimed for costs as aforesaid is paid in accordance with the indorsement (or is accepted by the plaintiff as if so paid) the defendant shall nevertheless be entitled to have those costs taxed.

subsection.leadIn: The Court in awarding costs to any person may direct that, instead of taxed costs, that person shall be entitled—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to a sum of money summarily assessed in lieu of taxed costs. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.content: This rule does not apply to costs of an interlocutory application. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s9A
section.heading: Summary assessment of costs of interlocutory application (O. 62, r. 9A)

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has determined an interlocutory application at any stage of proceedings and orders a party to pay costs in respect of the interlocutory application to any other party, it may, if it considers it appropriate to do so but subject to rule 9C—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make a summary assessment of the costs by ordering payment of a sum of money to that other party in lieu of taxed costs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make a summary assessment of the costs by ordering payment of a sum of money to that other party in lieu of taxed costs but subject to the right of either party to have the costs taxed pursuant to paragraph (2); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order that the costs be taxed in accordance with this Order.

subsection.content: Where the Court has made an order under paragraph (1)(b), either party to the interlocutory application is entitled to have the costs in respect of the interlocutory application taxed in accordance with this Order.

subsection.leadIn: Upon taxation pursuant to paragraph (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the amount of the taxed costs in respect of the interlocutory application equals the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b), the taxing master shall direct that no further amount is payable in respect of the taxed costs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the amount of the taxed costs in respect of the interlocutory application exceeds the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b), the taxing master may—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: direct the party against whom the order was made to pay the shortfall; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: set off the shortfall against any other costs to which the party against whom the order was made is entitled and direct payment of any balance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b) exceeds the amount of the taxed costs in respect of the interlocutory application, the taxing master may—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: direct the party in whose favour the order was made to pay the difference; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: set off the difference against any other costs to which the party in whose favour the order was made is entitled and direct payment of any balance.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b) equals or exceeds the amount of the taxed costs in respect of the interlocutory application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the taxed costs in respect of the interlocutory application do not materially exceed the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b),

subsection.continued: the taxing master may make such order as to the costs of the taxation or such other order as he considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether the taxed costs materially exceed the amount paid pursuant to an order made under paragraph (1)(b), the taxing master shall, in addition to any other matter that he may consider relevant, have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
