paragraph.content: the amount by which the taxed costs exceed the amount paid pursuant to the order made under paragraph (1)(b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the exceeded amount is disproportionate to the costs of the taxation.

section.name: s9B
section.heading: Time for complying with direction or order for summary assessment (O. 62, r. 9B)

subsection.leadIn: A party shall comply with a direction or order under rule 9(4)(b) or 9A(1)(a) or (b) for payment of a sum of money—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within 14 days of the date of the direction or order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by such date as the Court may specify.

subsection.content: Paragraph (1) does not apply if the party is an aided person.

section.name: s9C
section.heading: When summary assessment not allowed (O. 62, r. 9C)

subsection.leadIn: No direction or order may be made under rule 9(4)(b) or 9A(1)(a) or (b) for the payment of a sum of money if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the paying party shows substantial grounds for disputing the sum claimed for costs that cannot be dealt with summarily;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the receiving party is an aided person, and the legal representative acting for the receiving party has not waived the right to any further sum of money in respect of the costs of the interlocutory application; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the receiving party is a person under disability as defined in Order 80, rule 1, and the legal representative (or the next friend or guardian ad litem) acting for the person under disability has not waived the right to any further sum of money in respect of the costs of the interlocutory application.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: paying party (支付方) means the party against whom a direction or order under rule 9(4)(b) or 9A(1)(a) or (b) is made;
receiving party (收取方) means the party in whose favour a direction or order under rule 9(4)(b) or 9A(1)(a) or (b) is made.

section.name: s9D
section.heading: When to tax costs (O. 62, r. 9D)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraphs (2) and (4), the costs of any proceedings shall not be taxed until the conclusion of the action.
If it appears to the Court when making a costs order that all or any part of the costs ought to be taxed at an earlier stage it may order accordingly.
No order may be made under paragraph (2) in a case where the person against whom the costs order is made is an aided person.

Where it appears to a taxing master that there is no likelihood of any further order being made in a cause or matter, he may order the person entitled to payment of the costs of any interlocutory proceedings which have taken place to commence taxation proceedings in accordance with rule 21.

section.name: s10
section.heading: When a party may sign judgment for costs without order (O. 62, r. 10)

subsection.content: Where a plaintiff by notice in writing and without leave either wholly discontinues his action against any defendant or withdraws any particular claim made or question raised by him therein as against any defendant, the defendant may tax his costs of the action or his costs occasioned by the matter withdrawn, as the case may be, and, if the taxed costs are not paid within 4 days after taxation, may sign judgment for them. (See Appendix A, Form 50)

In the circumstances mentioned in this rule, Order 22, rules 20 and 21 and Order 25, rule 4(6) an order for costs shall be deemed to have been made to the effect described and, for the purposes of section 50 of the Ordinance, the order shall be deemed to have been entered up on the date on which the event which gave rise to the entitlement to costs occurred. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s11
section.heading: When order for taxation of costs not required (O. 62, r. 11)

subsection.content: Where an action, petition or summons is dismissed with costs, or a motion is refused with costs, or an order of the Court directs the payment of any costs, or any party is entitled under rule 10 to tax his costs, no order directing the taxation of those costs need be made. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Where a summons is taken out to set aside with costs any proceedings on the ground of irregularity and the summons is dismissed but no direction is given as to costs, the summons is to be taken as having been dismissed with costs.

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Commencement of costs-only proceedings (O. 62, r. 11A)

subsection.content: Proceedings under section 53A(2) of the Ordinance may be commenced by originating summons in Form No. 10 in Appendix A.

subsection.leadIn: The originating summons must be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an affidavit exhibiting the agreement referred to in section 53A(1) of the Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff’s bill of costs or statement of costs.

subsection.content: An acknowledgment of service of the originating summons must be in Form No. 15A in Appendix A.
A master may make a summary assessment of or an order for taxation of the costs that are the subject matter of the proceedings commenced in accordance with paragraph (1).
Orders 13A, 22 and 27 and Order 28, rules 1A, 4(3) to (5) and 7 to 9 do not apply in relation to the proceedings commenced in accordance with paragraph (1) unless otherwise directed by the Court.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Powers of taxing masters to tax costs (O. 62, r. 12)
section.leadIn: A taxing master shall have power to tax—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the costs of or incidental to any proceedings in the Court; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs that are the subject matter of the proceedings commenced in accordance with rule 11A(1); and (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other costs the taxation of which is directed by an order of the Court.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Powers of Chief Judicial Clerks to tax costs (O. 62, r. 13)

subsection.content: A Chief Judicial Clerk shall have power to transact all such business and exercise all such authority as under rule 21B of this Order may be transacted and exercised by the taxing master and to issue a certificate for any costs taxed by him.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Paragraph (1) only applies if the amount of the bill of costs does not exceed the sum of $200,000. (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Paragraph (1) shall not be taken as empowering a Chief Judicial Clerk to tax any costs the taxation of which is set down for hearing under rule 21B(4) or 21C(1).
In exercising the powers conferred on him by this Order, a Chief Judicial Clerk shall comply with any directions given to him by a taxing master.

section.name: s13A
section.heading: Taxing master may give directions (O. 62, r. 13A)

subsection.leadIn: A taxing master may give directions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the just and expeditious disposal of the taxation of a bill of costs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for saving the costs of taxation.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of paragraph (1), a taxing master may give directions as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the form and contents of a bill of costs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the filing of papers and vouchers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the manner in which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any objections to a bill of costs may be raised; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any reply to those objections may be made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the steps to be taken or things to be done at any stage of the taxation proceedings.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Supplementary powers of taxing master (O. 62, r. 14)
section.leadIn: A taxing master may, in the discharge of his functions with respect to the taxation of costs—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take an account of any dealing in money made in connection with the payment of the costs being taxed, if the Court so directs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require any party represented jointly with any other party in any proceedings before him to be separately represented;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: examine any witness in those proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: direct the production of any document which may be relevant in connection with those proceedings;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: correct any clerical mistake in any certificate or order, or any error arising therein from any accidental slip or omission.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Disposal of business by one taxing master for another (O. 62, r. 15)

subsection.content: If, apart from this paragraph, a taxing master has power to tax any costs, the taxation of which has been assigned to some other taxing master, he may tax those costs and if, apart from this paragraph, he has power to issue a certificate for the taxed costs he shall issue a certificate for them.
Any taxing master may assist any other taxing master in the taxation of any costs the taxation of which has been assigned to that other officer.

On an application in that behalf made by a party to any cause or matter, a taxing master may, and if the circumstances require it shall, hear and dispose of any application in the cause or matter on behalf of the taxing master by whom the application would otherwise be heard.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Extension, etc., of time (O. 62, r. 16)

subsection.leadIn: A taxing master may—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: where no period is specified by or under this Order or by the Court for the doing of anything in or in connection with such proceedings, specify the period within which the thing is to be done.

subsection.content: Where an order of the Court specifies a period within which anything is to be done by or before a taxing master, then unless the Court otherwise directs, the taxing master may from time to time extend the period so specified on such terms (if any) as he thinks just.
A taxing master may extend any such period as is referred to in the foregoing provisions of this rule although the application for extension is not made until after the expiration of that period.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Interim certificates (O. 62, r. 17)
section.content: A taxing master may from time to time in the course of the taxation of any costs by him issue an interim certificate for any part of those costs which has been taxed.

section.name: s17A
section.heading: Final certificate (O. 62, r. 17A)

subsection.content: A taxing master shall, after the conclusion of taxation proceedings before him, issue a final certificate specifying the amount of taxed costs and the amount of money payable under rule 32B.
A taxing master shall not issue a final certificate unless the period within which an application for review of his decision may be made under rule 33(2) has expired.
A taxing master may set aside a final certificate for good reasons and on such terms as he thinks fit.

section.name: s17B
section.heading: Taxing master may set aside his own decision (O. 62, r. 17B)
section.content: If a party entitled to be heard on taxation fails to raise any objection to a bill of costs or to appear at a hearing set down under rule 21B(4) or 21C(1), a decision of a taxing master made against that party may be set aside or varied by the taxing master for good reasons and on such terms as he thinks fit.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Power of taxing master where party liable to be paid and to pay costs (O. 62, r. 18)
section.leadIn: Where a party entitled to be paid costs is also liable to pay costs, the taxing master may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: tax the costs which that party is liable to pay and set off the amount allowed against the amount he is entitled to be paid and direct payment of any balance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: delay the issue of a certificate for the costs he is entitled to be paid until he has paid or tendered the amount he is liable to pay.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Taxation of bill of costs comprised in account (O. 62, r. 19)

subsection.content: Where the Court directs an account to be taken and the account consists in part of a bill of costs, the Court may direct a taxing master to tax those costs and the taxing master shall tax the costs in accordance with the direction and shall return the bill of costs, after taxation thereof, together with his report thereon to the Court.

A taxing master taxing a bill of costs in accordance with a direction under this rule shall have the same powers, and the same fees shall be payable in connection with the taxation, as if an order for taxation of the costs had been made by the Court.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Mode of commencing proceedings for taxation (O. 62, r. 21)

subsection.leadIn: A party entitled to payment of the costs of any action to be taxed may commence proceedings for the taxation of those costs by filing in the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a notice of commencement of taxation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: his bill of costs.

subsection.content: The party shall serve a copy of the notice of commencement of taxation and of the bill of costs on every other party entitled to be heard on taxation within 7 days after the notice and the bill of costs were filed in the Court.

The Court may give directions as to the service of a copy of the notice of commencement of taxation and of the bill of costs on any other person who may have a financial interest in the outcome of the taxation.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), it is not necessary for a copy of the notice of commencement of taxation or of the bill of costs to be served on any party who has not acknowledged service in the proceedings which gave rise to the taxation.
A party shall, when he files a notice of commencement of taxation, pay to the Court a prescribed taxing fee.

subsection.leadIn: A person who has been served with a copy of the notice of commencement of taxation and of the bill of costs pursuant to paragraph (3) shall, within 7 days of the service, give notice in writing to the taxing master and all other parties entitled to be heard on taxation, stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his financial interest in the outcome of the taxation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether he intends to take part in the taxation proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: A person who fails to comply with paragraph (6) is not entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receive from the Registrar or from any other party entitled to be heard on taxation any notice, application or other document relating to the taxation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take part in the taxation proceedings.

section.name: s21A
section.heading: Application for taxation to be set down (O. 62, r. 21A)

subsection.content: Upon compliance with the directions given by a taxing master under rule 13A relating to the steps to be taken or things to be done before the taxation is set down, the party who has commenced taxation proceedings under rule 21 may apply to the taxing master for setting down the taxation.
The party shall, within 7 days after making an application under paragraph (1), serve a copy of the application on every other party entitled to be heard on taxation.
A taxing master may refuse to proceed with taxation if he is of the opinion that any direction referred to in paragraph (1) has not been complied with.

section.name: s21B
section.heading: Provisional taxation (O. 62, r. 21B)

subsection.leadIn: Unless the taxation is set down for hearing under rule 21C(1), the taxing master may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: tax the bill of costs without a hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: make an order nisi as to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the amount which he allows in respect of the whole or part of the bill of costs; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the costs of the taxation.

subsection.content: Where the taxing master has taxed the bill of costs without a hearing and made an order nisi under paragraph (1), the party who has applied for setting down the taxation under rule 21A(1) shall serve a copy of the order nisi on every other party entitled to be heard on taxation.
The order nisi becomes absolute 14 days after it is made unless a party entitled to be heard on taxation applies to the taxing master within the 14-day period for a hearing.

The taxing master shall set down the taxation for hearing upon application made by a party under paragraph (3) and that party shall serve a notice of the hearing on every other party entitled to be heard on taxation.
The taxing master may order that party to pay any costs of the hearing if the taxed costs do not materially exceed the amount allowed under paragraph (1)(b)(i).

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether the taxed costs materially exceed the amount allowed under paragraph (1)(b)(i), the taxing master shall, in addition to any other matter that he may consider relevant, have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount by which the costs taxed at the hearing exceed the amount allowed under paragraph (1)(b)(i); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the exceeded amount is disproportionate to the costs of the hearing.

section.name: s21C
section.heading: Taxation with a hearing (O. 62, r. 21C)

subsection.content: Where the taxing master is satisfied that there is a good reason to do so, he may, either of his own motion or on application by a party entitled to be heard on taxation, set down for hearing the taxation of the whole or part of the bill of costs.

Upon notification by the taxing master of the date of hearing, the party who applied for setting down shall serve a notice of the hearing on every other party entitled to be heard on taxation within 7 days after the notification.

section.name: s21D
section.heading: Withdrawal of bill of costs (O. 62, r. 21D)

subsection.content: A party who has filed a bill of costs shall pay the prescribed fee to the Court if he withdraws the bill of costs within 7 days after his application to the taxing master for setting down the taxation under rule 21A(1) is made.
The Court shall deduct the fee payable under paragraph (1) from the amount paid under rule 21(5) and refund the balance to the party.

subsection.leadIn: The party is not entitled to any refund of the balance of the amount paid under rule 21(5) except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under paragraph (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the Court otherwise directs.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Delay in service of notice of commencement of taxation or in proceeding with taxation (O. 62, r. 22)

subsection.leadIn: If, within 3 months after the completion date, the person entitled to payment of costs has neither—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: agreed the amount of those costs with the person liable to pay them; nor

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: served upon such person a copy of a notice of commencement of taxation in accordance with rule 21(2),

subsection.continued: the taxing master, on the application of the person liable to pay such costs and on not less than 7 days’ notice to the person entitled to payment of those costs, may make an order under paragraph (3).

subsection.leadIn: If, after the proceedings for the taxation of a bill of costs have commenced in accordance with rule 21(1), the person entitled to payment of costs has neither—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: agreed the amount of those costs with the person liable to pay them; nor

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceeded with the taxation,

subsection.continued: the taxing master, on the application of the person liable to pay such costs and on not less than 7 days’ notice to the person entitled to payment of those costs, may make an order under paragraph (3).

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may order that the person entitled to payment of the costs must commence taxation proceedings in accordance with rule 21 or proceed with the taxation, within such period as may be specified in the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may further order that that person shall not be entitled to commence those taxation proceedings or proceed with the taxation unless the person does commence those taxation proceedings or proceed with the taxation within the specified period or such extended period as may be allowed by the taxing master.

subsection.content: The taxing master may make an order under paragraph (3) subject to such conditions as he thinks fit, including a condition that the person liable to pay the costs to be taxed shall pay a sum of money into court.

subsection.leadIn: On the taxation of a bill of costs, whether or not an order has been made under paragraph (3), the taxing master, if he is satisfied that there has been undue delay in commencing taxation proceedings or in proceeding with the taxation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make such order as he thinks fit as to the costs of any application or as to the costs of the taxation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may disallow any part of the costs to be taxed pursuant to the costs order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may, in relation to the taxed costs or any part of those costs, disallow interest or reduce the period for which interest is payable or the rate at which interest is payable.

subsection.leadIn: Where a party entitled to payment of costs fails to proceed with taxation after filing the notice of commencement of taxation under rule 21(1), the taxing master in order to prevent any other parties being prejudiced by that failure, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allow the party so entitled a nominal or other sum for costs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: certify the failure and the costs of the other parties.

subsection.leadIn: A party is not entitled to commence taxation proceedings under rule 21—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the expiry of 2 years from the completion date; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the Court has extended the period specified in subparagraph (a), after the expiry of the period as extended,

subsection.continued: whichever is the later.

subsection.content: Where the completion date is before the commencement* of this rule, paragraph (7)(a) has effect as if for the words “completion date”, there were substituted the words “commencement of this rule”.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule, completion date (完結日期) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the judgment or order of the Court which disposes of the action;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the date on which the taxing master orders under rule 9D(4) the person entitled to payment of the costs of any interlocutory proceedings in the Court to commence taxation proceedings; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where the person entitled to payment of costs is entitled to tax those costs without an order of the Court directing the taxation of them, the date on which he becomes entitled to tax those costs,

subsection.continued: whichever is the later.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Taxation (O. 62, r. 24)

subsection.content: The taxing master may proceed to taxation of a bill of costs under rule 21B(1) notwithstanding that a party entitled to be heard on taxation has failed to comply with any direction given by him relating to the steps to be taken or things to be done before the taxation proceeds under rule 21B, if the taxing master is satisfied that a copy of the notice of commencement of taxation and of the bill of costs were duly served in accordance with rule 21(2) on the party.

If, at the date and time of a hearing under rule 21B(4) or 21C(2), a party entitled to be heard on taxation does not appear before the taxing master in person or by his representative, the taxing master may proceed to taxation of the bill of costs in the absence of the party or of his representative, if the taxing master is satisfied that the party has been served with a notice of the hearing in accordance with rule 21B(4) or 21C(2), or has been otherwise informed of the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: If the taxing master is not so satisfied, he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must adjourn the hearing for such period as he may consider necessary to enable service of the notice of the adjourned hearing or of the bill of costs or both to be effected on the party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may make such order as he may consider appropriate in relation to costs thrown away by the adjournment.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Power to adjourn (O. 62, r. 26)

subsection.content: The taxing master by whom any taxation proceedings are being conducted may, if he thinks it necessary to do so, adjourn those proceedings from time to time. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

If the taxation proceedings are adjourned because a party has failed to comply with any directions given under rule 13A, the taxing master may make such order as he may consider appropriate in relation to costs thrown away by the adjournment. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s27
section.heading: Powers of taxing master taxing costs payable out of fund (O. 62, r. 27)

subsection.content: Where any costs are to be paid out of a fund the taxing master may give directions as to the parties who are entitled to attend on the taxation of those costs and may disallow the costs of attendance of any party not entitled to attend by virtue of the directions and whose attendance he considers unnecessary.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Court has directed that a bill of costs be taxed for the purpose of being paid out of a fund the taxing master by whom the bill is being taxed may, if he thinks fit, adjourn the taxation for a reasonable period and direct the party whose bill it is to send to any person having an interest in the fund a copy of the bill, or of any part thereof, free of charge together with a letter containing the following information, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the name of the taxing master and the address of the office at which the taxation is proceeding;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the time appointed by the taxing master at which the taxation will be continued; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such other information, if any, as the taxing master may direct.

section.crossHeading: Bases and Scales for Taxation and Assessment of Costs

section.name: s28
section.heading: Costs payable to one party by another or out of fund (O. 62, r. 28)

subsection.content: This rule applies to costs which by or under these Rules or any order or direction of the Court are to be paid to a party to any proceedings either by another party to those proceedings or out of any fund (other than a fund which the party to whom the costs are to be paid holds as trustee or personal representative).

Subject to the following provisions of this rule, costs to which this rule applies shall be taxed on the party and party basis, and on a taxation on that basis there shall be allowed all such costs as were necessary or proper for the attainment of justice or for enforcing or defending the rights of the party whose costs are being taxed.

The Court in awarding costs to which this rule applies may in any case in which it thinks fit to do so order or direct that the costs shall be taxed on the common fund basis or on the indemnity basis.

On a taxation on the common fund basis, being a more generous basis than that provided for by paragraph (2), there shall be allowed a reasonable amount in respect of all costs reasonably incurred, and paragraph (2) shall not apply; and accordingly in all cases where costs are to be taxed on the common fund basis the ordinary rules applicable on a taxation as between solicitor and client where the costs are to be paid out of a common fund in which the client and others are interested shall be applied, whether or not the costs are in fact to be so paid.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.def: On a taxation on the indemnity basis all costs shall be allowed except in so far as they are of an unreasonable amount or have been unreasonably incurred and any doubts which the taxing master may have as to whether the costs were reasonably incurred or were reasonable in amount shall be resolved in favour of the receiving party; and in these Rules the term the indemnity basis (彌償基準) in relation to the taxation of costs shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: The Court in awarding costs to which this rule applies to any person may if it thinks fit and if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the costs are to be paid out of a fund; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person to whom the costs are to be paid is or was a party to the proceedings in the capacity of trustee or personal representative,

subsection.continued: order or direct that the costs shall be taxed as if that person were a trustee of the fund or as if the costs were to be paid out of a fund held by that person, as the case may be, and where the Court so orders or directs rule 31(2) shall have effect in relation to the taxation in substitution for paragraph (2).

section.name: s28A
section.heading: Costs of a litigant in person (O. 62, r. 28A)

subsection.content: On a taxation of the costs of a litigant in person there may, subject to the provisions of this rule, be allowed such costs as would have been allowed if the work and disbursements to which the costs relate had been done or made by a solicitor on the litigant’s behalf.

The amount allowed in respect of any item shall be such sum as the taxing master thinks fit not exceeding, except in the case of a disbursement, two thirds of the sum which in the opinion of the taxing master would have been allowed in respect of that item if the litigant had been represented by a solicitor.

Where in the opinion of the taxing master the litigant has not suffered any pecuniary loss in doing any work to which the costs relate, he shall not be allowed in respect of the time reasonably spent by him on the work more than $200 an hour.
A litigant who is allowed costs in respect of attending Court to conduct his own case shall not be entitled to a witness allowance in addition.
Nothing in Order 6, rule 2(b), or rule 32(4) of this Order or Schedule 2 to this Order shall, unless otherwise specified therein, apply to the costs of a litigant in person. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

For the purposes of this rule a litigant in person does not include a litigant who is a practising solicitor but includes a company or other corporation which is acting without a legal representative. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

This rule applies, with the necessary modifications, to a summary assessment under rules 9(4)(b), 9A(1)(a) and (b) and 11A(4), as it applies to the taxation of the costs of a litigant in person, if the party entitled to the sum is a litigant in person. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s30
section.heading: Costs payable to solicitor where money recovered by or on behalf of infant, etc. (O. 62, r. 30)
section.leadIn: Order 62, rule 30 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) shall, where appropriate, apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings in which money is claimed or recovered by or on behalf of, or adjudged or ordered or agreed to be paid to, or for the benefit of, a person who is a minor or a mentally disordered person within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136) or in which money paid into court is accepted by or on behalf of such a person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceedings under the Fatal Accidents Ordinance (Cap. 22), in which money is recovered by or on behalf of, or adjudged or ordered or agreed to be paid to, or for the benefit of, the widow of the person whose death gave rise to the proceedings in satisfaction of a claim under the said Ordinance or in which money paid into court is accepted by her or on her behalf in satisfaction of such a claim, if the proceedings were for the benefit also of a person who, when the money is recovered, or adjudged or ordered or agreed to be paid, or accepted, is a minor.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Costs payable to a trustee out of trust funds, etc. (O. 62, r. 31)

subsection.content: This rule applies to every taxation of the costs which a person who is or has been a party to any proceedings in the capacity of trustee or personal representative is entitled to be paid out of any fund which he holds in that capacity.

On any taxation to which this rule applies, no costs shall be disallowed except in so far as those costs or any part of their amount should not, in accordance with the duty of the trustee or personal representative as such, have been incurred or paid, and should for that reason be borne by him personally.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Scales of costs (O. 62, r. 32)

subsection.content: Subject to the foregoing rules and the following provisions of this rule, the scale of costs contained in Schedule 1 to this Order, together with the notes and general provisions contained in that Schedule, shall apply to the taxation of all costs incurred in relation to contentious business done after the commencement of these Rules.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Court shall not, on taxation, allow as costs under items 5 and 6 of Schedule 1 to this Order an amount which exceeds two thirds of the amount which it would have allowed in respect of such items had the taxation been carried out by it in accordance with the scale applicable to a taxation of costs in the High Court.

subsection.leadIn: On a taxation in relation to which rule 31(2) has effect and in other special cases costs may at the discretion of the taxing master be allowed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to items not mentioned in the said scale; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of an amount higher than that prescribed by the said scale.

subsection.content: Where the amount of a solicitor’s remuneration in respect of non-contentious business connected with sales, purchases, leases, mortgages and other matters of conveyancing or in respect of any other non-contentious business is regulated, in the absence of agreement to the contrary, by any rules for the time being in force under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159), the amount of the costs to be allowed on taxation in respect of the like contentious business shall be the same, notwithstanding anything in the scale contained in Schedule 1 to this Order.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1), costs shall, unless the Court otherwise orders, be allowed in the cases to which Schedule 2 to this Order applies in accordance with the provisions of that Schedule.

section.name: s32A
section.heading: Liability for costs of taxation (O. 62, r. 32A)

subsection.leadIn: A party entitled to payment of any costs to be taxed is also entitled to his costs of the taxation except where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any Ordinance, any of these Rules or any relevant practice direction provides otherwise; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court makes some other order in relation to all or part of the costs of the taxation.

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether to make some other order, the Court shall have regard to the underlying objectives set out in Order 1A, rule 1 and all the circumstances, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the conduct of all the parties in relation to the taxation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount, if any, by which the bill of costs has been reduced; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether it was reasonable for a party to claim the costs of a particular item or to dispute that item.

section.name: s32B
section.heading: Reimbursement for taxing fees (O. 62, r. 32B)
section.content: Upon the issue of a final certificate under rule 17A, the party liable to pay costs shall pay to the party entitled to payment of the costs an amount of money equivalent to the prescribed taxing fee calculated on the basis of the amount of costs allowed.

section.name: s32C
section.heading: Court’s powers in relation to misconduct (O. 62, r. 32C)

subsection.leadIn: The Court may make an order under this rule where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party or his legal representative, in connection with a summary assessment or taxation of costs, fails to comply with a rule, practice direction or an order of the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the Court that the conduct of a party or his legal representative, before or during the proceedings which gave rise to the summary assessment or taxation, was unreasonable or improper.

subsection.content: For the purpose of paragraph (1), the conduct of a party or his legal representative does not include any conduct before the commencement of the action.

subsection.leadIn: Where paragraph (1) applies, the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by order disallow all or part of the costs being summarily assessed or taxed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order the party at fault or his legal representative, to pay costs that he has caused any other party to incur.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court makes an order under paragraph (3) against a legally represented party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the party is not present when the order is made,

subsection.continued: the party’s solicitor shall notify his client in writing of the order not later than 7 days after the solicitor receives notice of the order and shall inform the Court in writing that he has done so.

subsection.def: In this rule, client (當事人) includes a person on whose behalf the solicitor acts and any other person who has instructed the solicitor to act or who is liable to pay the solicitor’s costs.

section.name: s32D
section.heading: Costs for witnesses (O. 62, r. 32D)
section.text: There may be allowed on taxation in respect of the attendance of witnesses such reasonable amounts as the taxing master thinks fit.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Application to taxing master for review (O. 62, r. 33)

subsection.leadIn: Any party to any taxation proceedings who is dissatisfied with the allowance or disallowance in whole or in part of any item by a taxing master, or with the amount allowed by a taxing master in respect of any item— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may apply to the taxing master to review his decision in respect of that item; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may not apply to a judge for an order to review the decision until after its review by the taxing master. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

content.leadIn: An application under this rule for review of a taxing master’s decision in respect of any item may be made at any time within 14 days after the conclusion of the taxation in which that decision was made or such shorter period as may be fixed by the taxing master:
content.proviso: Provided that no application under this rule for review of a decision in respect of any item may be made after the signing of the taxing master’s final certificate dealing with that item. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

subsection.content: Every applicant for review under this rule must at the time of making his application deliver to the taxing master objections in writing specifying by a list the items or parts of items the allowance or disallowance of which or the amount allowed in respect of which, is objected to and stating concisely the nature and grounds of the objection in each case, and must deliver a copy of the objections to each other party (if any) who attended on the taxation of those items or to whom the taxing master directs that a copy of the objections shall be delivered.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: If an applicant fails to comply with paragraph (3), the taxing master may dismiss the application. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Any party to whom a copy of the objections is delivered under this rule may, within 14 days after delivery of the copy to him or such shorter period as may be fixed by the taxing master, deliver to the taxing master answers in writing to the objections stating concisely the grounds on which he will oppose the objections, and shall at the same time deliver a copy of the answers to the party applying for review and to each other party (if any) to whom a copy of the objections has been delivered or to whom the taxing master directs that a copy of the answers shall be delivered.

An application under this rule for review of the taxing master’s decision in respect of any item shall not prejudice the power of the taxing master under rule 17 to issue an interim certificate in respect of items his decision as to which is not objected to.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Review by taxing master (O. 62, r. 34)

subsection.content: A review under rule 33 shall be carried out by the taxing master to whom the taxation was originally assigned.

On reviewing any decision in respect of any item, a taxing master may receive further evidence and may exercise all the powers which he might exercise on an original taxation in respect of that item, including the power to award costs of and incidental to the proceedings before him; and any costs awarded by him to any party may be taxed by him and may be added to or deducted from any other sum payable to or by that party in respect of costs.

On a hearing of a review under rule 33 a party to whom a copy of objections was delivered under paragraph (4) of that rule shall be entitled to be heard in respect of any item to which the objections relate notwithstanding that he did not deliver written answers to the objections under that paragraph.

A taxing master who has reviewed a decision in respect of any item shall issue his certificate accordingly and, if requested to do so by any party to the proceedings before him, shall state in his certificate or otherwise in writing by reference to the objections to that decision the reasons for his decision on the review, and any special facts or circumstances relevant to it. A request under this paragraph must be made within 14 days after the review or such shorter period as may be fixed by the taxing master.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Review of taxing master’s certificate by judge (O. 62, r. 35)

subsection.content: Any party who is dissatisfied with the decision of a taxing master to allow or to disallow in whole or in part of any item on review under rule 34, or with the amount allowed by a taxing master in respect of any item on any such review, may apply to a judge for an order to review the taxation as to that item or part of an item if, but only if, one of the parties to the proceedings before the taxing master requested him in accordance with rule 34(4) to state the reasons for his decision in respect of that item or part of an item on the review.

An application under this rule for review of a taxing master’s decision in respect of any item may be made at any time within 14 days after the taxing master’s certificate in respect of that item is signed, or such longer time as the taxing master at the time when he signs the certificate, or the Court at any time, may allow.
An application under this rule shall be made by summons and shall, except where the judge thinks fit to adjourn into court, be heard in chambers.

Unless the judge otherwise directs, no further evidence shall be received on the hearing of an application under this rule, and no ground of objection shall be raised which was not raised on the review by the taxing master but, save as aforesaid, on the hearing of any such application the judge may exercise all such powers and discretion as are vested in the taxing master in relation to the subject-matter of the application.

If the judge thinks fit to exercise in relation to an application under this rule the power of the Court to call assessors under section 58 of the Ordinance, the judge shall call not less than 2 assessors, of whom one shall be a taxing master.

On an application under this rule the judge may make such order as the circumstances require, and in particular may order the taxing master’s certificate to be amended or, except where the dispute as to the item under review is as to amount only, order the item to be remitted to the same or another taxing master for taxation.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Transitional provision relating to Part 14 of Amendment Rules 2008 (O. 62, r. 36)
section.content: Rules 8, 8A, 8B, 8C, 8D and 8E do not apply in relation to any costs incurred before the commencement* of the Amendment Rules 2008, and rule 8 as in force immediately before the commencement continues to apply in relation to those costs as if Part 14 had not been made.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Transitional provisions relating to Part 21 of Amendment Rules 2008 (O. 62, r. 37)

subsection.content: Where a party entitled to require any costs to be taxed has filed his bill of costs before the commencement* of the Amendment Rules 2008, nothing in Part 21 of the Amendment Rules 2008 applies in relation to the taxation, and Order 62 as in force immediately before the commencement applies in relation to the taxation as if it had not been amended by that Part.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any item of work to which the costs or charges specified in Schedule 1 or Part III of Schedule 2 of this Order relate was undertaken before the commencement,

subsection.continued: then Schedule 1 or Part III of Schedule 2 of this Order as in force immediately before the commencement applies in relation to that item of work as if it had not been amended by Part 21 of the Amendment Rules 2008.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the writ of summons was issued before the commencement,

subsection.continued: then Part I and Part II of Schedule 2 of this Order as in force immediately before the commencement applies in relation to the writ of summons issued before the commencement as if they had not been amended by Part 21 of the Amendment Rules 2008.

subsection.content: No costs for work undertaken before the commencement of the Amendment Rules 2008 are to be disallowed if those costs would have been allowed under this Order as in force immediately before the commencement.

td.p: Preparation of a bundle of copies of documents, including the costs of copying and collating the documents and compiling (including indexing and pagination) the bundle, per page of whatever size (L.N. 153 of 2008)
$4 per page in respect of the first bundle, and $1 per page in respect of each subsequent bundle
Copying of documents, per page of whatever size (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Attendance suitable for unqualified staff, such as for filing of documents, delivery or collection of papers and to make appointments, whether such attendances are made by qualified or unqualified persons, for each attendance (L.N. 153 of 2008)
Attendance for necessary search and inquiries-such fee as the Registrar thinks proper but not less than $25 for each attendance
Service of any documents-such fee as the Registrar thinks proper but not less than $25 in each case
The Registrar may allow such fee as he thinks proper in respect of every other matter or thing not hereinbefore specially mentioned
Note to item 5: This item is intended to cover—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the doing of any work not otherwise provided for and which was properly done in preparing for a trial, hearing or appeal, or before a settlement of the matters in dispute, including—

tr.td: (ii)

td.p: witnesses: interviewing and corresponding with witnesses and potential witnesses, taking and preparing proofs of evidence and, where appropriate, arranging attendance at Court, including issue of subpoena;

tr.td: (iii)

td.p: expert evidence: obtaining and considering reports or advice from experts and plans, photographs and models; where appropriate arranging their attendance at Court, including issue of subpoena;

tr.td: (iv)

td.p: inspections: inspecting any property or place material to the proceedings;
searches and inquiries: making searches in Government registries and elsewhere for relevant documents;

tr.td: (vi)

td.p: special damages: obtaining details of special damages and making or obtaining any relevant calculations;

tr.td: (vii)

td.p: other parties: attending upon and corresponding with other parties or their solicitors;

tr.td: (viii)

td.p: discovery: perusing, considering or collating documents for affidavit or list of documents; attending to inspect or produce for inspection any documents required to be produced or inspected by order of the Court or by virtue of Order 24; (L.N. 153 of 2008)

tr.td: (ix)

td.p: documents: drafting, perusing, considering and collating any relevant documents (including pleadings, affidavits, cases and instructions to and advice from counsel, orders and judgments) and any law involved;
negotiations: work done in connection with negotiations with a view to settlement;

tr.td: (xi)

td.p: attendances: attendances at Court (whether in court or chambers) for the hearing of any summons or other application, on examination of any witness, on the trial or hearing of a cause or matter, on any appeal and on delivery of any judgment; attendances on counsel in conference, and any other necessary attendances;

tr.td: (xii)

td.p: interest: where relevant the calculation of interest on damages; and

tr.td: (xiii)

td.p: notices: preparation and service of miscellaneous notices, including notices to witnesses to attend Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the general care and conduct of the proceedings.

td.p: Taxation of costs—obtaining the appointment, preparing bill of costs and copies and attending to lodge; attending taxation, paying taxing fee and lodging certificate or order

section.name: s1
section.heading: Discretionary costs

subsection.leadIn: In exercising his discretion in relation to any item, the taxing master shall have regard to all relevant circumstances, and in particular to—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the skill, specialized knowledge and responsibility required of, and the time and labour expended by, the solicitor or counsel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number and importance of the documents (however brief) prepared or perused;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the place and circumstances in which the business involved is transacted;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the importance of the cause or matter to the client;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: where money or property is involved, its amount or value;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any other fees and allowances payable to the solicitor or counsel in respect of other items in the same cause or matter, but only where work done in relation to those items has reduced the work which would otherwise have been necessary in relation to the item in question.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Fees to counsel

subsection.leadIn: Except in the case of taxation under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) and taxation of fees payable by the Government, no fee to counsel shall be allowed unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before taxation its amount has been agreed by the solicitor instructing counsel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: before the taxing master issues his certificate a receipt for the fees signed by counsel is produced to him.

subsection.content: No retaining fee to counsel shall be allowed on any taxation of costs in relation to which rule 28(2) has effect.

subsection.leadIn: No costs shall be allowed in respect of counsel appearing before the Court unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a plaintiff, the amount recovered exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a defendant, the amount claimed by the plaintiff exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party making a counterclaim, the amount recovered exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party against whom a counterclaim is made, the amount of the counterclaim exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party to third party proceedings who issues the third party notice, the amount recovered exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party to third party proceedings against whom the third party notice is issued, the amount claimed in the third party notice exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party to proceedings on a notice issued by that party under Order 16, rule 8, the amount recovered exceeds $150,000; (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: where counsel appears for a party to proceedings on a notice issued against that party under Order 16, rule 8, the amount claimed in the notice exceeds $150,000; or (L.N. 94 of 2004)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the Court has certified the attendance of counsel as being proper in the circumstances of the case. (L.N. 94 of 2004)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Where a party appearing by counsel is awarded costs, but the costs of employing counsel are not allowed, the taxing master may, on taxation, allow such costs as may have been allowed if the party had appeared by a solicitor and not by counsel.

A refresher fee, the amount of which shall be in the discretion of the taxing master, shall be allowed to counsel, either for each period of 5 hours (or part thereof), after the first, during which a trial or hearing is proceeding or, at the discretion of the taxing master, in respect of any day, after the first day, on which the attendance of counsel at the place of trial is necessary.

The amount of fees to be allowed to counsel is in the discretion of the taxing master who shall, in exercising his discretion, have regard to all relevant circumstances and in particular to the matters set out in paragraph 1(2). (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s4
section.heading: Items to be authorized, certified, etc.

subsection.leadIn: In an action arising out of an accident on land due to a collision or apprehended collision, the costs of preparing a plan (other than a sketch plan) of the place where the accident happened shall not be allowed unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the trial the Court authorized the preparation of the plan; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notwithstanding the absence of an authorization under subparagraph (a) the taxing master is satisfied that it was reasonable to prepare the plan for use at the trial.

subsection.content: The costs of calling an expert witness with regard to any question as to which a Court expert is appointed under Order 40 shall not be allowed on a taxation of costs in relation to which rule 28(2) or (3) has effect unless the Court at the trial has certified that the calling of the witness was reasonable.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Attendances in chambers—equity jurisdiction

subsection.content: The following provisions of this paragraph apply in relation to every hearing in chambers in the equity jurisdiction of the Court.

Where on any such hearing as aforesaid the Court certifies that the speedy and satisfactory disposal of the proceedings required and received from the solicitor engaged in them exceptional skill and labour in the preparation for the hearing, the taxing master in taxing the costs to be allowed for instructions in relation to the summons or application shall take the certificate into account.

part.name: PI
part.heading: Costs on Judgment without Trial for Liquidated Sum or Under Order 13A

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: The scale of costs set out in Part II of this Schedule applies in relation to the following cases if the writ of summons therein was issued after the commencement* of the Amendment Rules 2008 and was indorsed with a claim for a debt or liquidated demand only, that is to say—

subsection.name: a
subsection.content: cases in which the defendant pays the amount claimed within the time and in the manner required by the indorsement of the writ;

subsection.name: b
subsection.leadIn: cases in which the plaintiff obtains—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend under Order 13, rule 1; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: judgment in default of defence under Order 19, rule 2.

section.name: s2
section.content: The scale of costs set out in Part II of this Schedule applies in relation to cases in which the plaintiff obtains judgment under Order 13A without a hearing.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in paragraph 1 or 2 of this Schedule or in the scale of costs set out in Part II of this Schedule, no costs shall be allowed in any case to which paragraph 1 or 2 of this Schedule applies unless—

subsection.name: a
subsection.content: the Court orders costs to be allowed; or

subsection.name: b
subsection.leadIn: in a case to which subparagraph (b) of paragraph 1 of this Schedule applies, judgment or an order for judgment, as the case may be, is obtained—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: within 28 days after the service of the writ; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: within such further time as the Court may allow.

section.name: s4
section.content: In a case to which the scale of costs set out in Part II of this Schedule applies, there shall be added to the basic costs set out in the scale the fee which would have been payable on the issue of a writ for the amount recovered.

td.p: To be allowed in cases under—
6,000 if the plaintiff is legally represented and 350 if the plaintiff is not legally represented
6,500 if the plaintiff is legally represented and 300 if the plaintiff is not legally represented
6,500 if the plaintiff is legally represented and 300 if the plaintiff is not legally represented

paragraph.content: For each additional defendant after the first
Where substituted service is ordered and effected, for each defendant served
Where a plaintiff or defendant signs judgment for costs under rule 10, there shall be allowed cost of the judgment

Where upon the application of any person who has obtained a judgment or order against a debtor for the recovery or payment of money, a garnishee order is made under Order 49 against a garnishee attaching debts owing by or accruing from him to the debtor, the following costs shall be allowed to the garnishee, to be deducted by him from any debt owing by or accruing from him to the debtor before payments to the applicant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if no affidavit used

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if affidavit used
Where a writ of execution within the meaning of Order 46, rule 1 is issued against any party, there shall be allowed cost of issuing execution

section.name: s62A
section.heading: Costs Offer and Payments into Court

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation and application (O. 62A, r. 1)
section.leadIn: (1) In this Order—

def.name: CostsOffer
def.leadIn: costs offer (訟費提議) means an offer to settle—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party’s entitlement to costs that are the subject of a taxation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs of the taxation;

section.def: offeree (受提議者) means the party to whom a costs offer is made;
offeror (提議者) means the party who makes a costs offer;
paying party (支付方) means the party liable to pay costs;
receiving party (收取方), in relation to a paying party, means the party who is entitled to payment of costs from that paying party;

def.name: RelevantDate
def.leadIn: relevant date (有關日期), in relation to a taxation, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the bill of costs is taxed under Order 62, rule 21B(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date set down under Order 62, rule 21C(1) for hearing the taxation;

section.def: sanctioned offer (附帶條款和解提議) means a costs offer made (otherwise than by way of a payment into court) in accordance with this Order;
sanctioned payment (附帶條款付款) means a costs offer made by way of a payment into court in accordance with this Order;
sanctioned payment notice (附帶條款付款通知書) means the notice relating to a sanctioned payment required to be filed under rule 8(2).

subsection.content: This Order does not apply to or in relation to a party who is or has been an aided person in the relevant proceedings.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Offer to settle with specified consequences (O. 62A, r. 2)

subsection.content: Any party to a taxation may make a costs offer in accordance with this Order.
An offer made under paragraph (1) has the consequences specified in rules 18, 19 and 20 (as may be applicable).

Nothing in this Order prevents a party from making a costs offer in whatever way he chooses, but if that costs offer is not made in accordance with this Order, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order, unless the Court so orders.

section.crossHeading: II. Manner of Making Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s3
section.heading: Paying party’s costs offer requires sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 3)

subsection.content: A costs offer by a paying party does not have the consequences specified in this Order unless it is made by way of a sanctioned payment.
A sanctioned payment may be made at any time before the relevant date.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Receiving party’s costs offer requires sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 4)
section.content: A costs offer by a receiving party does not have the consequences specified in this Order unless it is made by way of a sanctioned offer.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Form and content of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 5)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer must be in writing.
A sanctioned offer may relate to the whole or part of the costs.
A sanctioned offer must state whether it relates to the whole or part of the costs, and if it relates to part of the costs, to which part does it relate.
A sanctioned offer may be made at any time before the relevant date.

subsection.leadIn: A sanctioned offer must provide that after the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned offer is made, the offeree may only accept it if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court grants leave to accept it.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Service of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 6)
section.content: A receiving party who makes a sanctioned offer shall serve the sanctioned offer on the paying party.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Withdrawal or diminution of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 7)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer may not be withdrawn or diminished before the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned offer is made unless the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer, the sanctioned offer may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned offer, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned offer or diminished sanctioned offer may be accepted.
If a sanctioned offer is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Notice of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 8)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may relate to the whole or part of the costs.

subsection.leadIn: A paying party who makes a sanctioned payment shall file with the Court a notice in Form No. 93 in Appendix A, that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the amount of the payment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states whether the payment relates to the whole or part of the costs, and if it relates to part of the costs, to which part it relates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if an interim payment of costs has been made, states that the paying party has taken into account the interim payment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if it is expressed not to be inclusive of interest, states—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether interest is offered; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if so, the amount offered, the rate or rates offered and the period or periods for which it is offered; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if a sum of money has been paid into court as security for the costs of the action, cause or matter, states whether the sanctioned payment has taken into account that sum of money.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Service of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 9)
section.leadIn: A paying party who makes a sanctioned payment shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: serve the sanctioned payment notice on the receiving party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: file with the Court a certificate of service of the notice.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Withdrawal or diminution of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 10)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may not be withdrawn or diminished before the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned payment is made unless the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment, the sanctioned payment may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned payment, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned payment or diminished sanctioned payment may be accepted.
If a sanctioned payment is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Time when sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is made and accepted (O. 62A, r. 11)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is made when it is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned payment is made when a sanctioned payment notice is served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned offer is effective when its details are served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned payment is effective when notice of the amendment is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is accepted when notice of its acceptance is served on the offeror.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Clarification of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment notice (O. 62A, r. 12)

subsection.content: The offeree may, within 7 days of a sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment being made, request the offeror to clarify the offer or payment notice.
If the offeror does not give the clarification requested under paragraph (1) within 7 days of service of the request, the offeree may, before the relevant date, apply for an order that he does so.
If the Court makes an order pursuant to an application made under paragraph (2), it shall specify the date when the sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is to be treated as having been made.

section.crossHeading: III. Acceptance of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s13
section.heading: Time for acceptance of paying party’s sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 13)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 10(2) and paragraph (2), a receiving party may accept a sanctioned payment at any time before the relevant date without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the paying party a written notice of acceptance not later than 14 days after the payment was made.

subsection.leadIn: If the receiving party does not accept a paying party’s sanctioned payment within the 14-day period specified in paragraph (1), then the receiving party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, accept the payment without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, only accept the payment with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.
A notice of acceptance of a sanctioned payment must be in Form No. 93A in Appendix A.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Time for acceptance of receiving party’s sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 14)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 7(2) and paragraph (2), a paying party may accept a sanctioned offer at any time before the relevant date without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the receiving party a written notice of acceptance not later than 14 days after the offer was made.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying party does not accept a receiving party’s sanctioned offer within the 14-day period specified in paragraph (1), then the paying party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, accept the offer without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, only accept the offer with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Payment out of a sum in court on acceptance of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 15)
section.content: Subject to rule 16(4), where a sanctioned payment is accepted, the receiving party may obtain payment out of the sum in court by making a request for payment in Form No. 93B in Appendix A.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Acceptance of sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, paying parties (O. 62A, r. 16)

subsection.content: This rule applies where the receiving party wishes to accept a sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, of a number of paying parties.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying parties are jointly and severally liable to pay costs, the receiving party may accept the payment in accordance with rule 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he discontinues the proceedings for taxation against those paying parties who have not made the payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those paying parties give written consent to the acceptance of the payment.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying parties are not jointly, but severally liable to pay costs, the receiving party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: accept the payment in accordance with rule 13; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: continue with his proceedings for taxation against the other paying parties.

subsection.leadIn: In all other cases the receiving party shall apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order permitting a payment out to him of any sum in court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such order as to costs relating to the taxation as the Court considers appropriate.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Cases where court order is required to enable acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 17)
section.leadIn: Where a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is made in proceedings to which Order 80, rule 10 (Compromise, etc., by person under disability) applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offer or payment may be accepted only with the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no payment out of any sum in court may be made without a court order.

section.crossHeading: IV. Consequences of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s18
section.heading: Consequences of acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 18)

subsection.content: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment relates to the whole costs and is accepted, the taxation is stayed.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of acceptance of a sanctioned offer which relates to the whole costs—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the stay is upon the terms of the offer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: either party may apply to enforce those terms without the need to commence new proceedings.

subsection.content: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment which relates to part only of the costs is accepted, the taxation is stayed as to that part.

If the approval of the Court is required before a settlement as to costs can be binding, any stay which would otherwise arise on the acceptance of a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment takes effect only when that approval has been given.

subsection.leadIn: Any stay arising under this rule does not affect the power of the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce the terms of a sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to deal with any question of costs (including interest on costs) relating to the taxation; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to order payment out of court of any sum paid into court.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sanctioned offer has been accepted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a party alleges that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the other party has not honoured the terms of the offer; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is therefore entitled to a remedy for breach of contract,

subsection.continued: the party may claim the remedy by applying to the Court without the need to commence new proceedings unless the Court orders otherwise.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Costs consequences where receiving party fails to better sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 19)

subsection.content: This rule applies where upon taxation a receiving party fails to better a sanctioned payment.

The taxing master may by order disallow all or part of any interest otherwise payable under section 50 of the Ordinance on the whole or part of the amount of the costs awarded to the receiving party for some or all of the period after the latest date on which the payment could have been accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master may also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the receiving party to pay the costs of the taxation on the indemnity basis after the date on which the payment was made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that the paying party is entitled to interest on those costs at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the taxing master shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3) unless he considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), the taxing master shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of the sanctioned payment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which the sanctioned payment was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned payment was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the payment to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the taxing master under this rule is in addition to any other power he may have to award or disallow interest.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Costs and other consequences where receiving party does better than he proposed in his sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 20)

subsection.content: This rule applies where upon taxation a paying party is held liable for more than the proposals contained in a receiving party’s sanctioned offer.

The taxing master may order interest on the whole or part of the amount of the costs allowed to the receiving party at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate for some or all of the period after the date on which the sanctioned offer was served on the paying party.

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master may also order that the receiving party is entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his costs on the indemnity basis after the date on which the sanctioned offer was served on the paying party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: interest on those costs at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the taxing master shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3) unless he considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), the taxing master shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of the sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which the sanctioned offer was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned offer was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the offer to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the taxing master under this rule is in addition to any other power he may have to award interest.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Restriction on disclosure of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 21)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is treated as “without prejudice save as to costs”.
The fact that a sanctioned payment has been made must not be communicated to the taxing master until the amount of the costs to be allowed have been decided.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (2) does not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the taxation has been stayed under rule 18 following acceptance of a sanctioned payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the fact that there has or has not been a sanctioned payment may be relevant to the question of the costs of the issue of liability.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Interest (O. 62A, r. 22)

subsection.leadIn: Unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a receiving party’s sanctioned offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a sanctioned payment notice,

subsection.continued: indicates to the contrary, any such offer or payment is to be treated as inclusive of all interest until the last date on which it could be accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.
