subsection.content: The Court hearing an application under this rule may give such directions, including directions as to the taking of accounts and the making of inquiries, as may be just.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Attachment of debts owed by firm (O. 81, r. 7)

subsection.content: An order may be made under Order 49, rule 1, in relation to debts due or accruing due from a firm carrying on business within the jurisdiction notwithstanding that one or more members of the firm is resident out of the jurisdiction.

An order to show cause under Order 49, rule 1 relating to such debts as aforesaid must be served on a member of the firm within the jurisdiction or on some other person having the control or management of the partnership business.
Where an order made under Order 49, rule 1 requires a firm to appear before the Court, an appearance by a member of the firm constitutes a sufficient compliance with the order.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Actions begun by originating summons (O. 81, r. 8)
section.content: Rules 2 to 7 shall, with the necessary modifications, apply in relation to an action by or against partners in the name of their firm begun by originating summons as they apply in relation to such an action begun by writ.

section.name: s9
section.heading:
Application to person carrying on business
in another name (O. 81, r. 9)
section.content: An individual carrying on business within the jurisdiction in a name or style other than his own name, may, whether or not he is within the jurisdiction, be sued in that name or style as if it were the name of a firm, and rules 2 to 8 shall, so far as applicable, apply as if he were a partner and the name or style in which he carries on business were the name of his firm.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Applications for orders charging partner’s interest in partnership property, etc. (O. 81, r. 10)

subsection.content: Every application to the Court by a judgment creditor of a partner for an order under section 25 of the Partnership Ordinance (Cap. 38) (which authorizes the Court or a judge thereof to make certain orders on the application of a judgment creditor of a partner, including an order charging the partner’s interest in the partnership property), and every application to the Court by a partner of the judgment debtor made in consequence of the first-mentioned application, must be made by summons.
A master may exercise the powers conferred on a judge by that section.
Every summons issued by a judgment creditor under this rule, and every order made on such a summons, must be served on the judgment debtor and on such of his partners as are within the jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: Every summons issued by a partner of a judgment debtor under this rule, and every order made on such a summons, must be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the judgment creditor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the judgment debtor; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on such of the other partners of the judgment debtor as do not join in the application and are within the jurisdiction.

subsection.content: A summons or order served in accordance with this rule on some only of the partners shall be deemed to have been served on all the partners of the partnership.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Defamation Actions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application (O. 82, r. 1)
section.content: These Rules apply to actions for libel or slander subject to the following rules of this Order.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Indorsement of claim in libel action (O. 82, r. 2)
section.content: Before a writ in an action for libel is issued it must be indorsed with a statement giving sufficient particulars of the publications in respect of which the action is brought to enable them to be identified.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Obligation to give particulars (O. 82, r. 3)

subsection.content: Where in an action for libel or slander the plaintiff alleges that the words or matters complained of were used in a defamatory sense other than their ordinary meaning, he must give particulars of the facts and matters on which he relies in support of such sense.

Where in an action for libel or slander the defendant alleges that, in so far as the words complained of consist of statements of fact, they are true in substance and in fact, and in so far as they consist of expressions of opinion, they are fair comment on a matter of public interest, or pleads to the like effect, he must give particulars stating which of the words complained of he alleges are statements of fact and of the facts and matters he relies on in support of the allegation that the words are true.

Where in an action for libel or slander the plaintiff alleges that the defendant maliciously published the words or matters complained of, he need not in his statement of claim give particulars of the facts on which he relies in support of the allegation of malice, but if the defendant pleads that any of those words or matters are fair comment on a matter of public interest or were published on a privileged occasion and the plaintiff intends to allege that the defendant was actuated by express malice, he must serve a reply giving particulars of the facts and matters from which the malice is to be inferred.
This rule shall apply in relation to a counterclaim for libel or slander as if the party making the counterclaim were the plaintiff and the party against whom it is made the defendant.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Provisions as to payment into Court (O. 82, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where in an action for libel or slander against several defendants sued jointly the plaintiff, in accordance with Order 22, accepts money paid into court by any of those defendants in satisfaction of his cause of action against that defendant, then, notwithstanding anything in Order 22, the action shall be stayed as against that defendant only, but— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the sum recoverable under any judgment given in the plaintiff’s favour against any other defendant in the action by way of damages shall not exceed the amount (if any) by which the amount of the damages exceeds the amount paid into court by the defendant as against whom the action has been stayed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff shall not be entitled to his costs of the action against the other defendant after the date of the payment into court unless either the amount of the damages awarded to him is greater than the amount paid into court and accepted by him or the judge is of opinion that there was reasonable ground for him to proceed with the action against the other defendant.

subsection.content: Where in an action for libel a party pleads the defence for which section 4 of the Defamation Ordinance (Cap. 21) provides, Order 22, rule 25, shall not apply in relation to that pleading. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Statement in open Court (O. 82, r. 5)

subsection.content: Where a party wishes to accept money paid into court in satisfaction of a cause of action for libel or slander, malicious prosecution or false imprisonment, that party may before or after accepting the money apply to a judge in chambers by summons for leave to make in open court a statement in terms approved by the judge.

Where a party to an action for libel or slander, malicious prosecution or false imprisonment which is settled before trial desires to make a statement in open court, an application must be made to the Court for an order that an action be set down for trial, and before the date fixed for the trial a statement must be submitted for the approval of the judge before whom it is to be made.

section.name: s6
section.heading:
Interrogatories not allowed in certain
cases (O. 82, r. 6)
section.content: In an action for libel or slander where the defendant pleads that the words or matters complained of are fair comment on a matter of public interest or were published on a privileged occasion, no interrogatories as to the defendant’s sources of information or grounds of belief shall be allowed.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Evidence in mitigation of damages (O. 82, r. 7)
section.content: In an action for libel or slander in which the defendant does not by his defence assert the truth of the statement complained of, the defendant shall not be entitled on the trial to give evidence in chief, with a view to mitigation of damages, as to the circumstances under which the libel or slander was published, or as to the character of the plaintiff, without the leave of the judge, unless 7 days at least before the trial he furnishes particulars to the plaintiff of the matters as to which he intends to give evidence.

section.name: s83A
section.heading: Money Lenders’ Actions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application and interpretation (O. 83A, r. 1)

subsection.content: These Rules apply to a money lender’s action subject to the following rules of this Order.

subsection.leadIn: In this Order—
subsection.def: money lender (放債人) has the meaning assigned to it by section 2 of the Money Lenders Ordinance (Cap. 163);

money lender’s action (放債人訴訟) means an action for the recovery of money lent by a money lender or for the enforcement of any agreement or security relating to money so lent, being an action brought by the lender or an assignee.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Commencement of money lender’s action (O. 83A, r. 2)

subsection.content: Every money lender’s action may be begun by writ. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Before a writ beginning a money lender’s action is issued it must be indorsed with a statement that at the time of the making of the loan or contract or the giving of the security in question the lender was licensed as a money lender.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Particulars to be included in statement of claim (O. 83A, r. 3)
section.leadIn: Every statement of claim in a money lender’s action (whether indorsed on the writ or not) must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the loan was made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount actually lent to the borrower;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the rate per cent per annum of interest charged;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the date when the contract for repayment was made;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the amount repaid;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the amount due but unpaid;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the date upon which such unpaid sum or sums became due; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the amount of interest accrued due and unpaid on every such sum.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence (O. 83A, r. 4)

subsection.content: In a money lender’s action judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence shall not be entered except with the leave of the Court.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: An application for the grant of leave under this rule must be made by summons supported by an affidavit which must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prove that the money is due and payable;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: give the particulars required by rules 2 and 3; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: exhibit a true copy of any agreement or security relating to the money lent,

paragraph.continued: and the original agreement or security must be produced at the hearing of the summons.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The summons and a copy of the affidavit in support and of any exhibits referred to therein must, notwithstanding anything in Order 65, rule 9, be served on the defendant not less than 4 clear days before the day fixed for the hearing of the summons.

subsection.content: If the application is for leave to enter judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend, the summons shall not be issued until after the time limited for acknowledgment of service of the writ.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of such application, whether the defendant appears or not, the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may exercise the powers of the Court under section 25 of the Money Lenders Ordinance (Cap. 163);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it refuses leave under this rule to enter judgment on a claim or any part of a claim, may make or give any such order or directions as it might have made or given had the application been an application under Order 14, rule 1, for judgment on the claim.

section.name: s84A
section.heading: Actions Arising Out of Hire-Purchase or Conditional Sale Agreements

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application and interpretation (O. 84A, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: This Order applies to any action arising out of a hire-purchase agreement or a conditional sale agreement brought against the hirer or buyer of the goods to which the agreement relates or a guarantor, if the writ beginning the action is indorsed with a claim for money, not being—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a claim for unliquidated damages; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a claim for no more than the amount of any instalment or instalments of the hire-purchase price or total purchase price, as the case may be, which is due and unpaid.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: In this Order—
paragraph.def: buyer (買方), in relation to a conditional sale agreement, means the person who agrees to purchase goods under the agreement and includes a person to whom the rights or liabilities of that person under the agreement have passed by assignment or by operation of law;

conditional sale agreement (有條件售賣協議) means an agreement for the sale of goods under which the purchase price or part of it is payable by instalments, and the property in the goods is to remain in the seller (notwithstanding that the buyer is to be in possession of the goods) until such conditions as to the payment of instalments or otherwise as may be specified in the agreement are fulfilled;
goods (貨品), buyer (買方) except in relation to a conditional sale agreement, have the meanings assigned to them respectively by the Sale of Goods Ordinance (Cap. 26);
hire-purchase agreement (租購協議) means an agreement for the bailment of goods under which the bailee may buy the goods, or under which the property in the goods will or may pass to the bailee;

hire-purchase price (租購價), subject to subparagraph (b), means the total sum payable by the hirer under a hire-purchase agreement in order to complete the purchase of goods to which the agreement relates, exclusive of any sum payable as a penalty or as compensation or damages for a breach of the agreement;

hirer (租用人) means the person who takes or has taken goods from an owner under a hire-purchase agreement and includes a person to whom the hirer’s rights or liabilities under the agreement have passed by assignment or by operation of law;

total purchase price (總買價), subject to subparagraph (b), means the total sum payable by the buyer under a conditional sale agreement, exclusive of any sum payable as a penalty or as compensation or damages for a breach of the agreement.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: For the purposes of this Order, any sum payable by the hirer under a hire-purchase agreement, or by the buyer under a conditional sale agreement, by way of a deposit or other initial payment, or credited or to be credited to him under the agreement on account of any such deposit or payment, whether that sum is to be or has been paid to the owner or seller or to any other person or is to be or has been discharged by a payment of money or by the transfer or delivery of goods or by any other means, shall form part of the hire-purchase price or total purchase price, as the case may be.

section.name: s2
section.heading:
Particulars to be included in statement of claim
(O. 84A, r. 2)
section.content: Every statement of claim in an action to which this Order applies (whether indorsed on the writ or not) must state the circumstances in which the claim mentioned in rule 1(2) arises.

section.name: s3
section.heading:
Judgment on failure to give notice of
intention to defend or in default
of defence (O. 84A, r. 3)

subsection.content: In an action to which this Order applies judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence shall not be entered except with the leave of the Court.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: An application for the grant of leave under this rule must be made by summons supported by an affidavit which must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: give the particulars required by rule 2; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: exhibit a true copy of the hire-purchase or conditional sale agreement, the original of which must be produced at the hearing of the summons.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: The summons and a copy of the affidavit in support and of any exhibits referred to therein must, notwithstanding anything in Order 65, rule 9, be served on the defendant not less than 4 clear days before the day fixed for the hearing of the summons.

subsection.content: If the application is for leave to enter judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend, the summons shall not be issued until after the time limited for acknowledgment of service of the writ.
The plaintiff must produce to the Court hearing an application for the grant of leave under this rule the hire-purchase or conditional sale agreement to which the action relates.

Unless the Court hearing such application grants leave to enter judgment for the amount claimed or, having power to do so, transfers the action to the Court of First Instance, it shall (whether or not the defendant appears on the hearing) try the action.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Administration and Similar Actions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 85, r. 1)
section.content: In this Order administration action (遺產管理訴訟) means an action for the administration under the direction of the Court of the estate of a deceased person or for the execution under the direction of the Court of a trust.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Determination of questions, etc., without administration (O. 85, r. 2)

subsection.content: An action may be brought for the determination of any question or for any relief which could be determined or granted, as the case may be, in an administration action and a claim need not be made in the action for the administration or execution under the direction of the Court of the estate or trust in connection with which the question arises or the relief is sought.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), an action may be brought for the determination of any of the following questions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any question arising in the administration of the estate of a deceased person or in the execution of a trust;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any question as to the rights or interests of a person claiming to be a creditor of the estate of a deceased person or to be entitled under a will or on the intestacy of a deceased person or to be beneficially entitled under a trust.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), an action may be brought for any of the following reliefs—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order requiring an executor, administrator or trustee to furnish and, if necessary, verify accounts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order requiring the payment into court of money held by a person in his capacity as executor, administrator or trustee;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an order directing a person to do or abstain from doing a particular act in his capacity as executor, administrator or trustee;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order approving any sale, purchase, compromise or other transaction by a person in his capacity as executor, administrator or trustee;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an order directing any act to be done in the administration of the estate of a deceased person or in the execution of a trust which the Court could order to be done if the estate or trust were being administered or executed, as the case may be, under the direction of the Court.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Parties (O. 85, r. 3)

subsection.content: All the executors or administrators of the estate or trustees of the trust, as the case may be, to which an administration action or such an action as is referred to in rule 2 relates must be parties to the action, and where the action is brought by executors, administrators or trustees, any of them who does not consent to being joined as a plaintiff must be made a defendant.

Notwithstanding anything in Order 15, rule 4(2), and without prejudice to the powers of the Court under that Order, all the persons having a beneficial interest in or claim against the estate or having a beneficial interest under the trust, as the case may be, to which such an action as is mentioned in paragraph (1) relates need not be parties to the action; but the plaintiff may make such of those persons, whether all or any one or more of them, parties as, having regard to the nature of the relief or remedy claimed in the action, he thinks fit.

Where, in proceedings under a judgment or order given or made in an action for the administration under the direction of the Court of the estate of a deceased person, a claim in respect of a debt or other liability is made against the estate by a person not a party to the action, no party other than the executors or administrators of the estate shall be entitled to appear in any proceedings relating to that claim without the leave of the Court, and the Court may direct or allow any other party to appear either in addition to, or in substitution for, the executors or administrators on such terms as to costs or otherwise as it thinks fit.

section.name: s4
section.heading:
Grant of relief in action begun by
originating summons (O. 85, r. 4)
section.content: In an administration action or such an action as is referred to in rule 2, the Court may make any certificate or order and grant any relief to which the plaintiff may be entitled by reason of any breach of trust, wilful default or other misconduct of the defendant notwithstanding that the action was begun by originating summons, but the foregoing provision is without prejudice to the power of the Court to make an order under Order 28, rule 8, in relation to the action.

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Judgments and orders in administration
actions (O. 85, r. 5)

subsection.content: A judgment or order for the administration or execution under the direction of the Court of an estate or trust need not be given or made unless in the opinion of the Court the questions at issue between the parties cannot properly be determined otherwise than under such a judgment or order.

subsection.leadIn: Where an administration action is brought by a creditor of the estate of a deceased person or by a person claiming to be entitled under a will or on the intestacy of a deceased person or to be beneficially entitled under a trust, and the plaintiff alleges that no or insufficient accounts have been furnished by the executors, administrators or trustees, as the case may be, then, without prejudice to its other powers, the Court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that proceedings in the action be stayed for a period specified in the order and that the executors, administrators or trustees, as the case may be, shall within that period furnish the plaintiff with proper accounts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if necessary to prevent proceedings by other creditors or by other persons claiming to be entitled as aforesaid, give judgment or make an order for the administration of the estate to which the action relates and include therein an order that no proceedings are to be taken under the judgment or order, or under any particular account or inquiry directed, without the leave of the judge.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Conduct of sale of trust property (O. 85, r. 6)
section.content: Where in an administration action an order is made for the sale of any property vested in executors, administrators or trustees, those executors, administrators or trustees, as the case may be, shall have the conduct of the sale unless the Court otherwise directs.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Actions for Specific Performance, etc.: Summary Judgment

section.name: s1
section.heading:
Application by plaintiff for summary judgment
(O. 86, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: In any action begun by writ indorsed with a claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for specific performance of an agreement (whether in writing or not) for the sale, purchase, exchange, mortgage or charge of any property, or for the grant or assignment of a lease of any property, with or without an alternative claim for damages; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for rescission of such an agreement; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the forfeiture or return of any deposit made under such an agreement,

subsection.continued: the plaintiff may, on the ground that the defendant has no defence to the action, apply to the Court for judgment.

subsection.content: An application may be made against a defendant under this rule whether or not he has acknowledged service of the writ.

section.name: s2
section.heading:
Manner in which application under rule 1
must be made (O. 86, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An application under rule 1 must be made by summons supported by an affidavit verifying the facts on which the cause of action is based and stating that in the deponent’s belief there is no defence to the action.
subsection.continued: Unless the Court otherwise directs, an affidavit for the purposes of this paragraph may contain statements of information or belief with the sources and grounds thereof.

subsection.content: The summons must set out or have attached thereto minutes of the judgment sought by the plaintiff.
The summons, a copy of the affidavit in support and of any exhibit referred to therein must be served on the defendant not less than 4 clear days before the return day.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Judgment for plaintiff (O. 86, r. 3)

subsection.content: Unless on the hearing of an application under rule 1 either the Court dismisses the application or the defendant satisfies the Court that there is an issue or question in dispute which ought to be tried or that there ought for some other reason to be a trial of the action, the Court may give judgment for the plaintiff in the action.

The Court may by order, and subject to such conditions, if any, as may be just, stay execution of any judgment given against the defendant under this rule until after the trial of any counterclaim made or raised by the defendant in the action.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Leave to defend (O. 86, r. 4)

subsection.content: A defendant may show cause against an application under rule 1 by affidavit or otherwise to the satisfaction of the Court.

The Court may give a defendant against whom such an application is made leave to defend the action either unconditionally or on such terms as to giving security or time or mode of trial or otherwise as it thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of such an application the Court may order a defendant showing cause or, where that defendant is a body corporate, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer thereof, or any person purporting to act in any such capacity—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to produce any document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it appears to the Court that there are special circumstances which make it desirable that he should do so, to attend and be examined on oath.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Directions (O. 86, r. 5)
section.leadIn: Where the Court orders that a defendant have leave to defend the action, the Court shall give directions as to the further conduct of the action, and Order 25, rules 5 to 10— (L.N. 153 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the omission of so much of rule 10(1) as requires the parties to serve a notice specifying the orders and directions which they require; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with any other necessary modifications,

section.continued: apply as if the application under rule 1 were a case management summons.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Costs (O. 86, r. 6)
section.content: If the plaintiff makes an application under rule 1 where the case is not within this Order, or if it appears to the Court that the plaintiff knew that the defendant relied on a contention which would entitle him to unconditional leave to defend, then, without prejudice to Order 62, and, in particular, to rule 4(1) thereof, the Court may dismiss the application with costs and may, if the plaintiff is not an aided person, require the costs to be paid by him forthwith.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Setting aside judgment (O. 86, r. 7)
section.content: Any judgment given against a defendant who does not appear at the hearing of an application under rule 1 may be set aside or varied by the Court on such terms as it thinks just.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Application for summary judgment on counterclaim (O. 86, r. 8)

subsection.content: Where a defendant to an action begun by writ has served a counterclaim claiming against the plaintiff such relief as appears in rule 1(1) the defendant may, on the ground that the plaintiff has no defence to a claim made in the counterclaim or to a particular part of such a claim, apply to the Court for judgment against the plaintiff on that claim or that part.

subsection.leadIn: Rules 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 shall apply in relation to an application under this rule as they apply in relation to an application under rule 1 but with the following modifications—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: references to the plaintiff and defendant shall be construed as references to the defendant and plaintiff respectively;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the words in rule 3(2) “any counterclaim made or raised by the defendant in” shall be omitted;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reference in rule 4(2) to the action shall be construed as a reference to the counterclaim to which the application under this rule relates.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Right to proceed with residue of action or counterclaim (O. 86, r. 9)

subsection.content: Where on an application under rule 1 the plaintiff obtains judgment on a claim or a part of a claim against any defendant, he may proceed with the action as respects any other claim or as respects the remainder of the claim or against any other defendant.

Where on an application under rule 8 a defendant obtains judgment on a claim or a part of a claim made in a counterclaim against the plaintiff, he may proceed with the counterclaim as respects any other claim or against any other defendant to the counterclaim.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Mortgage Actions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Application and interpretation (O. 88, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: This Order applies to any action (whether begun by writ or originating summons) by a mortgagee or mortgagor or by any person having the right to foreclose or redeem any mortgage, being an action (other than an action to which rule 5A applies) in which there is a claim for any of the following reliefs, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: payment of moneys secured by the mortgage;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sale of the mortgaged property;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: foreclosure;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: redemption;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: reconveyance of the property or its release from the security;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: delivery of possession by the mortgagee.

subsection.def: In this Order mortgage (按揭) includes a legal and an equitable mortgage and a legal and an equitable charge, and references to a mortgagor, a mortgagee and mortgaged property shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.content: An action to which this Order applies is referred to in this Order as a mortgage action.
These Rules apply to mortgage actions subject to the following rules of this Order.

section.name: s4
section.heading:
Claim for possession: failure by a defendant
to acknowledge service (O. 88, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where in a mortgage action begun by originating summons, being an action in which the plaintiff is the mortgagee and claims delivery of possession or payment of moneys secured by the mortgage or both, any defendant fails to acknowledge service of the originating summons, the following provisions of this rule shall apply, and references in those provisions to the defendant shall be construed as references to any such defendant.
subsection.continued: This rule shall not be taken as affecting Order 28, rule 3 or 5(2), in so far as it requires any document to be served on, or notice given to, a defendant who has acknowledged service of the originating summons in the action.

subsection.content: Not less than 4 clear days before the day fixed for the first hearing of the originating summons the plaintiff must serve on the defendant a notice of appointment for the hearing and a copy of the affidavit in support of the summons.

Where the plaintiff claims delivery of possession there must be indorsed on the outside fold of the copy of the affidavit served on the defendant a notice informing the defendant that the plaintiff intends at the hearing to apply for an order to the defendant to deliver up to the plaintiff possession of the mortgaged property and for such other relief (if any) claimed by the originating summons as the plaintiff intends to apply for at the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: Where the hearing is adjourned, then, subject to any directions given by the Court, the plaintiff must serve notice of the appointment for the adjourned hearing, together with a copy of any further affidavit intended to be used at that hearing, on the defendant not less than 2 clear days before the day fixed for the hearing.
subsection.continued: A copy of any affidavit served under this paragraph must be indorsed in accordance with paragraph (3).

subsection.content:
Service under paragraph (2) or (4), and the manner in which it was effected, may be proved by a certificate signed by the plaintiff, if he sues in person, and otherwise by his solicitor.
The certificate may be indorsed on the affidavit in support of the summons or, as the case may be, on any further affidavit intended to be used at an adjourned hearing.
A copy of any exhibit to an affidavit need not accompany the copy of the affidavit served under paragraph (2) or (4).

Where the plaintiff gives notice to the defendant under Order 3, rule 6, of his intention to proceed, service of the notice, and the manner in which it was effected, may be proved by a certificate signed as mentioned in paragraph (5).

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Action for possession or payment: evidence
(O. 88, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: The affidavit in support of the originating summons by which an action to which this rule applies is begun must comply with the following provisions of this rule.
subsection.continued: This rule applies to a mortgage action begun by originating summons in which the plaintiff is the mortgagee and claims delivery of possession or payment of moneys secured by the mortgage or both.

subsection.content: The affidavit must exhibit a true copy of the mortgage and the original mortgage must be produced at the hearing of the summons.

subsection.leadIn: Where the plaintiff claims delivery of possession, the affidavit must show the circumstances under which the right to possession arises and except where the Court in any case or class of case otherwise directs, the state of the account between the mortgagor and mortgagee with particulars of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the amount of the advance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of the periodic payments required to be made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the amount of any interest or instalments in arrear at the date of the originating summons and at the date of the affidavit; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the amount remaining due under the mortgage.

subsection.content: Where the plaintiff claims delivery of possession, the affidavit must give particulars of every person who to the best of the plaintiff’s knowledge is in possession of the mortgaged property.

If the mortgage creates a tenancy other than a tenancy at will between the mortgagor and mortgagee, the affidavit must show how and when the tenancy was determined and if by service of notice when the notice was duly served.
Where the plaintiff claims payment of moneys secured by the mortgage, the affidavit must prove that the money is due and payable and give the particulars mentioned in paragraph (3).
Where the plaintiff’s claim includes a claim for interest to judgment, the affidavit must state the amount of a day’s interest.

section.name: s5A
section.heading:
Action for the enforcement of charging
order by sale (O. 88, r. 5A)

subsection.content: This rule applies to a mortgage action to enforce a charging order by sale of the property charged.

subsection.leadIn: The affidavit in support of the originating summons must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the charging order sought to be enforced and the subject-matter of the charge; (L.N. 26 of 2020)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the amount in respect of which the charge was imposed and the balance outstanding at the date of the affidavit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: verify, so far as is known, the debtor’s title to the property charged;

paragraph.name: d
e
f
paragraph.content: where the property charged consists of land in respect of which the plaintiff claims delivery of possession, give particulars of every person who to the best of the plaintiff’s knowledge is in possession of the property charged or any part of it.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Action by writ: judgment in default (O. 88, r. 6)

subsection.content: Notwithstanding anything in Order 13 or 19, in a mortgage action begun by writ judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence shall not be entered except with the leave of the Court.
An application for the grant of leave under this rule must be made by summons and the summons must, notwithstanding anything in Order 65, rule 9, be served on the defendant.

Where a summons for leave under this rule is issued, rule 4(2) to (7) shall apply in relation to the action subject to the modification that for references therein to the originating summons, and for the reference in paragraph (2) to the notice of appointment, there shall be substituted references to the summons.

Where a summons for leave under this rule is issued in an action to which rule 5 would apply had the action been begun by originating summons, the affidavit in support of the summons must contain the information required by that rule.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Foreclosure in redemption action (O. 88, r. 7)
section.content: Where foreclosure has taken place by reason of the failure of the plaintiff in a mortgage action for redemption to redeem, the defendant in whose favour the foreclosure has taken place may apply by summons for an order for delivery to him of possession of the mortgaged property, and the Court may make such order thereon as it thinks fit.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Proceedings between Husband and Wife

section.name: s1
section.heading: Determination of questions as to property (O. 89, r. 1)

subsection.content: Proceedings under section 3 of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16) and section 6 of the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182) may be begun by originating summons. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Provisions as to actions in tort (O. 89, r. 2)

subsection.content: This rule applies to any action in tort brought by one of the parties to a marriage against the other during the subsistence of the marriage.

On the first application by summons in an action to which this rule applies, the Court shall consider, if necessary of its own motion, whether the power to stay the action under section 5(2) of the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182) should or should not be exercised.

Notwithstanding anything in Order 13 or 19, in an action to which this rule applies judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend or in default of defence shall not be entered except with the leave of the Court.
An application for the grant of leave under paragraph (3) must be made by summons and the summons must, notwithstanding anything in Order 65, rule 9, be served on the defendant.
If the summons is for leave to enter judgment on failure to give notice of intention to defend, the summons shall not be issued before the time limited for acknowledging service of the writ.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Proceedings Concerning Minors

section.name: s1
section.heading: Applications under Guardianship of Minors Ordinance and Parent and Child Ordinance (O. 90, r. 1)

subsection.content: Any application under the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13) and the Parent and Child Ordinance (Cap. 429) may be made by originating summons. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

Where the minor with respect to whom an application under the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13) and the Parent and Child Ordinance (Cap. 429) is made is not the plaintiff he shall not, unless the Court otherwise directs, be made a defendant to the summons but, subject to paragraph (3), any other person appearing to be interested in, or affected by, the application shall be made a defendant.
The Court may dispense with service of the summons on any person and may order it to be served on any person not originally served.
Every application under paragraph (1) shall be heard by a judge who may dispose of the application in chambers.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Verification and passing of guardians accounts (O. 90, r. 2)
section.content: A guardian’s account must be verified and passed in the same manner as that provided by Order 30 in relation to a receiver’s account or in such other manner as the Court may direct.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Application of Matrimonial Causes Rules (O. 90, r. 3)

subsection.content: The provisions of the Matrimonial Causes Rules (Cap. 179 sub. leg. A) relating to proceedings under section 48 of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) shall apply, with the necessary modifications, to proceedings under sections 13(1), 14 and 15 of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13).

The provisions of the Matrimonial Causes Rules (Cap. 179 sub. leg. A) relating to the drawing up and service of orders shall apply to proceedings under this Order as if they were proceedings under those Rules.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Further provisions as to orders for supervision or care of a child (O. 90, r. 4)
section.content: An application by the Director of Social Welfare under the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13) for the variation or discharge of an order made under that Ordinance or for directions as to the exercise of the powers of the Director under that order may, in case of urgency or where the application is unlikely to be opposed, be made by letter addressed to the Court and the Director shall, whenever practicable, notify any interested party of his intention to make the application.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Removal of a child out of Hong Kong (O. 90, r. 5)

subsection.content: This rule and rules 6 and 7 shall apply to proceedings under the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13) and the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16).
An application for leave to remove a child under 18 permanently out of Hong Kong must be made to a judge unless the application is unopposed, in which case it may be made to the Registrar.

The father or mother of a child under 18 may apply ex parte to a judge for an injunction restraining the other of them or any other person from removing the said child out of Hong Kong or out of the custody, care or control of any person named in the application.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Reference to the Director of Social Welfare (O. 90, r. 6)

subsection.content: A judge or the Registrar may at any time refer to the Director of Social Welfare for investigation and report any matter concerning the welfare of a child which may arise in proceedings in the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Where a reference is made under this rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director may inspect and, with the approval of the judge or Registrar, copy from the Court file;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after completing his investigation, the Director shall file his report and the Registrar shall thereupon notify the parties that they may inspect it and may bespeak copies on payment of the prescribed fee; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall give notice to the Director of the date of hearing of the application or other proceedings.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Statement of other proceedings on application relating to child (O. 90, r. 7)
section.content: If, at the time when an application to the Court relating to a child is made in any cause, any proceedings relating to the said child and brought after the cause was begun are pending in the High Court or the Court, the applicant must file a statement of the nature of those proceedings when he makes his application.

section.name: s90A
section.heading: Proceedings Concerning Judgment Summons

section.name: s1
section.heading:
Enforcement of order for payment of money, etc.
(O. 90A, r. 1)

subsection.content: This rule shall apply to proceedings under the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16) and the Maintenance Orders (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 188).

Before any process is issued for the enforcement of an order for the payment of money to any person, an affidavit shall be filed verifying the amount due under the order and showing how that amount is arrived at.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Judgment summons: general provisions (O. 90A, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this Order, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: interest (利息) means interest in respect of arrears of maintenance payable under section 20A(2) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9B(2) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53A(2) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AA(2) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be; (18 of 2003 s. 25)
judgment creditor (判定債權人) means a person entitled to enforce an order;
judgment debtor (判定債務人) means a person liable under an order;
judgment summons (判決傳票) means a summons issued under an order made under Order 48, rule 1(1) requiring a judgment debtor to appear and be examined on oath as to his means;
order (命令) means an order made in proceedings to which this rule applies for the payment of money, including an order for costs; (E.R. 4 of 2017)

surcharge (附加費) means a surcharge in respect of arrears of maintenance payable under section 20B(1) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9C(1) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), section 53B(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179) or section 28AB(1) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), as the case may be. (18 of 2003 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: Where an order has been made, the Court may, on an application made ex parte by the judgment creditor, direct a summons to issue to the judgment debtor to attend before the Court and be orally examined on the questions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether any and, if so, what debts are owing to the judgment debtor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the judgment debtor has any and, if so, what other property or means of satisfying the order,

subsection.continued: and the Court may also order the judgment debtor to produce any books or documents in his possession, custody or power relevant to the questions aforesaid at the time and place appointed for the examination.

subsection.content: An application for the issue of a judgment summons shall be in Form No. 1 in Appendix D and there shall be filed with the application the affidavit required by rule 1(2) which shall exhibit a copy of the order.

Every judgment summons shall be in Form No. 2 in Appendix D and shall be served on the judgment debtor personally not less than 5 clear days before the hearing and at the time of service there shall be paid or tendered to the judgment debtor a sum reasonably sufficient to cover his expenses in travelling to and from the Court at which he is summoned to appear.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of the judgment summons the judge may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where the order is for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the payment of a lump sum or costs; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: maintenance or other periodical payments, and it appears to him that the order would have been varied or suspended if the judgment debtor had made an application for that purpose,

paragraph.continued: make a new order for payment of the amount due under the original order, together with the costs of the judgment summons, the interest and surcharge payable, either at a specified time or by instalments; (18 of 2003 s. 25)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the judgment debtor fails to attend, adjourn the summons to a specified time on a specified day and order the judgment debtor to attend at that time on that day; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the judgment debtor, having been ordered under subparagraph (b) to attend at a specified time on a specified day, fails to do so, or where the judgment debtor attends, but fails to show cause why an order of commitment should not be made against him, make an order for the commitment of the judgment debtor.

subsection.content: If the judge makes an order of commitment, he may direct its execution to be suspended on terms that the judgment debtor pays to the judgment creditor the amount due, together with the costs of the judgment summons, the interest and surcharge payable, either at a specified time or by instalments, in addition to any sums accruing due under the original order. (18 of 2003 s. 25)
All payments under a new order or an order of commitment shall be made to the judgment creditor unless the judge otherwise directs.

subsection.leadIn: Where an order of commitment is suspended on such terms as are mentioned in paragraph (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: all payments made after the date of the order of commitment by the judgment debtor to the judgment creditor in their respective capacities of judgment debtor and judgment creditor shall be deemed to be made in the following order in or towards the discharge of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: interest;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: surcharge;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the costs of the judgment summons;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: any sums from time to time falling due under the maintenance order, with the sums discharged in the reversed chronological sequence of the dates on which payment is due (that is, the most recent arrears will be discharged first);

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: if the Court makes an order on a judgment summons, the amount of the maintenance in arrears, whether in one amount or by instalments, payable by the judgment debtor under the order; and (18 of 2003 s. 25)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order of commitment so suspended shall not be issued until the judgment creditor has filed an affidavit of default on the part of the judgment debtor.

section.name: s3
section.heading:
Special provisions as to judgment summons
(O. 90A, r. 3)

subsection.content: Order 38, rule 2(3) (which enables evidence to be given by affidavit in certain cases) shall apply to a judgment summons as if it were an originating summons.

subsection.leadIn: Witnesses may be summoned—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to prove the means of the judgment debtor; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide information relevant to the Court’s decision on interest and surcharge,

subsection.continued: in the same manner as witnesses are summoned to give evidence on the hearing of a cause, and writs of subpoena may, for the purpose of subparagraph (a) or (b), be issued out of the registry in which the judgment summons was issued. (18 of 2003 s. 26)

subsection.content: Where the judgment debtor appears at the hearing, the travelling expenses paid to him may, if the judge so directs, be allowed as expenses of a witness, but if the judgment debtor appears at the hearing and no order of commitment is made, the judge may allow to the judgment debtor, by way of set-off or otherwise, his proper costs, including compensation for loss of time, as upon an attendance by a defendant at a trial in court.
Where a new order or an order of commitment is made, the Registrar shall send notice of the order to the judgment debtor.
An order of commitment shall be directed to the bailiff, for execution by him.

subsection.leadIn: Unless the judge otherwise directs, the judgment creditor’s costs of and incidental to the judgment summons shall be fixed without taxation in accordance with the following provisions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subparagraph (c), where the amount in respect of which the judgment summons is issued is paid before the hearing, there may be allowed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the court fees paid by the judgment creditor;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any travelling expenses paid to the judgment debtor; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the judgment creditor is represented by a solicitor, such sums as the Court may order in respect of the solicitor’s charges;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where an order is made on the hearing and the judgment creditor is awarded costs, there may be allowed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the court fees paid by the judgment creditor;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subject to paragraph (3), any travelling expenses paid to the judgment debtor;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the judgment creditor is represented by a solicitor without counsel, such sums as the Court may order in respect of the solicitor’s charges; and

subparagraph.name: iv

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the amount in respect of which the judgment summons is issued is paid too late to prevent the attendance of the judgment creditor or, as the case may be, his solicitor or counsel, at the hearing, the sums specified in subparagraph (b) may, if the judge so orders, be allowed instead of the sums specified in subparagraph (a);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where the costs of and incidental to a judgment summons are directed to be taxed, Order 62 shall have effect in relation to the costs of proceedings pending in the Court, or as the Court may otherwise order.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Lodgment, Investment, etc. of Funds in Court

section.name: s2
section.heading:
Payment into Court under Trustee Ordinance
(O. 92, r. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (2), any trustee wishing to make a payment into court under section 62 of the Trustee Ordinance (Cap. 29) must make and file an affidavit setting out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a short description of the trust and of the instrument creating it or, as the case may be, of the circumstances in which the trust arose;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: his submission to answer all such inquiries relating to the application of such money or securities as the Court may make or direct; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an address where he may be served with any summons or order, or notice of any proceedings, relating to the money or securities paid into court.

subsection.content: Where the money or securities represents a legacy or residue or any share thereof, to which a minor or a person resident outside Hong Kong is absolutely entitled, no affidavit need be filed under paragraph (1) and the money or securities may be paid into court in the manner prescribed by the District Court Suitors’ Funds Rules (Cap. 336 sub. leg. E) for the time being in force.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Notice of lodgment (O. 92, r. 4)
section.content: Any person who has lodged money or securities in court in accordance with rule 2 must forthwith send notice of the lodgment to every person appearing from the affidavit on which the lodgment was made to be entitled to, or to have an interest in, the money or securities lodged.

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Applications with respect to funds in
Court (O. 92, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Where an application to the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the payment or transfer to any person of any funds in court standing to the credit of any cause or matter or for the transfer of any such funds to a separate account or for the payment to any person of any dividend of or interest on any securities or money comprised in such funds;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the investment, or change of investment, of any funds in court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for payment of the dividends of or interest on any funds in court representing or comprising money or securities lodged in court under any enactment; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for the payment or transfer out of court of any such funds as are mentioned in subparagraph (c),

subsection.continued: is made the application may be disposed of in chambers.

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (3), any such application must be made by summons and, unless the application is made in a pending cause or matter or an application for the same purpose has previously been made by originating summons, the summons must be an originating summons.

Where an application under paragraph (1)(d) is required to be made by originating summons, then, if the funds to which the application relates do not exceed $50,000 in value, the application may be made ex parte to a master and the master may dispose of the application or may direct it to be made by originating summons. Unless otherwise directed, an ex parte application under this paragraph shall be made by affidavit.
This rule does not apply to any application for an order under Order 22A. (L.N. 153 of 2008)

section.name: s93
section.heading: Applications under Variation of Trusts Ordinance (Cap. 253)

section.name: s6
section.heading:
Applications under Variation of Trusts
Ordinance (O. 93, r. 6)

subsection.content: In addition to any other persons who are necessary and proper defendants to the originating summons by which an application under section 3 of the Variation of Trusts Ordinance (Cap. 253), is made, the settlor and any other person who provided property for the purposes of the trusts to which the application relates must, if still alive and not the plaintiff, be made a defendant unless the Court for some special reason otherwise directs.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Summary Proceedings for Possession of Land

section.name: s1
section.heading:
Application for summary proceedings for
possession of land (O. 113, r. 1)
section.content: Where a person claims possession of land which he alleges is occupied solely by a person or persons (not being a tenant or tenants holding over after the termination of the tenancy) who entered into or remained in occupation without his licence or consent or that of any predecessor in title of his, the proceedings may be brought by originating summons in accordance with the provisions of this Order.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Jurisdiction of masters (O. 113, r. 1A)
section.content: Proceedings under this Order may be heard and determined by a master, who may refer them to a judge if he thinks they should properly be decided by the judge.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Form of originating summons (O. 113, r. 2)
section.content: The originating summons shall be in Form No. 11A in Appendix A and no acknowledgment of service of it shall be required.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Affidavit in support (O. 113, r. 3)
section.leadIn: The plaintiff shall file in support of the originating summons an affidavit stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his interest in the land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the land has been occupied without licence or consent and in which his claim to possession arises; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that he does not know the name of any person occupying the land who is not named in the summons.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Service of originating summons (O. 113, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where any person in occupation of the land is named in the originating summons, the summons together with a copy of the affidavit in support shall be served on him—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally; or

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: by sending a copy of the summons and of the affidavit by ordinary post to him at the premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by leaving a copy of the summons and of the affidavit at the premises; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in such other manner as the Court may direct.

subsection.leadIn: The summons shall, in addition to being served on the named defendants (if any) in accordance with paragraph (1), be served, unless the Court otherwise directs, by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affixing a copy of the summons and a copy of the affidavit to the main door or other conspicuous part of the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if practicable, inserting through the letter-box at the premises a copy of the summons and a copy of the affidavit enclosed in a sealed envelope addressed to “the occupiers”.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Every copy of an originating summons for service under paragraph (1) or (2) shall be sealed with the seal of the Court.
Order 28, rule 3, shall not apply to proceedings under this Order.

section.name: s5
section.heading:
Application by occupier to be made
a party (O. 113, r. 5)
section.content: Without prejudice to Order 15, rules 6 and 10, any person not named as a defendant who is in occupation of the land and wishes to be heard on the question whether an order for possession should be made may apply at any stage of the proceedings to be joined as a defendant.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Order for possession (O. 113, r. 6)

subsection.content: A final order shall, except in case of urgency and by leave of the Court, not be made less than 5 clear days after the date of service.
An order for possession in proceedings under this Order shall be in Form No. 42A in Appendix A.

Nothing in this Order shall prevent the Court from ordering possession to be given on a specified date, in exercise of any power which could have been exercised if possession had been claimed in an action begun by writ.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Writ of possession (O. 113, r. 7)

subsection.content: Order 45, rule 3(2) shall not apply in relation to an order for possession under this Order but no writ of possession to enforce such an order shall be issued after the expiry of 3 months from the date of the order without the leave of the Court. An application for leave may be made ex parte unless the Court otherwise directs.
The writ of possession shall be in Form No. 66A in Appendix A.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Setting aside order (O. 113, r. 8)
section.content: The judge may, on such terms as he thinks just, set aside or vary any order made in proceedings under this Order.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Proceedings and Applications under Child Abduction and Custody Ordinance (Cap. 512)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 121, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: In this Order—
subsection.def: Ordinance (《條例》) means the Child Abduction and Custody Ordinance (Cap. 512).

subsection.content: Expressions used in this Order that are used in the Ordinance have the same meanings in this Order as in the Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Mode of application (O. 121, r. 2)
section.leadIn: Except as provided in the Ordinance, an originating application under section 21(3) of the Ordinance may be made by originating summons in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (subject to subparagraph (b)) Form No. 10A in Appendix A; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the application is made ex parte as provided in this Order) Form No. 10B in Appendix A.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Time for acknowledging service (O. 121, r. 6)
section.leadIn: The time limited for acknowledging service of an originating summons issued pursuant to rule 2 is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (subject to subparagraph (b)) 7 days after the service of the originating summons, including the day of service; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the service takes place out of the jurisdiction) 14 days after the service of the originating summons, including the day of service.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Hearing of originating summons (O. 121, r. 6A)

subsection.content: A day and time for the attendance of the parties before the Court for the hearing of an originating summons may be fixed on the application of the applicant.
If an originating summons is required to be served, the time limited for acknowledging service may, where appropriate, be abridged so as to expire on the 2nd day before the day so fixed.

subsection.leadIn: If an originating summons is required to be served and a day is fixed under paragraph (1) for the hearing of the originating summons, the applicant must, at least 4 clear days before that day, serve on the respondent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the originating summons and the affidavit required under this Order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the respondent has been served with the originating summons and the affidavit required under this Order) a notice of the day fixed for the hearing.

subsection.content: If the hearing of an originating summons required to be served is adjourned and any party to the proceedings desires to apply at the resumed hearing for any order or direction not previously asked for, that party must, at least 2 clear days before the resumed hearing of the originating summons, serve on the other party a notice specifying those orders and directions.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Further evidence (O. 121, r. 7)

subsection.content: Any respondent may within 5 days after acknowledging service of the originating summons file and serve on the other parties any affidavit on which the respondent intends to rely.
The applicant may within 5 days thereafter file and serve on the respondent an affidavit in reply.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Assignment of proceedings (O. 121, r. 8)
section.content: Every application must be heard and determined by a judge, except that applications to extend time and to join a respondent may be heard by a master, and must be dealt with in chambers unless the Court otherwise directs.

section.name: s12C
section.heading: Application for an order under section 21(3) of the Ordinance: for prohibiting removal of child out of Hong Kong (O. 121, r. 12C)

subsection.leadIn: An application for an order under section 21(3) of the Ordinance must be supported by an affidavit sworn by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person duly authorized to swear it on behalf of the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: The affidavit must, as far as possible—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: provide the information set out in paragraph (3) about the following persons—

subparagraph.content: the child;
the applicant;
the person believed to be intending to remove, or to be removing, the child out of Hong Kong; and
the person specified in section 21(2)(a) of the Ordinance who has the custody of the child under a court order or who is exercising the rights of that custody (other than the applicant);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state the basis for believing that the person mentioned in subparagraph (a)(iii) may remove the child out of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide any other relevant information; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: exhibit all relevant documents.

subsection.leadIn: The information includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following in respect of the child—

subparagraph.content: name (in both Chinese and English, if applicable);
date of birth (if available);
gender;
birth certificate number (if available);
Hong Kong Identity Card number (if available);
travel document number (if available); and
address (if available);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following in respect of the applicant—

subparagraph.content: name (in both Chinese and English, if applicable);
gender;
Hong Kong Identity Card number or travel document number;
address;
contact telephone number; and
relationship with the child;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the following in respect of the person mentioned in paragraph (2)(a)(iii)—

subparagraph.content: name (in both Chinese and English, if applicable);
gender;
(if available) Hong Kong Identity Card number or travel document number;
address (if available);
contact telephone number (if available); and
relationship with the child; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the following in respect of the person mentioned in paragraph (2)(a)(iv)—

subparagraph.content: name (in both Chinese and English, if applicable);
gender;
(if available) Hong Kong Identity Card number or travel document number;
address (if available);
contact telephone number (if available); and
relationship with the child.

subsection.content: The affidavit must be filed at the same time as the application.

subsection.leadIn: However, for an urgent case, the affidavit may be filed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the time specified by the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if no time is specified by the Court) as soon as possible after the application.

subsection.content: The application may be made ex parte.

section.name: s12D
section.heading: Application for an order under section 21(4) of the Ordinance: for variation, discharge, suspension or revival (O. 121, r. 12D)

subsection.leadIn: An application for an order under section 21(4) of the Ordinance must be supported by an affidavit sworn by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person duly authorized to swear it on behalf of the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: The affidavit must, as far as possible—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the ground of the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide any other relevant information; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exhibit all relevant documents.

subsection.content: The affidavit must be filed at the same time as the application.

subsection.leadIn: However, for an urgent case, the affidavit may be filed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the time specified by the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if no time is specified by the Court) as soon as possible after the application.

subsection.content: The application may be made ex parte.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Searching for, inspecting and obtaining copies of documents filed in proceedings under the Ordinance (O. 121, r. 13)

subsection.leadIn: Unless otherwise directed by the Court, a party to any proceedings under the Ordinance or the party’s solicitor, or the Secretary for Justice, may do one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have a search in the Registry made for a document filed in the Registry in those proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inspect or obtain a copy of the document.

subsection.leadIn: Except as provided in paragraph (1), if a document is filed in the Registry in any proceedings under the Ordinance (other than an order made in open court)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the document is not open to inspection by any person without leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no copy of the document, or of an extract from the document, may be taken by, or issued to, any person without leave of the Court.

p.b: Acknowledgment of Service of Writ of Summons

paragraph.leadIn: 1. The accompanying form of ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF SERVICE should be detached and completed by a Solicitor acting on behalf of the Defendant or by the Defendant if acting in person. After completion it must be delivered or sent by post to the Registry of the District Court at the following address:—

continued.p: [insert here the address of the Registry of the District Court]

paragraph.content: 1A. However, a Defendant (or a Solicitor acting on behalf of a Defendant) who is a registered user or an Organization User account holder may send the Acknowledgment of Service to the Registry of the District Court by means of an e-system in accordance with the Court Proceedings (Electronic Technology) (District Court Civil Proceedings) Rules (Cap. 638 sub. leg. C).

statutoryNote.content: For the meaning of Organization User account holder and registered user, please see rule 2 of the Court Proceedings (Electronic Technology) (District Court Civil Proceedings) Rules (Cap. 638 sub. leg. C).

paragraph.content: 2. A Defendant who states in his Acknowledgment of Service that he intends to contest the proceedings MUST ALSO file a DEFENCE which must be written in either the Chinese or the English language with the Registry and serve a copy thereof on the Solicitor for the Plaintiff (or on the Plaintiff if acting in person).

If a Statement of Claim is indorsed on the Writ (i.e. the words “Statement of Claim” appear at the top of the back), the Defence must be filed and served within 28 days after the time for acknowledging service of the Writ, unless in the meantime a summons for judgment is served on the Defendant.
If a Statement of Claim is not indorsed on the Writ, the Defence must be filed and served within 28 days after a Statement of Claim has been served on the Defendant.
If the Defendant fails to file and serve his Defence within the appropriate time, the Plaintiff may enter judgment against him without further notice.
The Defendant’s defence must be verified by a statement of truth in accordance with Order 41A of the Rules of the District Court (Cap. 336 sub. leg. H).

3. If the only remedy that the Plaintiff is seeking is the payment of a liquidated amount of money or the payment of an unliquidated amount of money, you may admit the Plaintiff’s claim in whole or in part by completing Form No. 16 or 16C (as the case may require) accompanying the Writ of Summons.
A completed Form No. 16 or 16C must be filed with the Registry of the District Court and served on the Plaintiff [or the Plaintiff’s Solicitors] within the period for service of the Defence.

4. A Defendant who wishes to dispute the jurisdiction of the District Court in the proceedings or to argue that the District Court should not exercise its jurisdiction in the proceedings, and wishes to apply to the District Court for an order staying the proceedings, must give notice of intention to defend the proceedings and make the application within the time limited for service of a defence.
1. Each Defendant (if there are more than one) is required to complete an Acknowledgment of Service and return it to the Registry of the District Court.

[2. For the purpose of calculating the period of 14 days for acknowledging service, a writ served on the Defendant personally is treated as having been served on the day it was delivered to him and a writ served by post or by insertion through the Defendant’s letter box, or by sending it by electronic transmission in accordance with the Court Proceedings (Electronic Technology) (District Court Civil Proceedings) Rules (Cap. 638 sub. leg. C), is treated as having been served on the seventh day after the date of posting, insertion or sending by electronic transmission.]
(Note: Not applicable if the defendant is a company served at its registered office.)
3. Where the Defendant is sued in a name different from his own, the form must be completed by him with the addition in paragraph 1 of the words “sued as (the name stated on the Writ of Summons)”.

4. Where the Defendant is a FIRM and a Solicitor is not instructed, the form must be completed by a PARTNER by name, with the addition in paragraph 1 of the description “partner in the firm of (....................................)” after his name.

5. Where the Defendant is sued as an individual TRADING IN A NAME OTHER THAN HIS OWN, the form must be completed by him with the addition in paragraph 1 of the description “trading as (............................)” after his name.

6. Where the Defendant is a LIMITED COMPANY the form must be completed by a Solicitor or by someone authorized to act on behalf of the Company, but the Company can take no further step in the proceedings unless:

tr.td: a Solicitor is acting on its behalf; or
(ii)
if the Company has more than one director, a director of the Company is acting on its behalf and:
the director has been authorized by the board of directors of the Company to act on its behalf in the proceedings; and

the director has made and filed at the Registry of the District Court an affidavit stating that he has been authorized by the board of directors of the Company to act on its behalf in the proceedings and exhibiting—
(II)
a copy of such resolution duly certified by another person who must either be a director or the secretary of the Company; or
if the Company has only one director, the director of the Company is acting on its behalf.

paragraph.content: 7. Where the Defendant is a MINOR or a MENTAL Patient, the form must be completed by a Solicitor acting for a guardian ad litem.

7A. A Defendant (or a Solicitor acting on behalf of a Defendant) who has received a printout of a Writ of Summons issued by the District Court in electronic form may contact the Registry of the District Court to ascertain whether the Writ of Summons had been issued by quoting its document reference number. For details, please refer to the administrative instructions issued by the Judiciary Administrator.
8. A Defendant acting in person may obtain help in completing the form at the Registry of the District Court.
9. These notes deal only with the more usual cases. In case of difficulty a Defendant in person should refer to paragraph 8 above.
